Handling a Criminal Case in New York Highlights

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Publisher’s Introduction to the 2024-2025 Edition

Handling a Criminal Case in New York takes you step by step through each stage of a criminal case, from undertaking representation through arraignment, motion and hearing practice, trial, sentencing, and appeal. Written in a concise outline style, this publication answers virtually any question that may arise, integrating statutes and caselaw with practice tips.

 

Among the changes that this edition covers are:

          • FOIL: whether records of unsubstantiated complaints of police misconduct are exempt from disclosure. Newsday v. Nassau County Police Dept. § 8:122.

         • Scope of the “community caretaking function” of police. § 9:72.

         • Whether “lay opinion identification testimony” of a person in a photograph or video is admissible. People v. Mosley. § 9:233.

         • Requiring an identification procedure before trial where the witness has not identified the defendant previously. People v. Perdue. §§ 9:195, 9:217.

         • Abuse of scope of Sandoval, and restatement of Molineux rule. People v. Weinstein. §§ 11:4, 12:2.

         • Speedy trial: the first decision by the Court of Appeals on speedy trial and discovery: the prosecution’s failure to comply with due diligence in discovery, before filing a Certificate of Compliance. People v. Bay. § 13:13.

         • Improper conditions of probation, § 22:51.

         • Whether SORA minimized risks of inaccurate risk-level classifications with a defendant who lacked capacity. People v. Watt, citing Handling. § 23:78 .

         • Whether a gag order was subject to a writ of prohibition. Trump v. Engoron. § 23:10.

         • “Red flag” (ERPO) statute found constitutional by the Second Department, R.M. v. C.M. § 23:154.

         • Sealing: enactment of the Clean Slate Act, requiring sealing of misdemeanor and felony convictions. § 23:157.

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York About the Author

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

About the Author

Gary Muldoon has practiced law for more than four decades, in both the public and private sectors. He worked at the Monroe County Public Defender’s Office and for several years was law clerk to judges. While in private practice, he appeared in state and federal court, on trials and appeals, including arguing before the Court of Appeals. He has taught, including at the University at Buffalo, both law school and undergraduate school, and at Monroe Community College. He has written several books on legal issues. His articles have been published in the Buffalo Law Review and the New York Law Journal. He is a member of Kaman Berlove LLP and is a town judge in Perinton, Monroe County.

 

Education: B.A., Skidmore College, J.D., University at Buffalo Law School.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:1

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:1. Governing authority

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​5

 

 

Criminal practice in New York involves a mix of statutes, state regulations, the federal and New York State constitutions, and the caselaw that interprets them. Cf. People v. Torres, 37 N.Y.3d 256, 155 N.Y.S.3d 548, 177 N.E.3d 973 (2021) (civil negligence standard in administrative code provision is a constitutional mens rea for criminal liability).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:2

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:2. Governing authority—Statutes

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​5

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​13.1

 

 

The main criminal statutes in New York are the Penal Law and the Criminal Procedure Law. Substantive criminal law is covered by the Penal Law, which is based in part on the Model Penal Code (available on Westlaw, ULA-MPC). The Penal Law was effective September 1, 1967.

 

Procedural law is governed by the Criminal Procedure Law, which was effective September 1, 1971, replacing the Code of Criminal Procedure.

 

A number of other statutes that fall under the broad category of “criminal law” relate to particular offenses. For example, the crime of Driving While Intoxicated is found in the Vehicle and Traffic Law. Violation of a regulation may form the basis of criminal liability. See § 1:21, Ethical issues.

 

The Penal Law is not to be strictly construed but according to the fair import of its terms. Penal Law § 5.00; People v. Ditta, 52 N.Y.2d 657, 439 N.Y.S.2d 855, 422 N.E.2d 515 (1981). In construing statutes, a court must first examine the statutory language. Where the statute is clear and unambiguous, it should be construed to give effect to the plain meaning of its words as written. People v. Robinson, 95 N.Y.2d 179, 711 N.Y.S.2d 148, 733 N.E.2d 220 (2000). The statute should be given effect as written, not as the court thinks it should have been written. See People v. Boothe, 16 N.Y.3d 195, 919 N.Y.S.2d 498, 944 N.E.2d 1137 (2011). The court’s primary consideration is to ascertain and give effect to legislative intent. People v. Ballman, 15 N.Y.3d 68, 904 N.Y.S.2d 361, 930 N.E.2d 282 (2010). If the result would be unreasonable or absurd, the court may apply a different interpretation. People v. Santi, 3 N.Y.3d 234, 785 N.Y.S.2d 405, 818 N.E.2d 1146 (2004); People v. Graubard, 214 A.D.3d 143, 185 N.Y.S.3d 267 (2d Dep’t 2023).

 

Whether a statute is vague for due process purposes, the court must first decide whether the statute is sufficiently definite to give a person of ordinary intelligence fair notice that the contemplated conduct is forbidden. Words and phrases should be given ordinary meaning when there is no indication that a different meaning is intended. People v. Lanham, 177 A.D.3d 637, 113 N.Y.S.3d 119 (2d Dep’t 2019).

 

With an ameliorative statute, various factors and rules of construction may be considered in whether it should be given retroactive effect. People v. Dyshawn B., 196 A.D.3d 638, 152 N.Y.S.3d 131 (2d Dep’t 2021). Statutory amendments are normally applied prospectively. People v. George, 199 A.D.3d 831, 154 N.Y.S.3d 269 (2d Dep’t 2021) leave to appeal denied, 38 N.Y.3d 927, 164 N.Y.S.3d 24, 184 N.E.3d 845 (2022). Ameliorative or remedial legislation should normally be given retroactive effect, but the language of the statute may control. See People v. Castro, 223 A.D.3d 20, 202 N.Y.S.3d 66 (1st Dep’t 2023), leave to appeal denied, 41 N.Y.3d 964, 208 N.Y.S.3d 528, 232 N.E.3d 206 (2024). See § 24:96, Retroactivity.

 

Nonprocedural statutes are generally not to be applied retroactively. But an ameliorative amendment may allow for retroactivity. See People v. Parker, 228 A.D.3d 70, 210 N.Y.S.3d 873 (4th Dep’t 2024).

 

Practice Tip:

A helpful guide with statutory interpretation is McKinney’s Statutes, Book 1 of McKinney’s Consolidated Laws. (See also, Scalia and Garner, Reading Law.) Among these rules are:

§ 231: Every word to be given effect.

 

§ 239: Noscitur a sociis and ejusdem generis.

 

§ 240: Expression of one thing as excluding others.

 

§ 273: Intent as an implied element of criminal offense.

 

 

Both the Penal Law and CPL contain definitions of terms in that chapter, or in articles of that chapter. Where a term is undefined in a chapter, it may be appropriate to borrow a definition from the other. People v. Montilla, 10 N.Y.3d 663, 862 N.Y.S.2d 11, 891 N.E.2d 1175 (2008).

 

Where a word is not defined in the Penal Law provision under review, caselaw warns against relying upon a definition of that term in another Penal Law section, absent legislative authority for doing so. See People v. Hernandez, 98 N.Y.2d 175, 746 N.Y.S.2d 434, 774 N.E.2d 198 (2002).

 

Practice Tip:

While the CPL governs criminal procedures statewide, many local practices exist that are not covered by statute. These may involve bail applications, preliminary hearings, notice of grand jury presentation, discovery, announcement of speedy trial readiness, and plea bargaining.

 

The CPL refers to the Civil Practice Law and Rules in certain areas, e.g., rules of evidence, CPL 60.10, and service of a subpoena, CPL 610.25(3). Civil rules of evidence, where appropriate, apply to criminal cases. CPL 60.10; CPLR article 45. Unless expressly incorporated by the CPL, the Civil Practice Law and Rules is inapplicable to criminal actions. People v. Silva, 122 A.D.2d 750, 506 N.Y.S.2d 55 (1st Dep’t 1986). A criminal statute may incorporate by reference a civil statute. People v. Rodriguez, 158 A.D.3d 956, 73 N.Y.S.3d 251 (3d Dep’t 2018). But in many areas of criminal practice, decisions frequently reference the CPLR.

 

In addition to state statutes, New York State has entered into a number of “compacts” with other states, particularly with reference to interstate issues. These agreements, e.g., provide for reciprocal disclosure of information regarding driving records. VTL §§ 516 et seq. See § 4:33, Mandatory suspension with .08% DWI: hardship privilege.

 

Finally, civil law remedies do not apply in criminal cases. See People v. Iverson, 37 N.Y.3d 98, 148 N.Y.S.3d 173, 170 N.E.3d 728 (2021). See also People v. Hernandez, 62 Misc. 3d 9, 89 N.Y.S.3d 513 (App. Term 2018) (default judgment); People v. DeSabato, 68 Misc. 3d 133(A), 130 N.Y.S.3d 593 (App. Term 2020).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:3

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:3. Governing authority—State regulations

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​5

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​13.1

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:4

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:4. Governing authority—Federal prosecution

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​5

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​13.1

 

 

Because this Practice Guide is limited to state court practice, federal criminal statutes, found mainly in Title 18 and Title 21 U.S. Code, are not covered.

 

Under the dual sovereignty rule, where a defendant is charged in state court, double jeopardy does not bar a federal prosecution. Abbate v. U.S., 359 U.S. 187, 79 S. Ct. 666, 3 L. Ed. 2d 729 (1959); U.S. v. Sewell, 252 F.3d 647 (2d Cir. 2001). See § 15:99, Double jeopardy.

 

Even where there has been a federal prosecution, it may be possible for a state prosecution arising out of the same transaction to be brought, despite the bar against double jeopardy, People v. Bryant, 92 N.Y.2d 216, 677 N.Y.S.2d 286, 699 N.E.2d 910 (1998); Polito v. Walsh, 8 N.Y.3d 683, 840 N.Y.S.2d 1, 871 N.E.2d 537 (2007); cf. Schmidt on Behalf of McNell v. Roberts, 74 N.Y.2d 513, 549 N.Y.S.2d 633, 548 N.E.2d 1284 (1989), where the charge contains a different element not found in the other, and the provisions are designed to prevent different kinds of harm. Martinucci v. Becker, 50 A.D.3d 1293, 855 N.Y.S.2d 718 (3d Dep’t 2008).

 

A defendant who waives constitutional defenses and pleads guilty in state court cannot raise those defenses in a later federal prosecution. U.S. v. Gregg, 2002 WL 1808235 (S.D. N.Y. 2002).

 

Example:

Defendant pleaded guilty in federal court to possessing drugs on a certain date. He was also indicted in state court for drug possession and sale occurring on a different date. The state charge was proper: the two offenses are separate and distinct. People v. Gray, 300 A.D.2d 696, 752 N.Y.S.2d 731 (3d Dep’t 2002). See § 15:99, Double jeopardy.

 

Under the U.S. Department of Justice’s “Petite policy,” a defendant should not be subjected to successive prosecutions for a single transaction, unless there is a compelling federal interest. Petite v. U.S., 361 U.S. 529, 80 S. Ct. 450, 4 L. Ed. 2d 490 (1960).

 

Practice Tip:

Despite the Petite policy, an increasing overlap has occurred with federal prosecutions of what was once prosecuted in state court, including controlled substances, weapons possession, bank robbery, child pornography, and identity theft, among others. Some charges that are initially filed in state court may be dismissed, and be eventually filed in federal court. No double jeopardy violation arises from this.

 

Where there is the possibility of federal prosecution, defense counsel in negotiating a plea bargain should consider obtaining a letter from the assistant DA to the effect that the federal prosecutor has been contacted and has indicated that no prosecution will occur, or place on the record that the ADA was in contact with the federal prosecutor, who has evaluated the case already.

 

A state crime committed on federal property may be prosecuted in federal court at the same offense level. 18 U.S.C.A. § 13.

 

A defendant who is charged in both state and federal courts may face difficult sentencing questions whether the defendant is in “primary state custody” or “primary federal custody.” See § 22:28, Effect of “primary” state or federal custody.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:5

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:5. Governing authority—Federal prosecution—The two constitutions

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​3

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​5

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​13.1

 

 

Because U.S. Supreme Court rulings have narrowed the scope of certain protections for defendants under the Federal Constitution, interpretations of the State Constitution by the New York Court of Appeals have become an important factor in state criminal practice. Court of Appeals decisions have provided defendants with rights that have a greater impact on the constitutional issues in a criminal case. See § 15:87, State constitution as separate basis. States are free to provide greater protections in their criminal justice systems than the Federal Constitution requires. California v. Ramos, 463 U.S. 992, 103 S. Ct. 3446, 77 L. Ed. 2d 1171 (1983).

 

Under the Supremacy Clause, federal laws are the supreme law of the land. U.S. Const. Art. VI, clause 2. Where a conflict exists between lower federal courts and the New York Court of Appeals, state courts are bound by the rulings of the New York Court of Appeals. People v. Jackson, 46 A.D.3d 1110, 847 N.Y.S.2d 743 (3d Dep’t 2007). See also People v. Kin Kan, 78 N.Y.2d 54, 571 N.Y.S.2d 436, 574 N.E.2d 1042 (1991) (Second Circuit’s rulings are useful and persuasive but not binding); People v. Pignataro, 22 N.Y.3d 381, 980 N.Y.S.2d 899, 3 N.E.3d 1147 (2013).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:6

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:6. Governing authority—Caselaw

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​3

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​5

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​10

 

 

Many procedures and rules of law now firmly imbedded in criminal practice are known by the Court of Appeals decisions that established them. These include the Huntley hearing, in which a defendant can attempt to have a previous statement suppressed, Ch 9, Suppression; Molineux principles regulating the degree to which guilt may be proved by prior crimes, Ch 12, Proving Guilt With Uncharged Crimes; and the Sandoval inquiry, governing the extent to which a defendant who chooses to testify may be cross-examined about prior crimes and bad acts. Ch 11, Defendant’s Decision to Testify.

 

Similarly, from the U.S. Supreme Court, the Miranda label identifies the warnings that must be given to an individual being held in custody before questioning can occur, while Wade and Mapp have become synonymous with the hearings held on suppression of identifications and physical evidence. Ch 9, Suppression.

 

The doctrine of stare decisis (literally, “to stand by things decided”) is an important legal principle that compels courts to follow established precedent when ruling on cases with similar facts. Mountain View Coach Lines, Inc. v. Storms, 102 A.D.2d 663, 476 N.Y.S.2d 918 (2d Dep’t 1984); People v. Shakur, 215 A.D.2d 184, 627 N.Y.S.2d 341 (1st Dep’t 1995); People v. Turner, 5 N.Y.3d 476, 806 N.Y.S.2d 154, 840 N.E.2d 123 (2005); cf. People v. Brisotti, 169 Misc. 2d 672, 652 N.Y.S.2d 206 (App. Term 1996). The Appellate Term is not bound by a contrary determination of an Appellate Division. People v. Wheeler, 61 Misc. 3d 30, 85 N.Y.S.3d 329 (App. Term 2018), reversed on other grounds, 34 N.Y.3d 1134, 118 N.Y.S.3d 68, 141 N.E.3d 136 (2020).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:7

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:7. Prosecution by the state

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​3

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​5

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​10

 

 

Although an individual complainant often initiates the filing of charges in court, the criminal case is always prosecuted by the government in the name of the “People of the State of New York.”CPL 1.20(1). The prosecutor does not represent the complainant. See § 1:67, Questioning by defense; § 3:5, Prosecutorial discretion to determine charges to be filed.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:8

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:8. Relief sought; civil action after conviction

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1407

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1409

 

 

In its most obvious sense, the “relief” sought in a criminal case is a criminal conviction with additional sanctions. These may include a sentence of incarceration, fine, surcharge, probation, or community service. See § 22:1, Sentencing alternatives often available.

 

Complainants may also want to use the conviction after trial, or the statements by a defendant who pleads guilty, in a later civil action for monetary damages. See §§ 22:201 et seq., Collateral estoppel effect of criminal conviction.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:9

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:9. Prosecutor: the district attorney

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​644

 

 

In most criminal cases the State is represented by the district attorney (the “DA”) who, with his/her deputies (Assistant District Attorneys, or “ADAs”) is responsible for conducting the prosecution of crimes within a given jurisdiction. County Law § 700. In doing so, however, the Rules of Professional Conduct calls on these lawyers not just to win cases, but to seek justice. See § 1:21, Ethical issues.

 

The prosecutor does not represent the complainant/victim, but rather the People. As a result, the prosecutor retains discretion regarding which cases to select for prosecution. See §§ 1:66 et seq., Role of the complainant. The district attorney has broad powers as to plea bargaining. See § 17:6, Plea negotiations generally discretionary with prosecutor.

 

The district attorney’s powers are statutory in nature; absent statutory authority, a prosecutor is not empowered to commence a civil action. Czajka v. Breedlove, 200 A.D.2d 263, 613 N.Y.S.2d 741 (3d Dep’t 1994); see also Doe v. Connell, 179 A.D.2d 196, 583 N.Y.S.2d 707 (4th Dep’t 1992); Winn v. Rensselaer County Conditional Release Com’n, 6 A.D.3d 929, 775 N.Y.S.2d 412 (3d Dep’t 2004) (prosecutor’s powers include ensuring that sentences are carried out, and may bring a proceeding to review legality of determination of local conditional release commission). A district attorney’s office may represent itself in an appeal under the Freedom of Information Law. Pennington v. Clark, 307 A.D.2d 756, 763 N.Y.S.2d 191 (4th Dep’t 2003). A prosecutor may bring a state forfeiture action.

 

Practice Tip:

A prosecutor other than the district attorney may be involved in cases involving correctional institutions, juveniles, the elderly in mental institutions, or protected situations: Justice Center for the Protection of People with Special Needs. Exec. Law § 551. See People v. Davidson, 27 N.Y.3d 1083, 36 N.Y.S.3d 54, 55 N.E.3d 1027 (2016). See http://www.justicecenter.ny.gov/.

 

Individual district attorney’s offices are organized in various ways. A particular district attorney’s office may be divided according to the type of cases that arises, or the courts that are covered.

 

While there are many members of a district attorney’s office, the representations and knowledge of one assistant may be attributable to another. Santobello v. New York, 404 U.S. 257, 92 S. Ct. 495, 30 L. Ed. 2d 427 (1971); Giglio v. U.S., 405 U.S. 150, 92 S. Ct. 763, 31 L. Ed. 2d 104 (1972); People v. Simmons, 36 N.Y.2d 126, 365 N.Y.S.2d 812, 325 N.E.2d 139 (1975); People v. Steadman, 82 N.Y.2d 1, 603 N.Y.S.2d 382, 623 N.E.2d 509 (1993).

 

Authority to prosecute in a state court may rest with:

         • the county district attorney

         • State Attorney General’s Office

         • Medicaid Fraud Control Unit, part of the AG’s office

         • State Organized Crime Task Force, part of the AG’s office

         • Justice Center for the Protection of People with Special Needs. Exec L § 552. But see People v. Viviani, 36 N.Y.3d 564, 145 N.Y.S.3d 512, 169 N.E.3d 224 (2021) (holding Executive Law § 552 unconstitutional, regarding creation of special prosecutor, and severing other portions).

         • special prosecutor

         • municipal attorney.

 

A Commission on Prosecutorial Conduct was enacted, Judiciary Law article 15-a, §§ 499-a et seq. The Commission may review and refer complaints of prosecutorial misconduct to a grievance committee. Located within the executive department, the commission has authority to review whether prosecutor conduct departs from applicable law and ethical standards. Its constitutionality is in question. See Soares v. State, 68 Misc. 3d 249, 121 N.Y.S.3d 790 (Sup 2020).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:10

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:10. Prosecutor: the district attorney—Attorney General as prosecutor

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​644

 

 

In addition to the district attorney, the New York State Attorney General has prosecutorial powers as well. Upon a referral from a state agency (which may include the State Police), the Attorney General may exercise jurisdiction.

 

The State Attorney General typically handles criminal matters involving state agencies, and may prosecute such matters as environmental crimes and Labor Law violations. Exec Law § 63.

 

The jurisdiction of the State Attorney General’s office is limited by statute. Where the consent or authorization of another entity is required, such as the governor or county district attorney, this must be obtained. People v. Gilmour, 98 N.Y.2d 126, 746 N.Y.S.2d 114, 773 N.E.2d 479 (2002); People v. Cuttita, 7 N.Y.3d 500, 824 N.Y.S.2d 771, 858 N.E.2d 318 (2006); People v. Fox, 253 A.D.2d 192, 692 N.Y.S.2d 174 (3d Dep’t 1999); see also People v. Marketing and Advertising Services Center Corp., 272 A.D.2d 982, 708 N.Y.S.2d 227 (4th Dep’t 2000); cf. People v. Adams, 2 Misc. 3d 166, 766 N.Y.S.2d 765 (County Ct. 2003) (written approval of Governor or district attorney not required); Kimyagarova v. Spitzer, 16 A.D.3d 507, 791 N.Y.S.2d 610 (2d Dep’t 2005); People v. Quadrozzi, 55 A.D.3d 93, 863 N.Y.S.2d 455 (2d Dep’t 2008) (Environmental Conservation Law); People v. Wassell, 171 A.D.3d 1499, 99 N.Y.S.3d 166 (4th Dep’t 2019).

 

Unlawful practice of law may be pursued by the Attorney General in civil and criminal proceedings. Jud L § 476-a.

 

The Attorney General may supersede a local prosecutor in a case brought pursuant to direction of the governor. Johnson v. Pataki, 91 N.Y.2d 214, 668 N.Y.S.2d 978, 691 N.E.2d 1002 (1997).

 

The Statewide Organized Crime Task Force is part of the Attorney General’s office. Exec Law § 70-a; see People v. Rallo, supra; Sussman v. New York State Organized Crime Task Force, 39 N.Y.2d 227, 383 N.Y.S.2d 276, 347 N.E.2d 638 (1976). Where the OCTF brings a charge under Executive Law § 70-a(7), it must be shown that the governor gave approval, that the district attorney requested or gave approval, and that the proceeding is concerned with multicounty or interstate conduct. It is not necessary to show that there are organized crime activities. People v. Rallo, 39 N.Y.2d 217, 383 N.Y.S.2d 271, 347 N.E.2d 633 (1976). See also People v. Fezza, 1 A.D.3d 808, 769 N.Y.S.2d 613 (3d Dep’t 2003).

 

A district attorney may enlist the help of an assistant attorney general, provided the appointment is made under the County Law and the district attorney retains ultimate prosecutorial authority of the case. People v. Mazzeo, 191 A.D.3d 1171, 143 N.Y.S.3d 427 (3d Dep’t 2021). An assistant attorney general who serves as an acting district attorney must be a resident of the county. Pub Off Law § 3. However, residency is not jurisdictional in nature. Haggerty v. Himelein, 89 N.Y.2d 431, 654 N.Y.S.2d 705, 677 N.E.2d 276 (1997); People v. Carter, 77 N.Y.2d 95, 564 N.Y.S.2d 992, 566 N.E.2d 119 (1990).

 

The attorney general must be notified and may appear, where the constitutionality of a state statute is questioned. See § 15:90, Notice to Attorney General required.

 

Where the State Attorney General is prosecuting a case, defense counsel should consider bringing a motion to challenge the AG’s jurisdiction. See § 6:7, Unauthorized presence improper; § 7:56, Affirmation in support of omnibus motion.

 

With repeated fraudulent or illegal business transactions and other matters, the AG’s office has broad authority to issue subpoenas. Exec L § 63(12), EPTL 8-1.4(i), N-FPCL § 112(b)(6). The office can subpoena and examine witnesses under oath. Failure to respond to the subpoena is punishable as a misdemeanor. Gen Bus L § 352(2),(3); see Judiciary Law § 751(4). See also Judiciary Law § 476-c (unlawful practice of law). See Haig, Commercial Litigation in New York State Courts § 90:17 (4th ed.). Similarly, willful failure to comply with a subpoena from the State Tax Department is a misdemeanor. Tax L § 1831. See Comiskey, “New Criminal Tax Laws,” New York State Bar Journal, Nov.-Dec. 2009, p. 11.

 

The Attorney General’s subpoena must be issued pursuant to legitimate authority and seek relevant information, and must have some factual basis for the inquisitorial action. Roemer v. Cuomo, 67 A.D.3d 1169, 888 N.Y.S.2d 669 (3d Dep’t 2009). An application to quash a subpoena should be granted only where the futility of the process to uncover anything legitimate is inevitable, obvious, or where the information sought is utterly irrelevant to any proper inquiry. Hogan v. Cuomo, 67 A.D.3d 1144, 888 N.Y.S.2d 665, 250 Ed. Law Rep. 746 (3d Dep’t 2009). See § 8:118, Motion to quash.

 

Practice Tip:

The AG’s office may use the same grand jury that the local DA’s office uses, or impanel a different one.

 

Medicaid fraud prosecutions are part of the Attorney General’s office, handled by the Medicaid Fraud Control Unit. Under the Executive Law, this office prosecutes fraud in connection with Medicaid as administered in and by New York State. See People v. Miran, 107 A.D.3d 28, 964 N.Y.S.2d 309 (4th Dep’t 2013) (AG’s office authorized to prosecute Medicare-related crimes).

 

Securities fraud prosecutions under the Martin Act, General Business Law article 23-A, are also under the Attorney General’s jurisdiction.

 

Under Executive Order 147, the Attorney General has authority to act as special prosecutor in all matters involving the death of an unarmed civilian, whether in custody or not, caused by a law enforcement officer. See Abelove v. Cuomo, 57 Misc. 3d 668, 61 N.Y.S.3d 837 (Sup 2017). But see People v. Abelove, 179 A.D.3d 39, 113 N.Y.S.3d 378 (3d Dep’t 2019).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:11

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:11. Prosecutor: the district attorney—State Inspector General

Correlation Table

The New York State Inspector General is authorized to conduct certain investigations. See People v. Sutera, 107 A.D.3d 556, 968 N.Y.S.2d 442 (1st Dep’t 2013).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:12

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:12. Prosecutor: the district attorney—Special prosecutor

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​644

 

 

A “special district attorney” may be appointed by a County or Supreme Court judge when the local prosecutor’s office is disqualified. Once appointed, a special prosecutor has the same powers as the local prosecutor in relation to the particular case. County Law § 701; 22 NYCRR § 200.15. This includes the authority to confer immunity, as does a prosecutor. See People v. Abrams, 17 N.Y.3d 760, 929 N.Y.S.2d 30, 952 N.E.2d 1022 (2011). While a superior court must appoint, a lower court may disqualify. People v. Nelson, 167 Misc. 2d 665, 647 N.Y.S.2d 438 (NYC Crim. Ct. 1995). A special prosecutor may appear before a grand jury. Exec. Law § 552(2)(c).

 

The statute’s superseder authority should not be expansively interpreted. Soares v. Herrick, 20 N.Y.3d 139, 957 N.Y.S.2d 664, 981 N.E.2d 260 (2012). Courts should remove a public prosecutor only to protect a defendant from actual prejudice arising from a demonstrated conflict of interest or a substantial risk of an abuse of confidence. Schumer v. Holtzman, 60 N.Y.2d 46, 467 N.Y.S.2d 182, 454 N.E.2d 522 (1983). See § 7:21, Disqualification of district attorney.

 

The disqualification of a prosecutor and appointment of a special prosecutor is reviewable via a writ of prohibition. McNamara v. Tormey, 42 A.D.3d 971, 839 N.Y.S.2d 386 (4th Dep’t 2007). See §§ 23:5 et seq., Actions of court that will support writ. The appearance of impropriety (such as a civil suit against the prosecutor) is insufficient; the objector must demonstrate actual prejudice or so substantial a risk thereof as could not be ignored. Soares v. Herrick, supra.

 

A defendant may challenge the appointment of a special prosecutor, which should be made within four months. A prosecutor may step aside on a good faith application that contains reasonable grounds for believing he was disqualified. Recusal applications should be addressed on a case-by-case basis and recusal is not required in all cases where a prosecutor is investigating a police officer. See Pinney v. Van Houten, 168 A.D.3d 1293, 92 N.Y.S.3d 468 (3d Dep’t 2019).

 

Once a special prosecutor is appointed, the district attorney’s authority is terminated. People v. Dellavalle, 259 A.D.2d 773, 687 N.Y.S.2d 199 (3d Dep’t 1999).

 

Example:

Where the prosecutor was a former judge who had presided over a case, disqualification was required. Jud. Law § 17; Czajka v. Koweek, 100 A.D.3d 1136, 953 N.Y.S.2d 394 (3d Dep’t 2012).

 

A defendant was related to an assistant district attorney. In this situation the prosecutor’s office was disqualified and a special prosecutor appointed. People v. Nuzzi, 128 Misc. 2d 502, 489 N.Y.S.2d 836 (Sup 1985).

 

No appointment of a special prosecutor was required with the following:

 

The district attorney office’s motion to appoint a special prosecutor was denied. No prosecutor was implicated in any misconduct. That office was not disqualified from investigating and perhaps prosecuting police officers based on evidence produced from a crime laboratory. The authority to supersede rests with the governor. In re Rice, 31 Misc. 3d 838, 924 N.Y.S.2d 743 (Sup 2011).

 

A defendant’s civil suit against the district attorney, relating to the criminal charge, does not necessarily require removal of the district attorney. Soares v. Herrick, 20 N.Y.3d 139, 957 N.Y.S.2d 664, 981 N.E.2d 260 (2012).

 

The fact that an ADA was a complainant in an unrelated case did not create an appearance of impropriety. Flynn v. DiTullio, 228 A.D.3d 1323, 2024 WL 2987731 (4th Dep’t 2024).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:13

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:13. Prosecutor: the district attorney—Outside counsel to assist at trial

Correlation Table

Where a case presents “unusual difficulty upon the trial thereof,” a district attorney may apply to county court for authority to employ counsel outside the district attorney’s office to assist at trial. County Law § 702.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:14

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:14. Prosecutor: the district attorney—Municipal attorneys

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​644

 

 

A town or village attorney may prosecute violations of local ordinances, which may have penal sanctions. Procedures in the CPL applicable to misdemeanors apply to zoning law violations. Town Law § 268; Village Law § 20-2006; see § 1:43, Parking violations and municipal ordinances; § 19:59, Local ordinances.

 

The district attorney is a quasi-judicial officer whose chief function is to enforce state law. Representing the civil interests of a complainant or the police can engender an appearance of impropriety or conflict of interest. Cowles v. Brownell, 73 N.Y.2d 382, 540 N.Y.S.2d 973, 538 N.E.2d 325 (1989); Kurlander v. Davis, 103 Misc. 2d 919, 427 N.Y.S.2d 376 (Sup 1980).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:15

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:15. Prosecutor: the district attorney—Prosecution of traffic infractions

Correlation Table

Traffic infractions may be prosecuted by a police officer rather than an ADA. People v. Soddano, 86 N.Y.2d 727, 631 N.Y.S.2d 120, 655 N.E.2d 161 (1995); People v. Christensen, 21 Misc. 3d 608, 864 N.Y.S.2d 845 (Sup 2008), judgment aff’d, 77 A.D.3d 174, 906 N.Y.S.2d 301 (2d Dep’t 2010). See also Sedore v. Epstein, 56 A.D.3d 60, 864 N.Y.S.2d 543 (2d Dep’t 2008) (district attorney may delegate authority to prosecute to other public officials and to an attorney outside of the prosecutor’s office but not to an attorney retained by the complainant); People v. Winsor, 53 Misc. 3d 1159, 42 N.Y.S.3d 525 (NYC Crim. Ct. 2016).

 

It is the policy of the New York State Police that they will not plea bargain traffic tickets in court. The State Police policy of no plea bargaining has been upheld. People v. Murphy, 29 Misc. 3d 79, 912 N.Y.S.2d 372 (App. Term 2010). A trial judge may not offer a plea to a reduced charge without the consent of the People’s representative.

 

Practice Tip:

While a police officer may present the traffic charge at trial, defense counsel may object “as to form” where the presentation is a narrative, requesting that a question-and-answer format be used. See Altkrug v. Horowitz, 111 A.D. 420, 97 N.Y.S. 716 (2d Dep’t 1906).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:16

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:16. Prosecutor: the district attorney—Private prosecution (cross-complaint)

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​644

 

 

A private person may seek to prosecute a criminal charge. For example, a “cross-complaint” might be filed by one defendant against the original complainant. A private prosecutor is held to the same standards of fairness that a district attorney would uphold. Such a prosecution must be conducted with the knowledge and consent of the district attorney. People v. Soddano, 86 N.Y.2d 727, 631 N.Y.S.2d 120, 655 N.E.2d 161 (1995). See § 3:5, Prosecutorial discretion to determine charges to be filed. A district attorney may delegate to others, including private attorneys, the authority to prosecute a criminal charge. People v. Cervera, 40 Misc. 3d 89, 971 N.Y.S.2d 789 (App. Term 2013). However, a private person has no standing to bring criminal prosecution. Linda R.S. v. Richard D., 410 U.S. 614, 93 S. Ct. 1146, 35 L. Ed. 2d 536 (1973).

 

A district attorney may not delegate the authority to prosecute a criminal offense to the complainant’s retained private attorney, but only to public officials, such as a police officer or town attorney. Sedore v. Epstein, 56 A.D.3d 60, 864 N.Y.S.2d 543 (2d Dep’t 2008).

 

The policy of denying an arrestee the right to have a cross-complaint entertained on the same basis as the original complaint may violate equal protection. Myers v. County of Orange, 157 F.3d 66 (2d Cir. 1998).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:17

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:17. Defense counsel

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1840

 

 

Although a criminal defendant may retain private counsel, many—perhaps most—cannot afford to do so. Therefore, in most counties in New York there is a Legal Aid Society or Public Defender’s Office, whose obligation is to represent indigents accused of crimes. Some counties have a “conflict defender” office that represents defendants who have a conflict of interest with someone represented by the county’s Public Defender office.

 

In some counties, an assigned counsel program (ACP) may provide such representation.

 

Due to significant deficiencies of indigent defense representation due to high caseloads, and uneven quality of representation across the state, an Office of Indigent Legal Services (ILS) has been established. Exec Law § 832(1). In 2014, a class action suit against New York State and several counties (Hurrell-Harring v. State) was settled, resulting in an agreement that included capping the number of cases that an institutional defender would be required to handle annually.

 

A defendant who has income sufficient to retain an attorney is not entitled to Legal Aid/Public Defender representation, but often there is no screening system and a simple statement of inability to pay for private counsel will result in an assignment. Other courts will require a sworn financial affidavit.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:18

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:18. Defense counsel—Defense organizations

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1710

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1840

 

 

Defense organizations include the New York State Defenders Association, 194 Washington Avenue, Suite 500, Albany, NY 12210-2314, (518) 465-3524, fax (518) 465-3249, www.nysda.org, the New York State Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, 90 State Street, Suite 700, Albany, NY 12207, (212) 532-4434, fax (888) 239-4665. http://www.nysacdl.org/contact/, and Office of Indigent Legal Services, 80 South Swan Street, Suite 1147, Albany, NY 12210, (518) 486-2028, https://www.ils.ny.gov/.

 

ILS has issued a report on best practices in areas of criminal representation, including:

         • appellate practice, https://www.ils.ny.gov/files/Appellate%20Standards%20Final%20100423.pdf.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:19

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:19. Defense counsel—Private attorneys for indigent defendants

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1710

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1840

 

 

When a defendant is indigent but there is a conflict of interest with the Legal Aid/Public Defender Office, and there is no conflict defender office, a private defense attorney will be assigned by a judge to represent the defendant. See §§ 2:20 et seq., The assigned counsel system: 18-B.

 

Such a conflict may occur, for example, if one defendant is represented by a Legal Aid or Public Defender office, considered the functional equivalent of one large law firm.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:20

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:20. Defense counsel—Pro se representation

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1710

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1835

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1840

 

 

A defendant who wishes to do so has the right to represent him/herself in a criminal proceeding. See § 2:5, Right to proceed pro se.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:21

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:21. Ethical issues

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​32(2)

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

Ethics rules for attorneys are contained in the Rules of Professional Conduct, 22 NYCRR part 1200. Generally, see Hall, Professional Responsibility in Criminal Defense Practice, 4th ed.; Simon’s New York Rules of Professional Conduct Annotated.

 

In a criminal case, various ethical issues may confront a defense attorney, including:

         • preserving client confidences, see § 2:47, Attorney-client privilege; § 2:101, Assertion of claim may waive confidentiality; § 18:33, Privileged communications; § 23:51, Ineffective assistance of counsel.

         • where a client seeks to testify and commit perjury, see § 2:90, Perjury intended by defendant.

         • conflict of interest due to representing more than one client, see § 2:50, Conflict may require new counsel; duty to inquire, or differences with client, see § 14:2, Representation by separate counsel.

         • handling fruits of a crime from a client, In re Ryder, 263 F. Supp. 360 (E.D. Va. 1967), judgment aff’d, 381 F.2d 713 (4th Cir. 1967); NYSBA Ethical Opinion 530, 1981 WL 27591; 54 Am. Crim. L. Rev. 751 (2017); see ABA Standards for Criminal Justice, Defense Function, § 4-4.6.

         • contacting a codefendant who is represented by another attorney, RPC 4.2(a); cf. Grievance Committee for Southern Dist. of New York v. Simels, 48 F.3d 640 (2d Cir. 1995); NYS Bar Ethics Opinion 466, 1977 WL 15694; see § 14:2, Representation by separate counsel.

         • contact with complainants, see § 1:69, Defense seeking to have complainant drop charges.

         • posting bail for a client.

         • competence in using technology.

 

Other issues facing a defense attorney include:

         • assigned billing matters, see §§ 2:20 et seq., The assigned counsel system: 18-B.

         • with a retainer, avoiding a “minimum nonrefundable fee” arrangement, see § 2:37, Prohibitions regarding fees.

         • neglecting representation, see § 24:67, Appellate delay as an appellate issue.

         • malpractice and effective assistance of counsel, see §§ 2:103 et seq., Legal malpractice, and §§ 2:69 et seq., Effective/ineffective assistance of counsel.

         • not advising a witness to leave the jurisdiction to be unavailable as a witness, RPC 3.4(a)(2).

 

Among the issues that confront prosecutors are:

         • the district attorney’s decision on whether and how to proceed with a criminal charge, including not proceeding with charges that are baseless, RPC 3.8.

         • disclosure of favorable and other required materials to the defense, see Matter of Kurtzrock, 192 A.D.3d 197, 138 N.Y.S.3d 649 (2d Dep’t 2020); Matter of Rain, 162 A.D.3d 1458, 79 N.Y.S.3d 387 (3d Dep’t 2018), see § 8:22, Brady material (favorable information).

         • illusory announcement of readiness for trial, see § 13:23, “Illusory” statement of readiness.

         • to not reveal grand jury testimony, see § 6:6, Proceedings conducted in secret.

 

Among the issues that confront both sides are:

         • the rule against being both an advocate and a witness, RPC 3.7. See § 2:51, Advocate-witness rule; § 7:21, Disqualification of district attorney.

         Practice Tip:

         While an attorney may not violate the advocate-witness rule or become an unsworn witness, an attorney of record as an “officer of the court” may issue a subpoena, CPL 610.20, and may make representations to the court without being placed under oath. People v. Hameed, 88 N.Y.2d 232, 644 N.Y.S.2d 466, 666 N.E.2d 1339 (1996).

          

         • avoiding ex parte communication with a judge, RPC 3.5. See § 19:68, Ex parte and in camera proceedings infrequent.

         • the trial judge’s role as to how the case will proceed, Balter v. Regan, 63 N.Y.2d 630, 479 N.Y.S.2d 506, 468 N.E.2d 688 (1984).

         • avoiding review of inadvertently disclosed information that is privileged or confidential. NYC Ethics Opinion 2003-04, 2003 WL 23789274; see People v. Terry, 1 Misc. 3d 475, 764 N.Y.S.2d 592 (County Ct. 2003).

         • misconduct at trial in presenting evidence and jury argument, see § 18:231, Objections to prosecutor’s summation.

         • the obligation to not cite misleading legal authority.

         • contact with jurors, RPC 3.5, see § 20:35, Juror misconduct. According to an ABA ethical opinion, a lawyer may review a juror or potential juror’s Internet presence, including posting in advance of and during a trial. But the lawyer may not communicate directly or indirectly with a juror or potential juror. The attorney may not send an “access request” to a juror’s social media. ABA Ethics Opinion 466.

         • not making statements to the media that will likely prejudice the proceeding. See § 19:53, “Gag orders.”

         Example:

         The prosecutor’s statements to the press were prejudicial to the administration of justice and resulted in disciplinary action. In re Soares, 97 A.D.3d 242, 947 N.Y.S.2d 233 (4th Dep’t 2012).

          

         • misconduct in issuing subpoenas, see § 8:99, Subpoena not to be used in place of discovery; § 8:110, Court discretion to issue; improper issuance by either side.

         • the duty to be candid and honest with the court, RPC 3.3; In re Bybel, 121 A.D.3d 286, 991 N.Y.S.2d 502 (4th Dep’t 2014); In re Rodeman, 65 A.D.3d 350, 883 N.Y.S.2d 835 (4th Dep’t 2009).

 

Additionally, it is improper for an attorney to record a conversation without first informing the other person to the conversation that it is being recorded. NYS Bar Ethics Opinion 328 (1974); Opinion 515, 1979 WL 15770; cf. Mena v. Key Food Stores Co-op., Inc., 195 Misc. 2d 402, 758 N.Y.S.2d 246 (Sup 2003). See § 9:111, Private recording of conversations.

 

The Rules of Professional Conduct, 22 NYCRR part 1200, should not be applied as if they were controlling statutory authority or decisional law. People v. Berroa, 99 N.Y.2d 134, 753 N.Y.S.2d 12, 782 N.E.2d 1148 (2002); cf. People v. Addimando, 197 A.D.3d 106, 152 N.Y.S.3d 33 (2d Dep’t 2021). Compare People v. Garson, 6 N.Y.3d 604, 815 N.Y.S.2d 887, 848 N.E.2d 1264 (2006) (using Rules Governing Judicial Conduct to prove element of crime); People v. Gordon, 72 A.D.3d 841, 898 N.Y.S.2d 257 (2d Dep’t 2010) (Code of Ethics in Public Officers Law imposes mandatory duty on state legislators). See also, People v. Casiano, 117 A.D.3d 1507, 984 N.Y.S.2d 781 (4th Dep’t 2014) (violation of regulation setting forth professional misconduct does not form the basis for criminal liability); People v. Barnes, 117 A.D.3d 1203, 984 N.Y.S.2d 693 (3d Dep’t 2014) (officer’s misconduct was disciplinable but not criminal). But see People v. Flanagan, 28 N.Y.3d 644, 49 N.Y.S.3d 50, 71 N.E.3d 541 (2017) (misconduct may occur even where the public servant’s duty is couched with discretion).

 

Ethics opinions of the New York State Bar Association can be found on the nysba.org website at: http://www.nysba.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Ethics_Opinions&Template=/TaggedPage/TaggedPageDisplay.cfm&TPLID=7&ContentID=21454. On Westlaw, these opinions are available under the subdirectory NYETH-EO. American Bar Association ethics opinions are found on Westlaw at ABA-ETHOP.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:22

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:22. Judge’s ethical obligations

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​32(2)

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.4

 

 

A judge is under a number of ethical obligations as well. In criminal law, these include:

         • avoiding comment on a pending case, 22 NYCRR § 100.3(A)(8).

         • disqualification where the judge’s impartiality might reasonably be questioned, 22 NYCRR § 100.3(E)(1). See § 19:64, Judicial disqualification.

         • to not convey to the jury any opinion of a witness, see § 18:219, Statements in jury’s presence may cause reversal.

         • avoiding ex parte communications, see § 19:67, Judicial conduct. An impermissible ex parte communication may generally be dispelled by disclosing it to all sides. Advisory Committee on Judicial Ethics, Opinion 23-138.

        Other ethical issues are addressed in §§ 18:219 to 18:23021 18:221, The issue of judicial bias.

          

 

Serious misconduct by a judge is reviewed by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, www.scjc.state.ny.us. The decisions of the State Commission on Judicial Conduct are available on Westlaw at NYETH-DISP.

 

Recusal is not required where a defendant files a complaint against the judge. See § 19:65, Nonstatutory grounds for disqualification.

 

A judge ordinarily has discretion to determine what appropriate action should be taken, but where misconduct calls into question the honesty, trustworthiness, or fitness as a lawyer, reporting is required. Once filed, the judge must disqualify in all cases involving that attorney while the disciplinary matter is pending and for two years after. Also, the judge should normally not reveal the reason for disqualification except to the extent required by law, unless the attorney waives confidentiality. NYS Bar Opinion 22-122.

 

One resource for judges is the Advisory Committee on Judicial Ethics, Office of Court Administration, Room 1401, 270 Broadway, NY, NY 10007.

 

Other information for town and village judges is available through the Justice Court Resource Center, 98 Niver Street, Cohoes, NY 12047, 1-800-232-0630.

 

Example:

In a CPL article 440 proceeding, the judge should have recused himself, as the law clerk had been an ADA on the case. People v. Roshia, 206 A.D.3d 1057, 169 N.Y.S.3d 400 (3d Dep’t 2022).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:23

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:23. Adult and minor defendants

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

The criminal law, generally, applies to adults. A person under 18 who commits a criminal act usually is charged as a juvenile delinquent in Family Court. The prosecutor in that court is the county attorney. With serious felonies, a youth may be prosecuted in adult criminal court as a Juvenile Offender. See Ch 21, Youthful and Juvenile Offenders.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:24

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:24. Corporation as defendant

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

A corporation and its officers may be criminally liable for illegal acts. Penal Law §§ 20.20, 60.25, 80.10; People v. Concert Connection, Ltd., 211 A.D.2d 310, 629 N.Y.S.2d 254 (2d Dep’t 1995). A corporation must be represented by an attorney in a criminal case. CPL 600.20. Cf. People v. NYTAC Corp., 5 Misc. 3d 304, 783 N.Y.S.2d 775 (Dist. Ct. 2004) (requirement violates equal protection). A court may issue and serve a summons or an appearance ticket to an officer, director, or other agent authorized to accept service. Personal delivery or service upon the Secretary of State is required. CPL 600.10; Bus Corp L § 306(b). People v. Eica Const. Corp., 85 Misc. 2d 1026, 381 N.Y.S.2d 377 (Dist. Ct. 1975); People v. New York Paving, Inc., 155 Misc. 2d 934, 591 N.Y.S.2d 318 (NYC Crim. Ct. 1992).

 

A labor union may be prosecuted as well. People v. Newspaper and Mail Deliverers’ Union of New York and Vicinity, 250 A.D.2d 207, 683 N.Y.S.2d 488 (1st Dep’t 1998).

 

The criminal prosecution of a corporation does not abate upon its dissolution. People v. Pymm Thermometer Corp., 188 A.D.2d 560, 591 N.Y.S.2d 459 (2d Dep’t 1992).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:25

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:25. Crimes are prosecuted in “superior” and “local” courts

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​83

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​86

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​92

 

 

The Criminal Procedure Law distinguishes between “superior courts” (County Court and Supreme Court) and “local criminal courts,” the classification applicable to the New York City Criminal Court, other city courts, the district courts in Nassau and Suffolk counties on Long Island, and town and village courts.

 

Depending upon the location where a crime occurred, a case is generally commenced in New York City Criminal Court, a city or district court, or a town and village court.

 

Under CPL 10.20, the level of the offense charged then determines where it will be tried:

         • Superior courts have exclusive jurisdiction over felonies.

         • Superior courts and local criminal courts have concurrent jurisdiction over misdemeanors.

         • Superior courts try petty offenses only when they are part of an indictment covering crimes.

 

By statute, a superior court may sit as a local court, exercising the local court’s jurisdiction. CPL 10.20(3); People v. Carson, 216 A.D.2d 965, 629 N.Y.S.2d 366 (4th Dep’t 1995). In some situations a superior court is mandated to act as a local court. CPL 180.20(2).

 

A municipality must have geographic jurisdiction to try a case. People v. Osborne, 29 N.Y.2d 250, 327 N.Y.S.2d 65, 277 N.E.2d 185 (1971); UJCA 2001(1). An offense committed within 100 yards of another municipality may be prosecuted in the local court of either jurisdiction. CPL 20.50(2). See § 15:47, Jurisdiction.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:26

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:26. Crimes are prosecuted in “superior” and “local” courts—Justice courts

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​83

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​86

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​92

 

 

Town and village courts are part of the unified court system, N.Y. Const. Art. 6, § 1, but the judges are employees of the municipality. See § 23:13, Procedure. http://www.courts.state.ny.us/courts/townandvillage/.

 

Many justice courts hold evening sessions. Conducting a jury trial after midnight may violate due process, unless the defendant has consented. See People v. Passero, 78 Misc. 2d 548, 357 N.Y.S.2d 677 (County Ct. 1974).

 

Information on court locations can be found at: http://www.courts.state.ny.us/courts/townandvillage/find.shtml

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:27

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:27. Process or orders issued by court

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​215 to 220

 

 

A court may issue various types of process and orders. These include:

         • a summons, issued by a local court, which directs a defendant to appear in court for arraignment on a criminal charge. If the defendant fails to appear in court as directed, the court may issue an arrest warrant. CPL art 130; see § 1:51, Arrest with warrant or summons.

         • an arrest warrant, requiring a defendant to appear in court, and permitting the police to secure the defendant’s attendance, CPL 120.10; see § 1:51, Arrest with warrant or summons.

         • a bench warrant, issued for the arrest of a defendant who has already appeared in court but has failed to return, CPL 1.20(30), 530.70; see Ch 4, Arraignment and Bail.

         • a securing order, setting the terms of release of a defendant from custody. CPL 510.10.

         • suspension of driver’s license, 60 days after failing to answer an appearance ticket, VTL § 510(4-a). A $70 scofflaw lift fee (an administrative fee, nonwaivable) for each ticket may be imposed before the license privileges are restored. VTL § 503(j-1).

         • a body order, requiring someone held in custody to be brought to court. CPLR 2302(b).

         • an order of protection, either temporary or permanent, see § 1:70, Order of protection; § 3:4, Order of protection upon filing of instrument.

         • a mandate of commitment for civil or criminal contempt, Jud Law §§ 750 et seq.; see 23:166 to 23:171 23:152, Criminal vs. civil contempt.

         • a search warrant, permitting the police to search a designated premises, person or vehicle, and to seize certain property, CPL art 690; see §§ 9:97 et seq., Search warrants, generally.

         • a wiretap warrant, permitting the police to eavesdrop in on and make audio or video recordings of conversations, CPL art 700; see § 9:110, Telephone, eavesdropping and video surveillance.

         • an order for a pen register, a device that identifies telephone numbers, CPL art 705; see § 9:112, Pen registers.

         • a subpoena ad testificandum (or simply subpoena), requiring a person to appear in court to testify, see § 8:97, Use of subpoenas.

         • a subpoena duces tecum, requiring a person to appear and bring specified documents or other physical evidence. CPL art 610. With certain exceptions, both types of subpoenas may be issued by a judge, a district attorney, or a defense attorney. CPL 610.20.

         • a material witness order, compelling a person who is unwilling to testify to appear in court, and to be taken into custody, CPL art 620; see § 18:81, Material witness proceeding.

         • an order producing an in-state incarcerated witness, CPL art 630.

         • a conditional witness examination, ordering that a witness be examined under oath and the testimony be preserved for use in later proceedings, CPL art 660; CPL 670.20; see § 18:87, Conditional examination.

         • an examination on commission, allowing a witness who is out of state to be questioned and the testimony preserved. CPL art 680. It should be noted, however, that such testimony is available for use at a trial, but not for a hearing. People v. Moore, 216 A.D.2d 218, 629 N.Y.S.2d 405 (1st Dep’t 1995). Only a defendant may initiate a request for an examination on commission, but once granted, the prosecution may request as well. CPL 680.20(1); CPL 680.30(1).

         • a subpoena, requiring a person to attend and testify at an out-of-state criminal proceeding, CPL 640.10; see § 18:83, Witness testifying out of state.

         • an order of commitment or order of observation, with a defendant who is too mentally ill to proceed to trial, see § 15:64, Determination of court.

         • an order of examination, temporary or final, or an order of observation, to determine whether a defendant is an incapacitated person, CPL 730.10(1), see § 15:61, CPL Article 730 examination.

         • a declaration of delinquency, where a convicted defendant is alleged to have violated the conditions of probation or conditional discharge, CPL 410.30.

         • a search order, allowing the search of a probationer or of real property. CPL 410.50(3).

         • a certificate of disposition, stating how charges were disposed of. See § 1:92, Acquittal or dismissal; civil remedies § 1:105, Certificate of disposition.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:28

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:28. Additional resources

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

In analyzing criminal law, a number of reference works are useful. These include:

         • ABA Standards for Criminal Justice: Prosecution Function and Defense Function, 3d edition (available on Westlaw: ABA-CJS)

         • A Jailhouse Lawyer’s Manual, 12th ed. (Columbia Human Rights Law Review)

         • Barker and Alexander, Evidence in New York State and Federal Courts, 2d ed. (available on Westlaw: NYPRAC-EVID)

         • Bogle, Criminal Procedure in New York, 2d edition

         • Breger, Kennedy, Zuccardy and Elkins, New York Law of Domestic Violence, 4th ed. (available on Westlaw: NYLDV)

         • Brunetti, New York Confessions

         • Carmody-Wait 2nd, Vols 31-36A (available on Westlaw: CW2D)

         • Davidowitz, The Practice of Criminal Law Under the CPLR and Related Civil Procedure Statutes, 6th edition (NYS Bar Association)

         • Davidowitz and Dreher, Foundation Evidence, Questions and Courtroom Protocols, 2d ed. (NYSBA)

         • Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th edition (DSM-5-TR) (available on Westlaw). See § 15:50, Mental health, generally.

         • Donnino, New York Court of Appeals on Criminal Law, 3d edition (available on Westlaw: NYCACL)

         • Farrell, Prince, Richardson on Evidence, 11th edition

         • Federal Defenders of San Diego, Inc., Defending a Federal Criminal Case

         • Gershman, Prosecutorial Misconduct, 2nd ed. (available on Westlaw: PROSMIS)

         • Gerstenzang and Sills, Handling the DWI Case in New York (available on Westlaw: HDWINY)

         • Greenberg, Fahey, Carey and Marcus, New York Criminal Law, 3rd ed. (available on Westlaw: NYPRAC-CRIM)

         • Haig, Commercial Litigation in New York State Courts, 4th ed.

         • Hall, Professional Responsibility in Criminal Defense Practice, 4th edition (available on Westlaw: PRCRIMDEF)

         • Hibel, New York Identification Law

         • Kamins, New York Search and Seizure

         • Karger, The Powers of the New York Court of Appeals, 3d ed. rev.

         • Kessler, New York Criminal and Civil Forfeitures

         • Kurzban, Kurzban’s Immigration Law Sourcebook, 18th ed.

         • Leventhal, Charges to Jury and Requests to Charge in a Criminal Case in New York (available on Westlaw: CTJFM)

         • MacCarthy, MacCarthy on Cross-Examination

         • Magill, New York Vehicle and Traffic Sentences

         • Marks, et al., New York Pretrial Criminal Procedure (available on Westlaw: NYPRAC-PCP)

         • McCormick on Evidence, 7th ed. (available on Westlaw: McMK-EVID)

         • Morris, et al., Village, Town and District Courts in New York (available on Westlaw: TOWNVILLNY)

         • Morris and Schneider, Criminal Law in New York, 4th edition (available on Westlaw: CRIMLAWNY)

         • Murray and Muldoon, Criminal Law Slanguage of New York, 5th edition

         • New York Jurisprudence, Vols 31-35

         • Office of Court Administration, Guide to New York Evidence, https://www.nycourts.gov/JUDGES/evidence/

         • Rose, NY Vehicle and Traffic, 2nd edition (available on Westlaw: NYVEH)

         • Nelson, New York DWI Defense Forms (available on Westlaw: NYDWIFM)

         • Vargas, Representing Immigrant Defendants in New York State, 6th edition.

         • Bench Book for Trial Judges–New York (available on Westlaw: BBTJ).

 

For investigating the background of a witness, one important area of searching is public records (available on Westlaw: PUBRECS-NY). On Westlaw, for psychological information, subdirectory PSYPPL.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

§ 1:29. Internet and Web sources

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:30

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:30. Traffic matters: administrative forum

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​83

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​86

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​92

 

 

Two bureaus at the Department of Motor Vehicles conduct hearings: traffic violations (in larger cities) and safety. In larger cities, a person who is charged only with a traffic infraction has the case heard in a Traffic Violations Bureau, rather than in a court. VTL § 225. The person who hears the case is an administrative law judge, who is an employee of the Department of Motor Vehicles. 15 NYCRR §§ 121-126; generally, see Rose, New York Vehicle and Traffic Law, 2nd edition, ch. 33. (Buffalo and Rochester have their own bureaus for traffic violations, while safety issues are handled by the state).

 

DMV is also where a hearing is held on the issue of revoking a driver’s license for cases in which the defendant, arrested for violating VTL § 1192, allegedly refused to submit to a chemical test. See § 9:68, Chemical test.

 

Where a defendant is charged with both a crime and traffic infractions from the same incident, all charges may be determined in the criminal court. VTL § 225(1).

 

Online, a person may plead, schedule a hearing, or pay a ticket with the Traffic Violations Bureau at http://www.dmv.ny.gov/PleadandPay/default.html.

 

Example:

Conviction of a traffic infraction in TVB did not bar prosecution in criminal court. The administrative adjudication was not a criminal punishment, nor was it barred by CPL 40.20(2). People v. Serrano, 176 A.D.3d 476, 110 N.Y.S.3d 112 (1st Dep’t 2019).

 

Pretrial license suspension, an administrative act, is not reviewable on direct appeal from a conviction of a traffic infraction in district court, but requires an article 78 proceeding. People v. Arteca, 78 Misc. 3d 36, 187 N.Y.S.3d 468 (App. Term 2023).

 

Practice Tip:

When representing a driver who cannot appear in person, the attorney should obtain an affidavit that authorizes representation. For attorneys handling numerous VTL cases, the DMV offers an online management system: TVB Ticket Management for Attorneys. To apply, the attorney must submit an application that is available on the DMV website.

 

In some cities and counties, traffic violations may be prosecuted based upon an automatic camera that takes a photo of a vehicle going through a red light or past a toll booth. Where a vehicle goes through a red light, in violation of a local ordinance or VTL § 1110-a, and is photographed, it becomes the basis for a civil administrative proceeding. State law may authorize a city or county to implement the program. See VTL § 1111-b. The proceeding may be handled by a local agency, such as a parking violations bureau or traffic and parking violations agency (TPVA). See People v. Iverson, 37 N.Y.3d 98, 148 N.Y.S.3d 173, 170 N.E.3d 728 (2021). The registered owner of the vehicle, rather than the driver, is liable, but no points on a driver’s license result. Programs of this type have been found constitutional. People v. Davidowitz, 51 Misc. 3d 59, 31 N.Y.S.3d 387 (App. Term 2016); Krieger v. City of Rochester, 42 Misc. 3d 753, 978 N.Y.S.2d 588 (Sup 2013); Levine v. Traffic and Parking Violation Agency for Nassau County, 29 Misc. 3d 1205(A), 958 N.Y.S.2d 308 (Sup 2010).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:31

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:31. Traffic matters: administrative forum—Hearings on traffic tickets

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​83

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​86

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​92

 

 

At a DMV hearing on a traffic infraction, the People’s burden to establish guilt is by clear and convincing evidence, not proof beyond a reasonable doubt. VTL § 227(1). This reduced burden of proof has been found constitutional. Graf v. Foschio, 102 A.D.2d 891, 477 N.Y.S.2d 190 (2d Dep’t 1984).

 

In addition, a defendant whose case is heard in the Traffic Violations Bureau is not entitled to discovery. Miller v. Schwartz, 72 N.Y.2d 869, 532 N.Y.S.2d 354, 528 N.E.2d 507 (1988). The person is not entitled to a supporting deposition. Sulli v. Appeals Bd. of Administrative Adjudication Bureau, 55 A.D.2d 457, 390 N.Y.S.2d 758 (4th Dep’t 1977). Thus, with the typical traffic ticket, the police officer must be present for the administrative law judge to make a finding against the driver. 15 NYCRR § 124.9. See § 22:94, Points and fines.

 

At a DMV hearing, the defense is entitled to Rosario-type material from testifying witnesses. Fenimore Circle Corp. v. State Liquor Authority, 27 N.Y.2d 716, 314 N.Y.S.2d 180, 262 N.E.2d 415 (1970); People ex rel. Deyver by Weinstein v. Travis, 172 Misc. 2d 83, 657 N.Y.S.2d 306 (Sup 1997), aff’d, 244 A.D.2d 990, 668 N.Y.S.2d 966 (4th Dep’t 1997). See § 8:43, The Rosario rule.

 

Where other charges are pending in a criminal court, a DMV hearing can be an effective place for obtaining information. Counsel should consider seeking information that will be helpful in the criminal case and obtaining a transcript of the hearing. See 8:83 to 8:108 8:120, Use of subpoenas.

 

A subpoena may be issued for an administrative proceeding. CPLR 2302; 15 NYCRR § 127.11(b).

 

The results of a DMV hearing do not have collateral estoppel effect in a criminal case. People v. Kearney, 196 Misc. 2d 335, 764 N.Y.S.2d 542 (County Ct. 2003).

 

Practice Tip:

While the DMV hearing is recorded, defense counsel should consider bringing a court reporter to transcribe the session as well. The proceeding is a public one, and a court reporter or other person is entitled to attend. While this is not the record that would be used on administrative review, it can be used at a criminal trial for impeachment.

 

Unlike criminal courts, typically no plea bargaining occurs with Traffic Violations Bureau cases. Additionally, the DMV hearing officer will not consider “speed not reasonable and prudent” (3 points) as a lesser offense of a speeding charge that carries more points.

 

Challenging traffic tickets is important for several reasons: higher surcharges; increased numbers of points for offenses; Driver Responsibility Assessment that is imposed civilly for six points or more; and the “problem driver” regulations that can result in extended loss of license. See § 22:94, Points and fines.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:32

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:32. Traffic matters: administrative forum—Hearings on traffic tickets—Safety hearings

Correlation Table

In addition to traffic tickets, DMV conducts “safety hearings,” which include a fatality hearing, moving point hearing, and chemical test refusal hearing. The purpose of this hearing is to determine whether a person’s license should be suspended or revoked. Limited discovery is permitted with a safety hearing. See 15 NYCRR § 127.6.

 

The refusal hearing is to be held within 15 days of the license being suspended. VTL § 1194(2)(c). The hearing is typically conducted by telephone. If the driver appears but the officer does not, the temporary suspension is terminated and hearing adjourned. 12 NYCRR § 127.9(c). Regulations set forth the time within which the various types of safety hearings are to be held, and whether postponements are deemed reasonable. 15 NYCRR § 127.2(b), (c).

 

Regulations address requests for adjournments: generally, an adjournment is granted for good cause if received at least seven days before the scheduled date of the hearing and no previous request has been made. 15 NYCRR § 127.7.
