A defendant is not required to testify at a safety hearing, but a negative inference may be drawn from the failure to testify. 15 NYCRR § 127.5(b). Subpoenas may be issued for a safety hearing. 15 NYCRR § 127.11(b).

 

The administrative law judge has authority to dismiss the charge if a police officer fails to attend. 15 NYCRR § 127.7(f)(7). However, hearsay is admissible at a safety hearing and may serve as the basis for the administrative determination. 15 NYCRR § 127.6(b). The determination at a safety hearing must be based on substantial evidence. 15 NYCRR § 127.6(b).

 

See § 1:101 for Form—Letter to client regarding fatality hearing.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:33

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:33. Traffic matters: administrative forum—Hearings on traffic tickets—Refusal hearings

Correlation Table

The issues at a refusal hearing are limited to: did the police officer have probable cause to believe that the person was driving in violation of any subdivision of § 1192; did the police officer make a lawful arrest; was the person given warnings in clear and sufficient language that refusal to submit would result in immediate suspension and thereafter revocation of the driver’s license regardless of whether the person is convicted at trial; and did the person refuse to submit to the chemical test. VTL § 1194(2)(c). Whether the police complied with defendant’s request for an attorney before taking the chemical test is not an issue for an administrative hearing. Clark v. New York State Dept. of Motor Vehicles, 55 A.D.3d 1284, 864 N.Y.S.2d 810 (4th Dep’t 2008).

 

Where the government is not ready for the hearing on the scheduled date, the hearing officer may dismiss the charge or adjourn. VTL § 227(2). At a refusal hearing, the hearing may proceed based on the contents of the “Report of Refusal” form.

 

The two-hour rule for taking a chemical test does not apply to a license revocation hearing held pursuant to VTL § 1194(2)(c). Endara-Caicedo v. New York State Department of Motor Vehicles, 38 N.Y.3d 20, 164 N.Y.S.3d 50, 184 N.E.3d 871 (2022).

 

Counsel should register objections, including constitutional objections, where appropriate. See Parsons v. New York State Department of Motor Vehicles Appeals Board, 224 A.D.3d 1263, 204 N.Y.S.3d 694 (4th Dep’t 2024).

 

Practice Tip:

If the officer fails to appear, a finding may be made against the driver based on the officer’s written report. Gray v. Adduci, 73 N.Y.2d 741, 536 N.Y.S.2d 40, 532 N.E.2d 1268 (1988); see Linton v. State of New York Dept. of Motor Vehicles Appeals Bd., 92 A.D.3d 1205, 937 N.Y.S.2d 905 (4th Dep’t 2012); Monaghan v. Schroeder, 223 A.D.3d 972, 202 N.Y.S.3d 806 (3d Dep’t 2024). 15 NYCRR § 127.9(c). See § 9:68, Chemical test.

 

Where the police officer fails to testify, the defense should consider requesting that a negative inference be drawn from the officer’s absence.

 

The ALJ may also draw an inference from the motorist’s failure to testify at the hearing. Peeso v. Fiala, 130 A.D.3d 1442, 13 N.Y.S.3d 742 (4th Dep’t 2015).

 

Example:

The driver’s single refusal to submit to a chemical test was sufficient for revocation; in an administrative proceeding, it was unnecessary to show that he persisted in his refusal. Hahne v. New York State Dept. of Motor Vehicles, 63 A.D.3d 936, 882 N.Y.S.2d 434 (2d Dep’t 2009). See § 4:36, Suspension and revocation with test refusal.

 

Driver was not adequately warned of consequences of refusing to take chemical test, thus revocation was unwarranted: no warning that his time for considering taking it had expired, and that his further request to consult with counsel would be deemed a refusal. Lamb v. Egan, 150 A.D.3d 854, 54 N.Y.S.3d 100 (2d Dep’t 2017). Cf. Clemens v. New York State Department of Motor Vehicles, 178 A.D.3d 921, 115 N.Y.S.3d 399 (2d Dep’t 2019).

 

Due to an erroneous interpretation by a police officer that the driver committed a traffic infraction, resulting in a stop that was illegal at the outset, that issue may be raised at the hearing. Byer v. Jackson, 241 A.D.2d 943, 661 N.Y.S.2d 336 (4th Dep’t 1997); McDonell v. New York State Dept. of Motor Vehicles, 77 A.D.3d 1379, 908 N.Y.S.2d 507 (4th Dep’t 2010).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:34

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

I. Criminal Practice, Generally

§ 1:34. Traffic matters: administrative forum—Hearings on traffic tickets—Appeal from DMV ruling

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1007

 

 

An appeal from a Traffic Violations Bureau ruling must be filed within 60 days, including the transcript. VTL § 261; 15 NYCRR Part 126.

 

The form for appealing a decision after a refusal hearing can be found at http://www.dmv.ny.gov/forms/aa33a.pdf.

 

The driver must first exhaust administrative remedies. The initial review occurs with the DMV Appeals Board. The next appellate step is an article 78 proceeding. Gazda v. New York State Department of Motor Vehicles, 159 A.D.3d 903, 72 N.Y.S.3d 555 (2d Dep’t 2018). See Kenny v. Commissioner of New York State Dept. of Motor Vehicles, 111 A.D.3d 726, 974 N.Y.S.2d 543 (2d Dep’t 2013) (appeal from safety hearing). See § 23:13, Procedure.

 

The standard of review is whether the determination is supported by “substantial evidence.” Hearsay may form the basis for an administrative determination. Baldwin v. Fiala, 102 A.D.3d 960, 958 N.Y.S.2d 757 (2d Dep’t 2013); Khan v. New York State Department of Motor Vehicles, 215 A.D.3d 844, 187 N.Y.S.3d 749 (2d Dep’t 2023).

 

A written motion to vacate a conviction from the traffic violations bureau, supported by documentary evidence, must be made within six months to the senior administrative law judge in the area. 15 NYCRR § 125.6.

 

Example:

There was substantial evidence for revoking the license because of refusal. The officer had reasonable grounds to believe there was a drinking-driver violation, probable cause to arrest, sufficient warnings were given, and there was a refusal three times to submit to the test. Rosulo v. State Dept. of Motor Vehicles, 153 A.D.3d 1346, 60 N.Y.S.3d 494 (2d Dep’t 2017); Crowder v. Fiala, 175 A.D.3d 1408, 109 N.Y.S.3d 333 (2d Dep’t 2019).

 

DMV determination had a rational basis. Gorecki v. New York State Department of Motor Vehicles, 201 A.D.3d 802, 162 N.Y.S.3d 85 (2d Dep’t 2022) (relicensure).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:35

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:35. A similar path for most cases

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

Low-level offenses often are resolved early in the process, even at a first court appearance. More serious charges may require extensive court appearances, motions, a jury trial, and appellate review, all of which can take months or years.

 

However, allowing for certain proceedings applicable to felonies only, criminal cases generally follow a similar procedural path, especially if the accused chooses to fight until all avenues are exhausted.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:36

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:36. The accusation

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

A criminal case has its genesis in an allegation of criminal conduct. The nature of that alleged conduct has a number of consequences.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:37

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:37. Levels of offenses

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​200

 

 

The Penal Law and related statutes differentiate criminal offenses according to the level of the potential punishment.

 

There are three main types of offenses: felonies, misdemeanors, and petty offenses. Within these are degrees of seriousness.

 

The term “crime” refers only to felonies and misdemeanors; the offenses that can result in imprisonment of a first offender for more than 15 days, up to one year. Penal Law § 10.00(4).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:38

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:38. Levels of offenses—Felonies

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​27

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​200

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​1234

 

 

In New York, felonies range from the most serious, class A-I (e.g., Murder 1st degree, Criminal Sale of a Controlled Substance 1st degree) to class E (e.g., Grand Larceny 4th degree).

 

If convicted of a felony, a defendant may receive punishment that includes state imprisonment—“upstate time.” See §§ 22:11 to 22:18, State prison.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:39

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:39. Levels of offenses—Violent vs. nonviolent felonies

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​27

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​200

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​1234

 

 

In addition to the A through E gradation of felony offenses, the Penal Law distinguishes between violent and nonviolent felonies. “Violent felony offense” is a term of art defined by Penal Law § 70.02(1), and not all felonies that involve violence are violent felony offenses under the statute. Murder, for example, is not classified as a “violent felony offense.” However, certain felonies where violence is not necessarily present are so classified, such as 2nd degree burglary.

 

With a violent felony offense, a “determinate” sentence of imprisonment (e.g., six years) along with post-release supervision is imposed, rather than an “indeterminate” sentence, which may be imposed for a nonviolent felony (e.g., two to six years). See § 22:12, State sentence is either determinate or indeterminate.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:40

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:40. Levels of offenses—Misdemeanors

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​27

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​200

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​1233

 

 

In New York, a misdemeanor is a crime: class A misdemeanors are more serious (e.g., Petit Larceny, Assault 3rd degree); class B misdemeanors are less serious (e.g., Menacing 3rd degree, Attempted Petit Larceny). Penal Law § 10.00(4).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:41

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:41. Levels of offenses—Misdemeanors—Unclassified

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​27

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​200

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​1233

 

 

New York crimes that are defined by chapters outside the Penal Law are usually not differentiated as class A, B, etc. They are referred to instead as “unclassified” misdemeanors or felonies. With these, the punishment imposed upon conviction may be provided for by the particular statute. If not, the Penal Law fills the gap—an unclassified felony is punishable as a class E felony, and an unclassified misdemeanor is punishable as a class A misdemeanor. Penal Law § 55.10(1)(b), (2)(b).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:42

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:42. Levels of offenses—Petty offenses

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​28

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​200

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​1233

 

 

Under Penal Law § 10.00, violations and traffic infractions, the least serious categories in New York, are not crimes but rather petty offenses. CPL 1.20(39). Conviction of either is not considered a criminal conviction. Possible punishment includes incarceration, fine, restitution, and community service, but not probation. See § 22:6, Incarceration; § 22:45, Probation; § 22:36, Community service; § 22:69, Restitution to crime victim; § 22:91, Fines.

 

Where the defendant is charged with a petty offense alone, there is no right to a jury trial. But where both a crime and a violation are charged, and the defendant is entitled to a jury trial, all of the charges are to be determined by the jury. See § 19:62, Right to jury trial; exceptions.

 

When a defendant is convicted of a noncriminal offense, the conviction is normally “sealed.” That is, photographs, fingerprints, and records relating to the incident are sealed and unavailable to law enforcement authorities and to the public. CPL 160.55. See § 1:97, Sealing of dismissed cases and violation-level offenses.

 

The district attorney, upon five days’ notice to the defendant, may request that the sealing of records be dispensed with in the interests of justice. CPL 160.50. In many courts, though, this notice is waived by the defense where a plea is worked out. See § 17:10, Plea to a lesser offense discretionary; § 22:37, Sealing of violation-level records.

 

A violation (e.g., disorderly conduct) is an offense in which the maximum punishment is no more than 15 days in a local jail.

 

Similarly, a traffic infraction (e.g., speeding) cannot be punished by more than 15 days in jail. A traffic infraction has similar punishment to a violation, but is not a violation. Penal Law § 55.10(4).

 

When the traffic charge is heard at a traffic violations bureau rather than a court, no imprisonment may result. VTL § 227(4)(a); see § 1:30, Traffic matters: administrative forum.

 

Practice Tip:

Regardless of the level, a defendant charged with an offense may bring motions in court, such as a motion to dismiss or a suppression motion. Discovery is limited with traffic infractions, however, whether brought in court or the Traffic Violations Bureau.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:43

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:43. Levels of offenses—Parking violations and municipal ordinances

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​28

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​200

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​1233

 

 

A parking violation is not a criminal offense, but the CPL has been held applicable to such cases. No supporting deposition is required. People v. Wienclaw, 183 Misc. 2d 727, 704 N.Y.S.2d 445 (J. Ct. 2000). In many municipalities, parking violations are handled in an administrative forum, such as a parking violations bureau.

 

Violations of municipal ordinances may also be prosecuted in criminal court. See § 1:14, Municipal attorneys.

 

Violation of an ordinance can be the basis of a stop for Fourth Amendment purposes, or of an arrest. See People v. Taylor, 294 A.D.2d 825, 741 N.Y.S.2d 822 (4th Dep’t 2002). See § 9:11, Search and seizure, generally.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:44

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:44. Defenses

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​31 to 43.5

 

 

A person accused of a crime may have legal arguments available to oppose the finding of guilt. New York State, by both statute and common law, provides a variety of defenses that may be available concerning a particular crime. These include self-defense and other defenses, such as alibi and entrapment. See Ch 15, Defenses.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:45

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:45. Defenses—Notice to prosecution of defenses

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1909

 

 

With certain defenses, the defendant must give the prosecutor written notice in advance of trial. These include alibi as well as the mental disease or defect defense. See § 8:74, CPL Article 250: defense notices to prosecution.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:46

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:46. Police involvement and investigation

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​55 to 57

 

 

The police do not necessarily become involved as the result of a crime, because the alleged victim (complainant) may file an accusation with the court directly.

 

If the victim contacts the police, however, the police may then perform an investigation, which includes interviewing eyewitnesses and victims, securing evidence, and attempting to question the person who is suspected of the crime.

 

If the police themselves witness or interrupt the incident, of course, the defendant may be arrested on the spot, with any investigation and questioning of the suspect done afterward.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:47

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:47. Police involvement and investigation—Questioning by police

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​55 to 57

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

The police may or may not advise the defendant of rights before questioning, which frequently occurs before any arrest takes place.

 

The failure to advise the defendant of Miranda warnings may affect the use in court of any statement that is made, but the absence of these warnings does not affect the validity of the arrest. See §§ 9:131 et seq., Miranda warnings required when defendant in “custody.”

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:48

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:48. Police involvement and investigation—Apprehension of the suspect

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​55 to 57

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​215.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

A criminal suspect can be arrested with or without a warrant or a summons, depending upon the facts of the case.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:49

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:49. Police involvement and investigation—Apprehension of the suspect—Arrest without a warrant

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​55 to 57

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​215.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

Whether a police officer may make an arrest without a warrant depends in part on the level of offense that has occurred.

 

If the offense is a crime (a felony or misdemeanor), a warrantless arrest may be made regardless of whether the offense occurred in the officer’s presence. Of course, that does not necessarily mean that a legal basis exists for that arrest. See Ch 9, Suppression.

 

With a petty offense, the officer can make a warrantless arrest only if it is committed in the officer’s presence. CPL 140.10; see § 9:32, Arrest for petty offense requires officer’s presence; § 9:51, Stop and arrest outside of officer’s geographical area.

 

A “citizen’s arrest” is permissible. CPL 140.30; Penal Law § 35.30(4) (private citizen using force to effect an arrest). Where such an arrest occurs (such as with a security guard arresting a shoplifter), the person arrested must be taken into police custody without unnecessary delay. CPL 140.40(1); 31 NY Jur 2d, Criminal Law: Procedure §§ 121, 153. See also Gen Bus L § 218 (defense in civil suit that person stopped for shoplifting was stopped in a reasonable manner and for a reasonable time).

 

A citizen’s arrest may be effectuated only by a person acting other than as a police or peace officer. A peace officer may not, under color of law, effectuate an arrest outside the geographical area of employment. People v. Williams, 4 N.Y.3d 535, 797 N.Y.S.2d 35, 829 N.E.2d 1203 (2005); People v. Page, 35 N.Y.3d 199, 126 N.Y.S.3d 67, 149 N.E.3d 905 (2020). See § 9:51, Stop and arrest outside of officer’s geographical area.

 

Practice Tip:

At the time of arrest, where a defendant has a pistol permit, County Court may send a letter suspending the permit and requiring that firearms be surrendered. A person who owns pistols and anticipates being arrested may be well advised to transfer those firearms to another person with a pistol permit. See § 22:207, Pistol permit.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:50

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:50. Police involvement and investigation—Apprehension of the suspect—Arrest without a warrant—Mandatory arrest in domestic violence cases

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​55 to 57

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​215.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

Police are required to make an arrest when they have reasonable cause to believe an offense against a family member or violation of a “stay-away” order of protection has been committed. Where more than one family member has engaged in an altercation, the officer may arrest the primary physical aggressor. CPL 140.10(4); see 22:73 to 22:80 22:68, Orders of protection; see Breger, Kennedy, Zuccardy and Elkins, New York Law of Domestic Violence, 3rd ed., § 1:4.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:51

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:51. Police involvement and investigation—Apprehension of the suspect—Arrest with warrant or summons

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​55 to 57

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​215.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

If a warrantless arrest is not made, the police can apply for an arrest warrant, either on papers or orally, depending upon the situation. A local criminal court judge may sign the arrest warrant or a summons, directing that the defendant be brought to the court.

 

A summons may be issued by a court where it is anticipated that the defendant will voluntarily appear in court for arraignment. CPL Art. 130. See § 4:13, Summons.

 

When executing an arrest warrant, police must give notice of their purpose. CPL 120.80(4). Failure to do so may result in suppression of tangible evidence seized. People v. Jones, 214 A.D.3d 483, 184 N.Y.S.3d 350 (1st Dep’t 2023).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:52

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:52. Police involvement and investigation—Processing defendant: fingerprints and photographs

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​55 to 57

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​215.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

Upon an arrest, the police will process the defendant. Fingerprints must be taken for all felony and most misdemeanor charges, and may be taken where the arresting officer is unable to ascertain the defendant’s identity, suspects that the identification given is inaccurate, or suspects that the defendant is being sought for some other offense. CPL 160.10(1), 160.10(2). Thus, traffic infractions and most violations do not require fingerprinting.

 

The defendant’s photograph might be used at trial to establish how the defendant looked around the time the crime occurred. See § 18:111, Use of arrest photographs of defendant.

 

Where the charge is dismissed, or dismissed after an adjournment in contemplation of dismissal (ACD), photographs and fingerprints are to be returned to the defendant or defendant’s attorney. CPL 160.50(1). Court and police records are to be sealed. CPL 160.50(1)(c); see § 1:97, Sealing of criminal records; § 22:37, Sealing of violation-level records.

 

Where the defendant is given an appearance ticket, the defendant may be directed to appear before the police for fingerprinting. CPL 150.70.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:53

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:53. Police involvement and investigation—Postarrest release or confinement

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​55 to 57

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​215.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

Upon making the arrest, the desk officer at the police station where the individual is taken after arrest may set bail (so-called “stationhouse bail”) or, with low-level offenses, the defendant may be released upon an “appearance ticket.” An appearance ticket requires the defendant to appear in court on a specified date and time. CPL 150.10, CPL 150.30. See § 4:41, Prearraignment bail.

 

When serious charges are involved, the decision of bail will be left to the arraignment judge, and thus the defendant will be held in custody until arraignment. See Ch 4, Arraignment and Bail.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:54

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:54. Filing of accusatory instrument—Defendant’s presence

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​35 to 37

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​43

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​47

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​54

 

 

Before a defendant can be charged and a criminal action commenced, a written accusation must be filed in the local criminal court. This is the accusatory instrument that, at the beginning of a case, may be a traffic ticket, a misdemeanor information, complaint, or felony complaint.

 

The accusatory instrument states which section of the law the defendant is accused of violating, and gives details of how the offense is alleged to have occurred. If all elements of the crime are not adequately alleged, the instrument is defective and may be subject to dismissal. See Ch 3, Accusatory Instruments.

 

Upon the filing of an accusatory instrument the defendant may not thereafter be questioned by police in the absence of an attorney. See § 9:154, No questioning in absence of counsel after case commenced. Additionally, speedy trial time begins to accrue. See § 13:27, “Commencement” of action.

 

In civil cases, the parties and/or counsel usually attend court only when a motion has been made, for a pretrial conference, or when the trial date has been set. In criminal cases, by contrast, regular adjourned dates are set for the two sides to address various matters, such as discovery, plea bargaining discussions, and the like. Because the adjourned date will be scheduled during the current court appearance, a portable personal calendar is essential.

 

The court will require the defendant’s appearance on each date unless specifically excused. (In contrast, the complainant is not required to appear in court unless subpoenaed to testify, i.e., usually only for trial). See § 1:66, Role of the complainant.

 

A defense motion in a criminal case will be made returnable on the next scheduled adjourned date, unless that does not provide sufficient notice to the prosecution.

 

The reason for the adjournment, and whether the defense consented to it, may later become important in calculating statutory speedy trial periods. See Ch 13, Time Limits.

 

Practice Tip:

The defendant should be present on all required occasions, or a bench warrant may result.

 

Having a bench warrant issued may affect the defendant’s eligibility for release even after the current case is disposed of; should a new charge be filed at some later point, this history will likely mean that a judge will not consider release in lieu of bail.

 

Where the defendant is unable to make a particular court appearance, defense counsel should obtain the court’s consent beforehand to the defendant being absent at that court appearance. While a judge may excuse a defendant’s appearance on routine court dates, the defendant’s presence is required for hearings and trial. See §§ 19:11 et seq., Defendant’s right to be present.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:55

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:55. Filing of accusatory instrument—Multiple charges against one defendant

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​35 to 37

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​43

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​47

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​54

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​261(1)

 

 

A defendant can be charged with more than one crime as the result of an incident. In a purse snatching, for example, the defendant is typically charged with 3rd degree robbery (forcibly stealing property) as well as grand larceny (taking property from the person of another). The charges are prosecuted together.

 

The charges arising out of the same criminal transaction are almost always dealt with together by the judge and attorneys who handle the case. Whether there is a guilty plea or the case goes to trial, all of the charges will be considered together. See § 14:6, One criminal transaction involved. If the defendant is allowed to plead guilty to one of the charges, that may cause jeopardy to attach, barring prosecution of the other charges. § 15:99, Double jeopardy; § 17:76, Early guilty plea as double jeopardy.

 

Even though the offenses are charged and processed together, problems may arise with one of them that results in its dismissal at or before trial. This does not affect the validity of the remaining charges.

 

Example:

A defendant is charged with 2nd degree assault and 3rd degree menacing, both arising out of the same criminal incident. The defense makes a written motion to dismiss the assault charge on the ground that the indictment fails to allege an essential element. If the assault charge is dismissed, the menacing charge will still remain.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:56

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:56. Filing of accusatory instrument—Multiple defendants charged with a crime

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​35 to 37

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​43

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​47

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​54

 

 

When more than one person participates in a crime, the cases against the defendants may be prosecuted together, or may be severed.

 

Each person involved may be legally responsible, but the extent of involvement may differ. For example, a person who participates in a crime may be found guilty as a “principal,” or may have liability imposed under Penal Law § 20.00 as an accomplice. In either situation the level of punishment is the same. See Ch 14, Codefendants and Accomplices.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:57

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:57. Initial court appearance—Arraignment

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​261 to 266

 

 

When a defendant has been held in custody, the initial local court appearance, an arraignment, will typically occur within 24 hours of arrest. See Ch 4, Arraignment and Bail.

 

When the defendant has been released without bail being set (e.g., on a traffic ticket in a justice court), the first court date may be set further off. For a defendant who was released on “stationhouse bail,” the time of the arraignment can vary widely by locale.

 

On a minor charge, one arraignment will occur, but with a felony charge, typically at least two arraignments take place: an arraignment in local court on the felony complaint, and, upon indictment, arraignment on the indictment in county court or supreme court. (The indictment, which is issued by the grand jury, replaces the felony complaint.) See § 1:75, Superior court arraignment on indictment. A defendant will enter a plea to each charging instrument filed in a case.

 

There may be additional accusatory instruments: where a prior conviction is an element of the crime, a “special information” is filed, to which the defendant admits or denies. See § 3:24, Special information. At sentencing, if the defendant has a prior felony conviction that “enhances” the range of sentence, a “second felony offender information” or other instrument is filed, to which the defendant may either admit or deny. See § 22:128, Prosecutor to file presentencing statement.

 

Arraignment is considered a critical stage, where the right to counsel attaches. See § 2:3, Counsel required at “critical stages.”

 

At the arraignment, the judge will advise the defendant of the rights that a defendant has in court, including the right to counsel. If the level of offense is such that the defendant is entitled to counsel and the defendant is indigent, an attorney will be assigned or appointed. Often eligibility is determined after arraignment. In large cities with busy arraignment parts, defendants who are represented are assumed to have conferred with their attorneys about the charges and their rights, and thus are asked “to waive the reading of rights and charges.” See Ch 4, Arraignment and Bail; Ch 2, Role of Defense Counsel.

 

An attorney should be present when a defendant is arraigned, as it is a critical stage of a criminal proceeding. See § 2:3, Counsel required at “critical stages”; § 4:19, Right to counsel. When the Public Defender or Legal Aid attorney is to be assigned, the attorney may be present in the court during arraignment and may begin representation immediately. The case may also be adjourned so that the attorney can review the file.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:58

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:58. Initial court appearance—Plea entered

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​261 to 266

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​268

 

 

At arraignment, a defendant must enter a plea, which may be either guilty or not guilty. For an unrepresented defendant charged with a petty offense (a violation or traffic infraction), the judge may allow the defendant to plead guilty on the spot, and then impose sentence.

 

With more serious offenses, the judge typically enters a not-guilty plea and advises the defendant to obtain the services of an attorney. Indeed, from the defendant’s standpoint, a not-guilty plea is almost always the best choice at this stage of the proceedings to keep options open. See Ch 4, Arraignment and Bail.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:59

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:59. Initial court appearance—Bail application may be made

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Bail​39

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Bail​42

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​261 to 266

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​268

 

 

At arraignment a defendant typically applies for release on bail. See Ch 4, Arraignment and Bail.

 

When an attorney first appears after arraignment, a request may be made to the court to review the bail status. See § 4:67, Request for change of bail.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:60

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:60. Initial court appearance—Notice may be served by prosecution

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​261(1)

 

 

Also at arraignment, the prosecutor may serve on the defendant or defense counsel a written notice pursuant to CPL 710.30. This notice informs the defense that, at trial, the prosecution intends to introduce evidence of an oral or written statement made by the defendant, a previous identification of the defendant, or both.

 

The purpose of CPL 710.30 is to set forth a procedure to provide notice to a defendant who might otherwise be unaware that the prosecution possesses such evidence, and to allow the defendant to test its admissibility or reliability before trial. See People v. Pacquette, 25 N.Y.3d 575, 14 N.Y.S.3d 775, 35 N.E.3d 845 (2015).

 

If not served at arraignment, the CPL 710.30 notice may be served on the defense within 15 days of arraignment. See Ch 8, Disclosure; Ch 9, Suppression.

 

If the CPL 710.30 notice is not timely served, the prosecution may be barred at trial from introducing identification evidence or evidence of a defendant’s statement. See §§ 8:60 et seq., CPL Article 710: statements and identifications; §§ 9:186 et seq., Required prosecution notice where statement to be used; §§ 9:241 et seq., Prosecution notice to defendant usually required.

 

Additionally, the prosecution may serve a “grand jury notice” under CPL 190.50. See Ch 6, Grand Jury Proceedings.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:61

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:61. Initial court appearance—Adjournment after arraignment

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​261(1)

 

 

If the case is not disposed of at arraignment, the judge will adjourn it for a variety of reasons: for appearance of an attorney, for “disposition” (such as a plea or other resolution), for discovery, for a pretrial conference or, in the case of a felony defendant who will remain incarcerated, for a preliminary hearing. See Ch 5, The Preliminary Hearing. The case may be adjourned one day or several days for the next court appearance. A defendant will typically be required to attend each court appearance, unless the judge gives specific permission to not attend. See People v. Dhanraj, 40 Misc. 3d 250, 964 N.Y.S.2d 898 (NYC Crim. Ct. 2013). If the defendant fails to appear again in court, a “bench warrant” may be issued. But the complainant and witnesses are not required to attend unless their testimony is needed at a hearing or trial.

 

Where a case has been resolved but one final step is needed, such as confirmation that a person has completed counseling or community service, the court may set another court appearance as a “control date.” If compliance occurs, and documentation is provided to the court beforehand, the court excuses appearances on that date.

 

A bench warrant may be issued only in a criminal proceeding. CPL 1.20(3); Oliver C. v. Weissman, 203 A.D.2d 458, 611 N.Y.S.2d 12 (2d Dep’t 1994).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:62

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:62. Investigation by the People

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

The People’s investigation is usually conducted by the police department of the locality, sheriff’s department, or state police. Police will almost always be on the scene of a criminal offense before the defense.

 

The written reports of an officer who later testifies at trial for the prosecution are to be turned over to the defense, before the officer testifies, as Rosario material. See Ch 8, Disclosure.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:63

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:63. Return of stolen property

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1221

 

 

Where property is seized during an arrest, the parties may seek early return of the property to its owner, particularly where the evidence is a motor vehicle. Penal Law art 450. With a larceny-related charge, the prosecution may serve notice for the defense to inspect, otherwise the property will be returned to the owner before trial. See § 8:87, Penal Law Article 450: inspection of stolen property.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:64

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:64. Property held by police: evidence, retained or forfeited

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1221

 

 

The prosecution may seek to retain property belonging to the defendant or another to use as evidence, or to possibly forfeit. A defendant is not entitled to appointed counsel in a forfeiture proceeding. Morgenthau v. Rodriguez, 261 A.D.2d 165, 690 N.Y.S.2d 201 (1st Dep’t 1999).

 

Forfeiture proceedings may be brought under federal law, state law, or the NYC administrative code. The forfeiture may be civil, CPLR art. 13–A, or criminal, Penal Law art. 410 (pornography), art. 415 (gambling records), or art. 480 (felony controlled substances). As a civil proceeding, the burden is a preponderance of the evidence, and the outcome of any criminal charge is irrelevant to the outcome of the forfeiture proceeding. Property Clerk of New York City Police Dept. v. Ferris, 77 N.Y.2d 428, 568 N.Y.S.2d 577, 570 N.E.2d 225 (1991). Forfeiture issues are usually addressed separate from the criminal proceeding. Cf. People v. Burgos, 129 A.D.3d 627, 13 N.Y.S.3d 350 (1st Dep’t 2015) (forfeiture stipulation is not part of a sentence, but can be part of a judgment of conviction). See § 22:91, Forfeiture.

 

Federal forfeiture proceedings may also be brought in the absence of a criminal proceeding. 28 U.S.C.A. § 888. The proceeding may be venued in federal district court or in an administrative context. The person whose property is seized may obtain the property upon posting of bond.

 

The constitutionality of New York City’s forfeiture provision has been upheld. Grinberg v. Safir, 266 A.D.2d 43, 698 N.Y.S.2d 218 (1st Dep’t 1999).

 

For the most part New York State forfeiture provisions (limited to felony offenses) are less frequently used. The forfeiture action may be commenced during the pendency of the criminal action, but is stayed until a conviction occurs. CPLR 1311(1)(a). See Morgenthau v. Basbus, 68 A.D.3d 442, 890 N.Y.S.2d 43 (1st Dep’t 2009). In a state court proceeding, the prosecutor is required by a preponderance of the evidence to establish that calculation of monetary proceeds was reasonably accurate. Hynes v. Dallas, 83 A.D.3d 896, 922 N.Y.S.2d 137 (2d Dep’t 2011). See Clark v. Richardson, 163 A.D.3d 448, 80 N.Y.S.3d 260 (1st Dep’t 2018) (misdemeanor conviction, but People established that money was the subject of a Penal Law article 220 felony).

 

Property seized pursuant to a search warrant remains in the custody of the court so long as a criminal investigation is ongoing. Marra v. Hynes, 221 A.D.2d 539, 635 N.Y.S.2d 482 (2d Dep’t 1995); Matter of Documents Seized Pursuant to a Search Warrant, 124 Misc. 2d 897, 478 N.Y.S.2d 490 (Sup 1984). Due process requires that the government not retain property under color of a search warrant beyond the exhaustion of any law enforcement purpose adequate to justify it being withheld. People v. DeProspero, 20 N.Y.3d 527, 964 N.Y.S.2d 487, 987 N.E.2d 264 (2013) (dictum).

 

Although the government may seize and hold property for various reasons in connection with a criminal or related proceeding, once those proceedings have ended, or the property is unrelated to or unneeded for those proceedings, due process requires that the property be returned. It may be necessary for the defendant (or other claimant) to file a written demand for the return of non-contraband property. See DeBellis v. Property Clerk of City of New York, 79 N.Y.2d 49, 580 N.Y.S.2d 157, 588 N.E.2d 55 (1992). If suppression is granted, the judge may order the return of the property if it is not subject to lawful retention. CPL 710.70(1). See Kamins, New York Search and Seizure, § 4.02(7)(h).

 

Where property is seized pursuant to a search warrant, and criminal charges are later dismissed, the property owner may have to resort to a CPLR Article 78 proceeding to obtain its release. See People v. Sash, 194 Misc. 2d 195, 753 N.Y.S.2d 295 (NYC Crim. Ct. 2002). See also Marshall v. Soares, 94 A.D.3d 1258, 941 N.Y.S.2d 894 (3d Dep’t 2012); Engel v. Engel, 24 A.D.3d 548, 807 N.Y.S.2d 383 (2d Dep’t 2005).

 

The property owner may seek return of the property, while the prosecutor and police may seek its disposal or destruction. See Correnti v. Suffolk County Dist. Atty., 88 A.D.3d 633, 930 N.Y.S.2d 624 (2d Dep’t 2011). The owner is not entitled to the return of contraband. Khoshneviss v. Property Clerk of New York City Police Dept., 123 A.D.3d 929, 1 N.Y.S.3d 122 (2d Dep’t 2014).

 

Seized firearms are to be automatically destroyed at least once each year. Penal Law § 400.05(2); see Reeves v. Giannotta, 130 A.D.3d 1444, 12 N.Y.S.3d 736 (4th Dep’t 2015).

 

Return of firearms was required upon termination of an order of protection that was issued in a criminal proceeding, when there was no legal impediment to the owner possessing the surrendered firearms. Delgado v. Sinagra, 72 Misc. 3d 233, 146 N.Y.S.3d 759 (County Ct. 2021).

 

Example:

After a defendant was arrested, his pistol permit was revoked, but other weapons, for which no permit was required, had also been seized. In a CPLR Article 78 proceeding to compel the return of firearms to the arrestee, the petitioner was entitled to a hearing. Caso v. Nassau County Police Dept., 306 A.D.2d 473, 761 N.Y.S.2d 303 (2d Dep’t 2003). See also Blauman v. Blauman, 2 A.D.3d 727, 769 N.Y.S.2d 584 (2d Dep’t 2003).

 

Defendant pleaded guilty to a drug felony. The prosecutor proposed a five-year prison sentence if defendant agreed to forfeit $5,000; if not, the sentence would be ten years. Defendant signed a waiver of bail money that a relative had posted, now made payable to the local police department, and received the lower sentence. The Appellate Division noted that neither civil nor criminal forfeiture statutes had been followed. The waiver was held involuntary, the People having “with the court’s imprimatur essentially threatened to double the sentence if he failed to do so.” The appearance of impropriety was that funds were extorted and that defendant was allowed to “buy” a more lenient sentence by donating money to the local police department. People v. McCoy, 96 A.D.3d 1674, 947 N.Y.S.2d 740 (4th Dep’t 2012). See also, People v. Carmichael, 123 A.D.3d 1053, 999 N.Y.S.2d 476 (2d Dep’t 2014).

 

Practice Tip:

It may be worthwhile for the defense to make a written request for the return of property, such as a firearm within one year, or the timely return of electronic devices. See § 9:104, Search warrants, generally; § 22:207, Pistol permit. Not all courts are authorized to order the property’s return. It may be necessary to bring an application in State Supreme Court.

 

Practice Tip:

In some locations, after a case ends, the defendant or defense counsel may be able to obtain property via a letter or form for release of property, signed by the assistant DA, along with a copy of the property clerk voucher, and provided to the property clerk’s office with proof of identification. With items such as automobiles, the defendant may be required to pay for towing and storage.

 

Practice Tip:

Where police hold a vehicle, the defense should request release of the license plates, so that these can be turned in, and the insurance cancelled.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:65

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:65. Property held by police: evidence, retained or forfeited—Seizure and return of automobiles

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1221

 

 

With seizure of a vehicle, the person is entitled to a prompt postseizure, prejudgment hearing before a neutral person to determine whether the agency is likely to succeed on the merits, and whether continued impoundment is required to ensure its availability as evidence or for a judgment of forfeiture. At the hearing, the agency must establish, by a preponderance, reasonable suspicion for making the initial stop. Krimstock v. Kelly, 306 F.3d 40 (2d Cir. 2002); Property Clerk of Police Dept. of City of New York v. Burnett, 22 A.D.3d 201, 801 N.Y.S.2d 592 (1st Dep’t 2005). Where the prosecutor establishes substantial likelihood of conviction, a preliminary injunction and order of attachment may be granted. Morgenthau v. Khalil, 73 A.D.3d 509, 902 N.Y.S.2d 501 (1st Dep’t 2010). See nycitylaw@nyls.edu.

 

With AUO 1st charges, the police may seize the vehicle that was driven. VTL §§ 511-c(2), 511(3)(a).

 

With a seized vehicle, the owner may be required to pay for the costs of towing and storage. VTL § 511-c(5)(iii).

 

The administrative law judge at a Krimstock hearing is to consider three issues: whether probable cause existed for the arrest of the operator; whether it is likely that the municipality will prevail in a forfeiture action; and whether it is necessary that the vehicle remain impounded to ensure its availability for a forfeiture judgment. Price v. Property Clerk of New York City Police Dept., 74 A.D.3d 1078, 903 N.Y.S.2d 142 (2d Dep’t 2010).

 

Practice Tip:

To obtain release of a vehicle, it may be necessary to obtain the consent of the DA or police officer. When obtaining the vehicle, the owner should bring proof of identification, as well as insurance and registration. A damaged or uninsured vehicle may be required to be towed away, rather than driven.

 

If forfeiture proceedings are brought, the vehicle may be retrieved, but a bond must be posted to obtain it.

 

An adversarial hearing is not required to review the prosecutor’s decision to retain the vehicle as potential evidence. A prosecutor may make an ex parte showing to the judge for a retention order. The same analysis is not applicable to other possible evidence. Krimstock v. Kelly, 464 F.3d 246 (2d Cir. 2006).

 

Nassau County has authority to bring forfeiture proceedings. County of Nassau v. Kilcommons, 45 A.D.3d 522, 845 N.Y.S.2d 127 (2d Dep’t 2007). See also County of Nassau v. Rojas, 49 A.D.3d 487, 856 N.Y.S.2d 124 (2d Dep’t 2008) (forfeiture is dependent on guilty conviction, not on physical seizure of vehicle).

 

An owner is entitled to notice that property is subject to forfeiture. See County of Nassau v. Bassen, 14 Misc. 3d 633, 827 N.Y.S.2d 638 (Sup 2006). Others with a possessory interest in the property may have rights to seek recovery of a chattel. County of Nassau v. Canestro, 41 A.D.3d 760, 838 N.Y.S.2d 784 (2d Dep’t 2007); see also Ford Motor Credit Co. v. NYC Police Dept., 503 F.3d 186 (2d Cir. 2007) (lienholder). Once the government has established a prima facie case for impoundment, the burden shifts to a purported innocent coowner. It is important for the person to demonstrate that critical access to life necessities would be impaired. Property Clerk of Police Dept. of City of New York v. Harris, 9 N.Y.3d 237, 848 N.Y.S.2d 588, 878 N.E.2d 1004 (2007).

 

The police property clerk should return property seized upon arrest to the rightful owner upon timely demand, or bring a forfeiture or other proceeding. See Warren v. City of Poughkeepsie, 66 Misc. 3d 538, 115 N.Y.S.3d 619 (City Ct. 2019).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:66

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:66. Role of the complainant

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

When a criminal charge has been filed, the victim/complainant is not required to attend court appearances unless called to testify. This may be at a preliminary hearing, grand jury proceeding, various suppression hearings, and trial. Normally a complainant is not called as a witness at a pretrial hearing by the defense. See § 7:30, Importance of calling witnesses at hearing.

 

The parties to a criminal action are the People of the State of New York and one or more defendants. A complainant or witness may not formally “appear” by counsel. People v. Robinson, 27 Misc. 3d 635, 898 N.Y.S.2d 438 (Sup 2010).

 

Dismissal or withdrawal of the charge may have civil consequences. See § 1:16, Private prosecution (cross complaint).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:67

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:67. Role of the complainant—Questioning by defense

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

A complainant in a criminal case may be contacted by the defense attorney or defense investigator and questioned about the incident. The defense attorney may do so without the prosecution’s permission. New York State Bar Association Ethics Opinion 72-245; New York County Lawyers’ Association Ethics Opinion 711, 1996 WL 592651; ABA Standards for Criminal Justice, Prosecution Function and Defense Function, 4th ed., § 3-3.1(d). A temporary order of protection may properly direct the defendant to have no contact with the complainant; defense counsel may still seek access to witnesses as part of the obligation to investigate. See People v. O’Connor, 242 A.D.2d 908, 662 N.Y.S.2d 951 (4th Dep’t 1997). However, the complainant also may decline to be interviewed. Witnesses have a constitutional right to refuse to talk to defense counsel. People v. Marino, 87 Misc. 2d 542, 385 N.Y.S.2d 918 (County Ct. 1976). See § 2:4, Representing a witness.

 

Witnesses are not the property of either prosecution or defense. The defense has a due-process right to an equal opportunity to interview them. It is inappropriate for either a prosecutor or a defense attorney to instruct witnesses to not talk to anyone unless the attorney is present. Gregory v. U.S., 369 F.2d 185 (D.C. Cir. 1966); Schulz v. Marshall, 528 F. Supp. 2d 77 (E.D. N.Y. 2007), judgment aff’d, 345 Fed. Appx. 627 (2d Cir. 2009); People v. Eanes, 43 A.D.2d 744, 350 N.Y.S.2d 718 (2d Dep’t 1973).

 

Practice Tip

The issue of advising witnesses has arisen in other jurisdictions. Where the prosecutor merely advised witnesses of the right to decline the request for an interview, this was permissible. U.S. v. Black, 767 F.2d 1334, 19 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 128 (9th Cir. 1985); U.S. v. Pinto, 755 F.2d 150, 17 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 690 (10th Cir. 1985).

 

But an artfully worded advisement does not necessarily insulate counsel. In one federal case, prosecutors said to a witness that they couldn’t tell the witness not to talk to the defense, but could tell him that he probably shouldn’t, and that anything said would be used later against the witness. The disapproval of communicating with the defense chilled the witnesses’ willingness to communicate and was found improper. U.S. v. Peter Kiewit Sons’ Co., 655 F. Supp. 73 (D. Colo. 1986) (federal judge ordered deposition of witnesses). See also State v. Hofstetter, 75 Wash. App. 390, 878 P.2d 474 (Div. 2 1994). See Hall, Professional Responsibility in Criminal Defense Practice, 3rd ed, §§ 16:14 et seq.

 

Defense counsel may also speak with grand jury witnesses, who may disclose their own testimony. See § 6:6, Proceedings conducted in secret. Defense counsel should not communicate with a complainant or witness who is represented by another attorney in that matter. Rules of Prof. Conduct, Rule 4.2(a).

 

It is improper for an attorney to record a conversation without informing the other person. See § 1:21, Ethical issues.

 

An attorney may not advise a witness to leave the jurisdiction to avoid testifying as a witness. RPC 3.4(a)(2).

 

The defense may seek to obtain information, including by subpoena or court order. See §§ 8:89 et seq., Discovery from victim or third party.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:68

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:68. Role of the complainant—Complainant’s attitude can affect prosecutor’s discretion

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

Once charges have been filed, they are in the hands of the district attorney, who has discretion in handling the case, including whether to drop or reduce charges, or offer no reduction. People v. Eboli, 34 N.Y.2d 281, 357 N.Y.S.2d 435, 313 N.E.2d 746 (1974). See § 1:9, Prosecutor: the district attorney; § 3:5, Prosecutorial discretion to determine charges to be filed.

 

A complainant’s attitude about the case, though, can have a considerable effect on how the district attorney will proceed. See § 2:4, Representing a witness.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:69

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:69. Role of the complainant—Complainant’s attitude can affect prosecutor’s discretion—Defense seeking to have complainant drop charges

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

The defendant or the defense attorney may wish to induce the complainant to drop criminal charges, as well as resolve any civil suit arising out of the criminal charges.

 

Deciding what steps by the defense are permissible toward these ends can be problematic. Improper actions may lead to additional criminal charges, such as intimidating a witness or bribery. People v. Soper, 209 A.D.2d 829, 620 N.Y.S.2d 1014 (3d Dep’t 1994); 18 U.S.C.A. § 1512(b).

 

Further, if a defendant attempts to procure false testimony from a complainant, it may be admissible to show consciousness of guilt, People v. Hernandez, 118 A.D.2d 729, 500 N.Y.S.2d 61 (2d Dep’t 1986), as would an attempt at manipulation by defendant’s relative, if done with the defendant’s knowledge and consent. Compare People v. Plummer, 36 N.Y.2d 161, 365 N.Y.S.2d 842, 325 N.E.2d 161 (1975) with People v. Ramdowe, 204 A.D.2d 663, 612 N.Y.S.2d 206 (2d Dep’t 1994). See § 12:34, Evidence of witness intimidation.

 

And, of course, preparing an affidavit by which a person falsely recants prior testimony is improper. Matter of Barrett, 183 A.D.2d 1076, 583 N.Y.S.2d 606 (3d Dep’t 1992).

 

It is proper for defense counsel to have a complainant sign a “general release” with payment to drop civil and criminal charges, because this does not constitute an illegal agreement either to alter testimony or to avoid appearing at a proceeding. People v. Harper, 75 N.Y.2d 313, 552 N.Y.S.2d 900, 552 N.E.2d 148 (1990); see also People v. Gagnon, 21 Misc. 3d 594, 863 N.Y.S.2d 903 (Sup 2008); Penal Law § 215.45(2).

 

It is improper for an attorney to threaten to present criminal charges solely to gain an advantage in a civil matter. RPC 3.4(e).

 

Practice Tip:

Although the defendant as well as the defense attorney can discuss dropping charges with the complainant and obtain a “release” to that end, the defendant should always be advised by counsel not to do so, and in fact to have no contact whatsoever with the complainant.

 

Only the defense attorney or the attorney’s investigator should broach the subject of dropping charges with the victim. Under the Rules of Professional Conduct, an attorney should not give advice to an unrepresented person, other than to advise the person to secure counsel, if the person’s interests are likely to conflict with the lawyer’s client. RPC 4.3. For the defendant her/himself to do so is a course of action that, as noted above, is fraught with peril. Defense counsel as well should take care that neither the complainant or prosecutor afterward can assert that overreaching or other impropriety occurred. The presence of a witness, or having another person notarize a statement, or referring the complainant to another attorney, are among the safeguards to consider. In re Rowe, 12 A.D.3d 133, 784 N.Y.S.2d 440 (4th Dep’t 2004).

 

Practice Tip:

Where the complainant contacts the defense attorney and wants to drop criminal charges, counsel should consider having the person sign an affidavit to this effect, and also include in the affidavit any discrepancies between what was alleged in the accusatory and what the person says actually occurred. Also include information accentuating the weaknesses in the prosecution’s case, as well as a statement that the defense attorney did not provide legal advice to the complainant.

 

All information in the affidavit should be accurate. See Matter of Barrett, 183 A.D.2d 1076, 583 N.Y.S.2d 606 (3d Dep’t 1992).

 

Where a complainant who has filed charges wishes to discontinue the case, some prosecutor’s offices will request that the complainant sign an affidavit to that effect. While the district attorney has discretion on whether to continue with charges, the affidavit may dissuade further prosecution. If further prosecution occurs, the complainant’s affidavit may be helpful as part of a motion to dismiss in the interest of justice. See Ch 10, Dismissal in Interests of Justice.

 

Compounding a crime, Penal Law § 215.45, occurs by accepting a benefit for agreeing to refrain from bringing criminal charges. It is an affirmative defense that the benefit did not exceed an amount that the defendant reasonably believed was restitution or indemnification.

 

See § 1:104 for Form—No prosecute statement.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:70

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:70. Role of the complainant—Order of protection

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

The court may issue an “order of protection” that requires the defendant to stay away from or have no contact with the complainant in a case. The order of protection may be issued during the pendency of the case, such as at arraignment, or at the end of the case, at sentencing. See §§ 22:60 et seq., Order of protection.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:71

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:71. Role of the complainant—Involvement in sentencing

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​804(.5)

 

 

The victim of a serious crime has a right to be notified and to participate in the sentencing. CPL 380.50(2); see also Exec L §§ 640 et seq.; see 22 NYCRR Part 129. See §§ 22:60 et seq., Order of protection; §§ 22:69 et seq., Restitution to crime victim; § 22:197, Victim’s right to address sentencing court.

 

The presentence report should include a victim impact statement. CPL 390.30(3)(b). Upon request, the prosecutor must give the victim written notice of the final disposition of the case, whether that be an acquittal, dismissal, or a conviction and sentence. CPL 440.50.

 

The victim of a violent felony offense is to be notified by the prosecutor within 60 days of final disposition of the case. A crime victim statement is considered during the parole process. See CPL 440.50(1). See § 23:123, Factors considered for parole release.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:72

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:72. Further proceedings in felony cases

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

In terms of jurisdiction, local (district, city, town or village) courts may handle preliminary matters with a felony charge: the judge may arraign the felony defendant, set bail, and hold a preliminary hearing. If the defendant is out of custody on a felony charge, the case may be adjourned for a possible plea offer by the prosecutor. But after an indictment charging a felony, all proceedings, including trial, occur in a superior court. In New York City, felony cases are tried in Supreme Court. In other counties, the superior court where a felony case is tried may be either County or Supreme Court.

 

As a procedural matter, the additional proceedings that may occur with a felony charge also differentiate this more serious offense from lesser ones.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:73

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:73. Further proceedings in felony cases—Preliminary hearing in felony cases

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

A felony defendant who remains incarcerated after arraignment (because of an inability to make bail, or a denial of the bail application) is entitled to a preliminary hearing five days (six if a weekend or holiday intervenes) after being taken into custody. See Ch 5, The Preliminary Hearing.

 

The purpose of the preliminary hearing is to determine whether there is “reasonable cause” to continue holding the defendant on the felony charge. The prosecution must call witnesses to establish the defendant’s commission of a felony. The defense is entitled to question the witnesses.

 

If, after the hearing, the local court judge determines that reasonable cause exists, the accused is “bound over” for (kept in custody to await action of) the grand jury. See Ch 6, Grand Jury Proceedings. The lack of reasonable cause will result in the defendant’s release. See Ch 5, The Preliminary Hearing.

 

If the prosecution does not proceed with the preliminary hearing, the case is referred to the grand jury and the defendant is released on that charge.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:74

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:74. Further proceedings in felony cases—Felony charge at grand jury

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

Any charge to be tried as a felony must be submitted to a grand jury, a body that hears the evidence and decides whether there is “reasonable cause” and “legally sufficient” evidence to charge the defendant with a felony. If the evidence is sufficient, the defendant is charged in an indictment. See Ch 3, Accusatory Instruments; Ch 6, Grand Jury Proceedings.

 

If there is insufficient evidence, the charge may be reduced or dismissed by the grand jury.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:75

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:75. Further proceedings in felony cases—Superior court arraignment on indictment

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

A defendant indicted by a grand jury must appear again in court, this time in a superior court, for arraignment and the entry of a plea on the felony indictment. Bail status will also be reviewed. See Ch 4, Arraignment and Bail.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:76

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:76. Discovery

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​627.5(1)

 

 

The prosecution is required to provide the defense with “automatic discovery.” The information includes previous statements of witnesses who will testify at trial as prosecution witnesses, reports of laboratory tests, and the like. See § 8:4, Timing of initial prosecution disclosure.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:77

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:77. Defense motions

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​632(3.1)
