Before trial, defense counsel will seek various forms of relief, such as dismissal of one or more charges against the defendant, review of grand jury minutes, or suppression of evidence. Any such relief must be requested through a written motion on notice to the prosecutor, who is entitled to respond.

 

The primary defense motion, the “omnibus” motion, normally contains all the pretrial requests appropriate for a particular defendant. Some requests may be waived if omitted from this motion, although the opportunity remains to bring other motions—before, during, and after trial—as warranted by the circumstances of a case.

 

The defense must file its omnibus motion within 45 days after either arraignment (arraignment on the indictment, in a felony case) or defense counsel’s first court appearance in the case, whichever comes later. See § 7:1, The omnibus motion, generally. The motion consists of a Notice of Motion and an affidavit or affirmation, along with whatever exhibits are necessary. It is served upon the prosecution and made returnable before the judge assigned to the case. See § 7:55, Notice of motion (omnibus motion) and § 7:56, Affirmation in support of omnibus motion.

 

Some types of relief that this motion frequently requests include the following, although this list is by no means exhaustive:

         • dismissal of the accusatory instrument as defective, see Ch 3, Accusatory Instruments.

         • review of the grand jury proceedings, see Ch 6, Grand Jury Proceedings.

         • suppression of evidence obtained in violation of the U.S. or New York State Constitution. The evidence sought to be suppressed can include: tangible evidence seized by the police; an improperly conducted and suggestive identification of the defendant; or a statement obtained in violation of the defendant’s rights. See Ch 9, Suppression.

         • dismissal in the interests of justice, see Ch 10, Dismissal in Interest of Justice.

         • restricting the use of evidence of other crimes or bad acts in the defendant’s past on the People’s direct case. Under certain circumstances the prosecutor may use such evidence to prove guilt; this is known as Molineux evidence. The defense should request a ruling from the court before the start of trial disallowing the use of such evidence. See Ch 12, Proving Guilt With Uncharged Crimes.

         • the prosecution may also wish to use evidence of other crimes or bad acts on cross-examination to impeach the credibility of a defendant who exercises the right to testify at trial; this is known as a Sandoval issue. The defense should request a pretrial ruling restricting Sandoval cross-examination, since the extent to which the prosecution is permitted to use such evidence will affect the defendant’s decision to take the stand. See Ch 11, Defendant’s Decision to Testify.

         • severance of charges or codefendants from the same trial, see Ch 14, Codefendants and Accomplices.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:78

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:78. Defense motions—Prosecution response to defense motions

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​632(3.1)

 

 

The prosecution will respond in writing to a defense motion, admitting or disputing defense allegations. See § 7:13, Prosecutor’s response; § 7:56, Affirmation in response to omnibus motion. The prosecution as well may move for various forms of relief. Often this is brought in a cross-motion.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:79

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:79. Defense motions—Hearings on defense motions

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​632(3.1)

 

 

When the prosecution contests a defense motion, the court, on the return date, may schedule a hearing to determine the facts in dispute. Certain common hearings involving constitutional claims are the Huntley hearing (suppression of a statement of the defendant) and the Mapp hearing (suppression of physical evidence seized from the defendant). Hearings on a number of other defense issues may be held as well. See Ch 7, Motion and Hearing Practice.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:80

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:80. Resolution without trial

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​273.2(1)

 

 

The vast majority of criminal cases do not reach trial, but are resolved through various other means. These include plea bargaining, see Ch 17, The Guilty Plea, dismissal of an accusatory instrument as defective, see Ch 3, Accusatory Instruments, dismissal of the charge due to suppression of evidence, see Ch 9, Suppression, dismissal on speedy trial grounds, see Ch 13, Time Limits, or dismissal by the grand jury for lack of sufficient evidence. See Ch 6, Grand Jury Proceedings. Alternatively, the parties and judge may agree to an Adjournment in Contemplation of Dismissal as an appropriate disposition. See § 22:38, Adjournment in contemplation of dismissal, generally.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:81

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:81. Resolution without trial—The guilty plea and plea bargaining

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​273.2(1)

 

 

Many cases are resolved by the defendant entering a guilty plea. In so doing the defendant voluntarily gives up the right to a trial and other rights, typically as part of a “plea bargain.” See § 17:6, Plea negotiations generally discretionary with prosecutor.

 

In this process the defendant may be offered the opportunity to plead guilty to a charge that is less serious than the one that is pending. Or the defendant may plead guilty to the highest charge, upon the judge’s representation that, in return, a certain amount and type of punishment will be imposed. A plea may also be entered to one charge in satisfaction of multiple charges. Various plea arrangements are possible. See Ch 16, Lesser Included Offenses; Ch 17, The Guilty Plea.

 

By pleading guilty, many issues are waived, while others may survive, absent more specific waivers. In addition, the defendant may be required to waive the right to appeal as a condition of the plea bargain.

 

After pleading guilty, a defendant may seek to withdraw the guilty plea. Courts rarely grant such a motion. See § 17:63, Withdrawal of plea by defendant.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:82

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:82. Agencies

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

An important component of the criminal justice system in many parts of New York State is the role played by agencies. A judge may refer the case to an alternate dispute resolution organization (mediation). See § 18:33, Privileged communications. Or a defendant with an apparent problem with drugs, alcohol, or violence may be referred (with defense and prosecutor’s consent) to an agency to address that problem. These referrals occur most frequently with lower offenses rather than high felonies or violent crimes. The agency’s report to the court on a later adjourned date will strongly influence the court’s and prosecutor’s perception of how the case should be handled.

 

Obtaining information from other sources may be critical for the defense in certain cases, including for investigation, plea bargaining, trial preparation, and sentencing. While a subpoena can be used in pending litigation, see § 8:97, Use of subpoenas, often a release of information is the better route.

 

With alcohol and drug information, as well as Child Protective Services reports, restrictions on disclosure may require the use of a special release form. Men Hyg Law § 33.16. See § 1:94, Specialized courts; § 8:126, Access to court records. For hospital records, see http://www.nycourts.gov/forms/Hipaa_fillable.pdf A. Also, http://www.nycourts.gov/litigants/forms.shtml.

 

The maximum cost for patients obtaining their own records is $.75 per page. Public Health Law § 18(2)(e).

 

Where new counsel represents a defendant, it may be important to obtain prior counsel’s file. See § 2:68, Substitution of counsel; obtaining file from former counsel.

 

See § 1:102 for Form—Release of information request.

 

See § 1:103 for Form—Release of information: HIPAA form.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:83

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:83. Trial

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​618

 

 

If the defense and prosecution cannot agree upon a disposition of the case, and if any hearings do not result in dismissal, a trial will be scheduled.

 

The prosecution is subject to the highest standard of proof—establishing its case “beyond a reasonable doubt”—in its effort to prove that the defendant committed the crime. See Ch 19, Trial.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:84

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:84. Trial—Jury and bench trials

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​254.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​618

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​731

 

 

If the charge is a felony, the defense is entitled to a jury of 12 people. If the highest charge is a misdemeanor, the jury is six people. See § 19:81, Number of jurors to be selected.

 

The defendant may give up the right to a jury trial and have the charges decided by the judge. See §§ 19:69 et seq., Trial before a lay judge.

 

With a violation or traffic infraction, the trial is before the judge alone.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:85

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:85. Verdict

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​753.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​870

 

 

After the jury retires to consider its verdict, it may return to the courtroom for a readback of testimony or for further instructions from the judge. The jury’s verdict in a criminal case must be unanimous. CPL 310.80. See § 19:230, Verdict must be unanimous.

 

If, after a period of time, the jury is deadlocked and cannot reach a unanimous verdict, the judge may declare a mistrial and discharge the jury. The prosecutor has the right to retry the defendant on the same charges.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:86

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:86. Postverdict motion

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1044.1(1)

 

 

Between the time of conviction and sentencing, the defense may bring a motion, either orally or in writing, to set aside the verdict. This motion, called a CPL 330.30 motion, has specific limits on what may be raised. See Ch 20, Verdict and Motions to Set Aside.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:87

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:87. Sentencing

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1557(1)

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​200

 

 

If the defendant is convicted at trial, or pleads guilty, the judge may pronounce sentence immediately, and will often do so with low-level offenses. With serious charges, though, the judge will usually adjourn the case for several weeks to allow time for a “presentence investigation” to be written up by the probation department and submitted to the court. See Ch 22, Sentencing.

 

On the adjourned date for sentencing, the defendant and the attorneys are allowed to address the court, after which the judge pronounces sentence. If the defendant is to be incarcerated, the sentence usually begins immediately. See § 22:6, Incarceration.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:88

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:88. Postconviction motion

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1557(1)

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​200

 

 

Judgment of conviction occurs when the sentence is pronounced. CPL 1.20(15). At any time after sentencing, the defense may bring another motion, to set aside the judgment pursuant to CPL 440.10. Possible grounds for this motion include newly discovered evidence, or a claim that the judgment was obtained in violation of the defendant’s constitutional rights. See §§ 23:32 et seq., Coram nobis motion.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:89

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:89. Appeal after conviction

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1559

 

 

After conviction, whether by guilty plea or after trial, a defendant has the right to appeal. If the defendant pleaded guilty, the issues that can be raised on appeal may be quite restricted; additionally, waiver of appellate rights may become a threshold issue on the appeal. See Ch 17, The Guilty Plea; Ch 24, Appellate Practice.

 

If the defendant was convicted at trial, a larger number of issues can be appealed, although some issues, at least in the first instance, must be raised by either a CPL 330.30 or 440.10 motion, mentioned above.

 

While the appeal is pending, the defendant may seek to remain at liberty by requesting a stay of sentence from the appellate court. See § 4:81, Stay of sentence and release pending appeal.

 

Where reversal occurs, it may be possible to retry the defendant. Depending on the issue raised, the constitutional prohibition against double jeopardy may bar reprosecution. See § 24:123, Retrial after appeal.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:90

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:90. Appeal by prosecutor

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1016 to 1020.5

 

 

Where a defendant is acquitted at trial, double jeopardy principles bar the prosecution from appealing. See § 15:99, Double jeopardy; §§ 24:123 et seq., Retrial after appeal.

 

However, the prosecutor has the right to appeal, where provided for by statute. These include some pretrial suppression rulings and where the sentence imposed is erroneous as a matter of law. See §§ 24:43 et seq., Appeal by prosecutor.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:91

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:91. Jurisdiction of appellate courts

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1016 to 1020.5

 

 

The court a defendant appeals to depends on the court in which the defendant was convicted.

 

With a felony conviction, the defendant has been convicted in Supreme or County Court. The initial appeal is heard by the Appellate Division.

 

With a misdemeanor or violation conviction in town, village, and upstate city courts in the Third and Fourth Department, the appeal is to County Court. With a conviction in New York City Criminal Court or a district court in the Second Department, the appeal is to the Appellate Term of the appropriate judicial department. See § 24:21, Court appealed to.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:92

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:92. Acquittal or dismissal; civil remedies

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​257

 

 

If the jury verdict is not guilty, acquitting the defendant of all of the charges, double jeopardy prevents the prosecutor from retrying the defendant for those offenses. CPL Article 40. See § 15:99, Double jeopardy.

 

Upon acquittal or dismissal, all intermediate orders and components of the sentence should be vacated as well. See CPL 215.40.

 

A civil suit may arise due to an appellate reversal, or where a trial order of dismissal is granted. Owens v. State, 200 A.D.3d 1624, 161 N.Y.S.3d 608 (4th Dep’t 2021). Among the elements that must be pleaded and proved is that the defendant was “actually innocent.” Court of Claims Act § 8-b.

 

A person whose conviction is overturned in a collateral proceeding (such as CPL article 440) may be able to bring a civil action for compensation for unjust imprisonment. Court of Claims Act § 8-b. Where it is overturned on direct appeal, the wrongly convicted defendant may be entitled to file a civil action, in the Court of Claims, to establish actual innocence by clear and convincing evidence.

 

Additionally, there may be a claim against police for malicious prosecution and false arrest.

 

See § 1:105 for Form—Certificate of disposition.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:93

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

II. The Progress of a Criminal Case

§ 1:93. Virtual court appearances

Correlation Table

Due to the pandemic, a number of changes in the criminal-justice system have occurred. See § 13:1, Coronavirus’s effect on criminal law.

 

The state court system has moved toward virtual court appearances, using a variety of electronic methods. This trend may continue beyond the time that public health concerns exist. Significant legal and logistical problems arise based partly on the limitations caused by using virtual media. These difficulties arise both with trials as well as other court appearances.

 

Among the many issues are: the ability to confer with client and counsel, difficulties where there is more than one defendant (e.g., conferring between co-counsel), the ability to have a bench conference, reviewing exhibits offered into evidence, and effective examination of witnesses. Particularly with the latter, virtual court appearances may be an ersatz substitute.

 

Courts are authorized to innovate. Jud L § 2-b.

Example:

In CPL 440.47 proceeding to vacate sentence, defense failed to establish need for out-of-state witnesses to testify virtually. People v. Smith, 82 Misc. 3d 548, 205 N.Y.S.3d 713 (Sup 2023).

 

 

Constitutional confrontation issues may arise with virtual court appearances. Cf. Maryland v. Craig, 497 U.S. 836, 110 S. Ct. 3157, 111 L. Ed. 2d 666, 30 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1 (1990).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:94

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

III. Specialized courts and sealing issues

§ 1:94. Specialized courts

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​83

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​84(1)

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​86

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​92

 

 

In some parts of New York, specialized courts exist to address particular issues. These include:

 

community drug treatment

 

domestic violence

 

human trafficking intervention

 

family treatment

 

Opioid Stabilization Part

 

mental health

 

judicial diversion program (JDP)

 

veteran’s treatment

 

 

 

Drug court: Administrative rules provide that a defendant may sign an agreement that provides that communications occurring during staff meetings may be provided to the judge, whether defendant or defense counsel are present. See § 22:163, Noncompliance with diversion program.

 

Domestic violence court: Supreme Court, as a court of general jurisdiction, can include an “integrated domestic violence” part to accept domestic violence cases with criminal charges and a case in Supreme Court or Family Court involving a party or witness to a domestic violence case.

 

Judicial diversion program: see CPL art 216. See § 1:97, Sealing of dismissed cases and violation-level offenses.

 

Example:

Felony conviction occurring in “hybrid court” was valid. People v. Feliz, 202 A.D.3d 633, 162 N.Y.S.3d 373 (1st Dep’t 2022).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:95

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

III. Specialized courts and sealing issues

§ 1:95. Judicial diversion

Correlation Table

“Judicial diversion” of certain felony offenders exists. CPL article 216. This normally includes a defendant charged with a class B, C, D, or E drug felony, although previous felony convictions may disqualify.

 

A guilty plea normally is required before entering the Judicial Diversion Program, CPL 216.05(4); People v. Gavrilov, 178 A.D.3d 727, 115 N.Y.S.3d 358 (2d Dep’t 2019). But the consequence of deportation was found to warrant entry into JDP without a guilty plea, as conviction would render defendant ineligible for cancellation of removal or asylum relief even if the conviction was later withdrawn. People v. Kollie, 38 Misc. 3d 865, 959 N.Y.S.2d 854 (County Ct. 2013).

 

A judge has discretion to allow diversion over the DA’s objection. People v. Carper, 124 A.D.3d 1319, 997 N.Y.S.2d 579 (4th Dep’t 2015). A judge may not allow judicial diversion to a defendant whose criminal charges do not come within the diversion statute. CPL 410.91; Doorley v. DeMarco, 106 A.D.3d 27, 962 N.Y.S.2d 546 (4th Dep’t 2013); People v. Zerafa, 38 Misc. 3d 251, 954 N.Y.S.2d 831 (Sup 2012).

 

But inclusion in the indictment of nonviolent, non-specified crimes did not automatically disqualify defendant from judicial diversion. People v. Smith, 139 A.D.3d 131, 30 N.Y.S.3d 19 (1st Dep’t 2016). See also People v. Dawson, 47 Misc. 3d 425, 1 N.Y.S.3d 883 (Sup 2015) (defendant is eligible if non-specified crimes integrally relate to the specified crimes). See People v. Young, 184 A.D.3d 443, 126 N.Y.S.3d 450 (1st Dep’t 2020) (separate indictment charging a nonqualifying offense did not render defendant ineligible for judicial diversion) (dictum).

 

Sealing may be available upon successful completion of a judicial diversion program. See § 1:97, Sealing of dismissed cases and violation-level offenses.

 

A defendant alleged to have violated the terms of a diversion contract is not entitled to an evidentiary hearing, but must be allowed to submit letters, testimony, or affidavits. People v. Fiammegta, 14 N.Y.3d 90, 896 N.Y.S.2d 735, 923 N.E.2d 1123 (2010); see People v. Cooney, 120 A.D.3d 1445, 991 N.Y.S.2d 676 (3d Dep’t 2014). See § 22:163, Noncompliance with diversion program.

 

Appellate review of wrongful rejection from judicial diversion is not foreclosed by a guilty plea. People v. Commissiong, 194 A.D.3d 952, 147 N.Y.S.3d 143 (2d Dep’t 2021).

 

Examples:

Denial or removal from judicial diversion was proper in the following:

 

The judge found that defendant’s drug and alcohol history were not contributing factors to his criminal behavior, and given extensive criminal history, judge properly exercised discretion. People v. Clarke, 155 A.D.3d 1242, 65 N.Y.S.3d 578 (3d Dep’t 2017); People v. McKoy, 175 A.D.3d 1616, 108 N.Y.S.3d 520 (3d Dep’t 2019).

 

Defendant did not request participation until after pleading guilty. People v. Miller, 154 A.D.3d 1002, 63 N.Y.S.3d 112 (3d Dep’t 2017).

 

Although defendant successfully completed drug court, he used illegal drugs before final disposition. County Court properly sentenced defendant pursuant to the felony conviction. People v. Nedlik, 144 A.D.3d 1324, 40 N.Y.S.3d 677 (3d Dep’t 2016). See also People v. Alolafi, 170 A.D.3d 1379, 96 N.Y.S.3d 720 (3d Dep’t 2019).

 

Defendant was an inappropriate candidate. People v. Conley, 161 A.D.3d 1486, 77 N.Y.S.3d 772 (3d Dep’t 2018).

 

Denying participation in diversion was improper in the following:

 

Denying participation was improper, on the basis that defendant failed to show that his abuse or dependence was a “contributing” factor to his criminal behavior, where the facts suggested otherwise. People v. Alston, 161 A.D.3d 472, 77 N.Y.S.3d 17 (1st Dep’t 2018).

 

Practice Tip:

Defendants in diversion courts often enter into a contract that, among other things, waives the right to have counsel present during certain types of court appearances. People v. Cooney, supra.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:96

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

III. Specialized courts and sealing issues

§ 1:96. Diversionary programs

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Sentencing and Punishment​2045 to 2057

 

 

In many counties, various programs provide an alternative to the criminal justice system. Some diversion programs are geared toward defendants who are young or who are not repeat offenders; others may deal with recidivists. The district attorney’s office may recognize that participating in such a program is of significant benefit to the defendant and the community, and agree to place a criminal charge on hold pending the defendant’s completion of the program, which may involve mental health, employment or drug abuse counseling. The goal is to have the defendant not engage in any future criminal activity. In exchange for the defendant’s successful completion of the program, the prosecutor may agree to reduce or even dismiss the charges.

 

Example:

Ending drug treatment program and resentencing after 18 months’ participation was appropriate. People v. Lundy, 162 A.D.3d 1535, 78 N.Y.S.3d 842 (4th Dep’t 2018).

 

Practice Tip:

Where a defendant is seeking diversion, the prosecutor’s policy may require, e.g., a plea to a felony up front, with a reduction to a misdemeanor once the diversion program is completed. For some defendants, this approach may be unrealistic: their employer may have a policy that requires termination upon a felony conviction, and since conviction occurs upon verdict or guilty plea, CPL 1.20(13), the person has a felony conviction. One example: an attorney who is convicted of a felony is automatically disbarred. See In re Silberman, 62 A.D.3d 61, 874 N.Y.S.2d 466 (1st Dep’t 2009), reinstatement granted, 83 A.D.3d 95, 921 N.Y.S.2d 204 (1st Dep’t 2011). In this situation, defense counsel may need to produce the employer’s policy and seek an alternative solution.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:97

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

III. Specialized courts and sealing issues

§ 1:97. Sealing of dismissed cases and violation-level offenses

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1226(3.1)

 

 

Upon acquittal, or dismissal for other reasons, the records are sealed, with the defendant’s fingerprints and photos returned or destroyed. The sealed records are available to the defendant or designated agent. CPL 160.50(1)(d).

 

There are a few narrow exceptions to the prohibition against releasing sealed records. Katherine B. v. Cataldo, 5 N.Y.3d 196, 800 N.Y.S.2d 363, 833 N.E.2d 698 (2005). Where a criminal action is ends in favor of the accused, the sealed record is not available for consideration at sentencing on a different charge (revocation of interim probation). People v. Desdunes, 227 A.D.3d 1101, 212 N.Y.S.3d 675 (2d Dep’t 2024).

 

Sealing occurs where the entire accusatory instrument is dismissed. It does not occur where a defendant is convicted of one charge and other charges are dismissed. People v. O’Brien, 193 Misc. 2d 500, 750 N.Y.S.2d 737 (Sup 2002).

 

Not all items constitute “official records” subject to sealing. City of Elmira v. Doe, 11 N.Y.3d 799, 868 N.Y.S.2d 568, 897 N.E.2d 1049 (2008) (property tag, bags, logs, for use in later disciplinary proceeding). As to Domestic Incident Reports, compare People v. P.D., 78 Misc. 3d 352, 181 N.Y.S.3d 452 (NYC Crim. Ct. 2023) (DIRs not sealed) with People v. Anonymous, 76 Misc. 3d 1022, 174 N.Y.S.3d 820 (NYC Crim. Ct. 2022).

 

With a plea to a noncriminal offense, e.g., Disorderly Conduct or Harassment 2nd degree, sealing also occurs. CPL 160.55. Sealing occurs unless the prosecution moves upon not less than five days’ notice to stop the sealing in the interests of justice. People v. Anonymous, 7 A.D.3d 309, 776 N.Y.S.2d 282 (1st Dep’t 2004). But a conviction for Harassment 2nd may not be sealed if it was for a domestic violence-related offense. CPL 160.55(1)(d)(vi).

 

Criminal records are made confidential where a defendant is adjudicated a youthful offender, but this is not coextensive with the sealing that occurs with an adjudication favorable to the defendant.

 

Where a defendant has completed judicial diversion, drug court or other judicially-sanctioned drug treatment program of similar duration, requirements, and supervision, and has completed the sentence, “conditional sealing” is available. CPL 160.58. No person is required to divulge information relating to this type of sealing. It is improper to inquire or act adversely based on this type of sealing. Exec L § 296(16). See § 22:158, Conditional sealing.

 

Generally, the public has a common-law right of access to court records. See § 8:126, Access to court records.

 

Sealing does not always result in true sealing. Where a violation-level offense, Disorderly Conduct, was sealed, the court granted unsealing of the record for purposes of a SORA hearing. People v. S.L., 70 Misc. 3d 663, 137 N.Y.S.3d 659 (Sup 2020).

 

Records that are sealed may later be unsealed, e.g., for a civil commitment proceeding. See § 23:115, Trial on civil commitment.

 

Denial of a motion to seal a conviction is appealable. See People v. Coulibaly, 198 A.D.3d 84, 152 N.Y.S.3d 499 (2d Dep’t 2021).

 

Evidence obtained as the result of a statutory violation, lacking constitutional implications, is nonetheless admissible. People v. Stewart, 161 A.D.3d 1108, 78 N.Y.S.3d 176 (2d Dep’t 2018). See People v. Patterson, 78 N.Y.2d 711, 579 N.Y.S.2d 617, 587 N.E.2d 255 (1991).

 

Practice Tip:

In some situations, such as where a decision is to be published, the defense may seek (by motion) to keep the defendant’s name confidential. Situations may include where the defendant has cooperated with the prosecution. See People v. Anonymous, 12 A.D.3d 171, 786 N.Y.S.2d 134 (1st Dep’t 2004). See also People v. Anthony C., 6 Misc. 3d 616, 787 N.Y.S.2d 648 (Sup 2004).

 

Example:

The prosecutor’s motion to unseal records to allow police to have access was improper. Albany County Dist. Attorney’s Office ex rel. Barrett Tp. Police v. William T., 88 A.D.3d 1133, 931 N.Y.S.2d 154 (3d Dep’t 2011).

 

Sealing of criminal convictions is addressed in ch 23, subchapter, XI, Sealing of records; Rehabilitation certificates.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:98

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

IV. Recurring issues

§ 1:98. Forfeiture vs waiver

Correlation Table

An issue that arises at various points in criminal law is the distinction between forfeiture and waiver. Forfeiture is the loss of a right by operation of law, applied as a matter of public policy; waiver is the intentional relinquishment of a known right.

 

A waiver may be express or implied. People v. Thomas, 53 N.Y.2d 338, 441 N.Y.S.2d 650, 424 N.E.2d 537 (1981). Waiver cannot be accomplished through silence. People v. Jurgins, 26 N.Y.3d 607, 26 N.Y.S.3d 495, 46 N.E.3d 1048 (2015). See § 19:18, Waiver of right to be present at trial: Parker warnings.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:99

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

IV. Recurring issues

§ 1:99. Presumptions

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​305 t0 325

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Evidence​53 to 89

 

 

Throughout the criminal law, a number of presumptions exist, both statutory and common law. A statutory presumption allows a particular fact to be established by inferential proof. People v. Galindo, 23 N.Y.3d 719, 993 N.Y.S.2d 525, 17 N.E.3d 1121 (2014). These include:

         • presumption of sanity, People v. Silver, 33 N.Y.2d 475, 354 N.Y.S.2d 915, 310 N.E.2d 520 (1974).

         • presumption of effective assistance of counsel, People v. Myers, 220 A.D.2d 461, 632 N.Y.S.2d 27 (2d Dep’t 1995). See § 2:75, Defendant’s burden to overcome presumed effectiveness: strategy, § 24:99, Overcoming presumption if issue was not raised.

         • presumption of regularity, People v. Velasquez, 1 N.Y.3d 44, 769 N.Y.S.2d 156, 801 N.E.2d 376 (2003). See § 6:27, Presumption of regularity, § 24:35, Reconstruction hearing when record incomplete.

         • presumption of a statute’s constitutionality, see § 15:89, Presumption and burden of proof.

         • presumption of innocence, see § 19:203, Presumption of innocence.

         • presumption of competency to stand trial, see § 15:63, Hearing may be held.

         • presumption of validity of search warrant, see § 9:93, Courts that may review search warrant.

 

These presumptions may affect who has the burden of proof. It should be remembered that a presumption is rebuttable.

 

Additionally, the Penal Law contains a number of presumptions. Typically, these function as “shortcuts” to allow the prosecution to establish an element of a crime by establishing other facts.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:100

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

IV. Recurring issues

§ 1:100. Burdens of proof

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​326 to 336

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Evidence​90 to 98

 

 

Various burdens of proof may apply, depending on the issue and stage of the criminal action, and in related administrative proceedings. The burden may be upon the prosecution or upon the defendant. With some issues, the “burden of going forward” may shift from one party to the other. For a list of pretrial hearings, see § 7:38, Hearings and burdens of proof.

 

The “reasonable cause” standard, equated with the term “probable cause,” has been described as not meaning “‘more likely than not’ as though the phrase had some mathematically precise meaning.” People v. Mercado, 112 Misc. 2d 368, 446 N.Y.S.2d 980 (Sup 1982); People v. Quarles, 187 A.D.2d 200, 593 N.Y.S.2d 635 (4th Dep’t 1993). In applying the “probable cause” standard, it must appear more likely than not that a crime has taken place. See People v. Vandover, 20 N.Y.3d 235, 958 N.Y.S.2d 83, 981 N.E.2d 784 (2012).

 

At trial, the prosecution has the burden of proving guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. See § 19:207, Reasonable doubt. The reasonable doubt standard is inherently qualitative. See McCullough v. State, 99 Nev. 72, 657 P.2d 1157 (1983). See also Tribe, “Trial by Mathematics: Precision and Ritual in the Legal Process,” 84 Harv. L. Rev. 1329 (1971). Statistical evidence may lack a proper foundation to be admissible. See U.S. v. Jackson, 368 F.3d 59 (2d Cir. 2004).

 

Additionally, at various points at trial or on appeal, the evidence may be viewed in different ways, e.g., in the light most favorable to the defense (such as lesser included offenses, see § 16:13, Evidentiary standard favors defendant), or in the light most favorable to the prosecution (such as whether the evidence is legally sufficient, see § 18:204, Standard for decision).

 

It may be inappropriate for a court to use a previous adjudication with a lower standard of proof to a legal situation with a higher standard of proof. See, e.g., People v. Torres, 5 A.D.3d 1097, 773 N.Y.S.2d 726 (4th Dep’t 2004); People v. Rumph, 267 A.D.2d 1093, 701 N.Y.S.2d 218 (4th Dep’t 1999); People v. Milhouse, 246 A.D.2d 119, 676 N.Y.S.2d 555 (1st Dep’t 1998).

 

 

STANDARDS OF PROOF

 

Level

 

Example

 

Authority

 

Probable cause

 

Preliminary hearing

 

CPL 180.70(1)

Handling § 5:1

 

 

Grand jury

 

CPL 190.65(1)

Handling § 6:10

 

Preponderance

 

Affirmative defense, defendant has burden

 

Penal Law § 25.00(2)

Handling § 15:3

 

Clear and convincing evidence

 

SORA classification

 

Corr Law § 168–d(3)

Handling §§ 23:92 to 23:107

 

Beyond a reasonable doubt

 

Trial, prosecution has burden

 

CPL 300.10(2)

Handling § 19:214

 

 

Huntley hearing, prosecution has burden to show voluntariness

 

People v. Huntley, 15 N.Y.2d 72 (1965)

Handling § 9:197

 

 

Ordinary defense, prosecution has burden of disproving

 

Penal Law § 25.00(1)

Handling § 15:6

 

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 1:101

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 1. Overview of a Criminal Case

V. Forms

§ 1:101. Letter to client regarding fatality hearing

Correlation Table

(See § 1:32, Safety hearings)

 

In the near future, a hearing will be conducted by the Department of Motor Vehicles. This is required by law: any driver involved in a fatal accident is summoned to a “safety hearing.” The safety hearing is important, and the purpose of this letter is to give you some background information on what might take place at the hearing.

 

The hearing is administrative in nature. It is not a criminal proceeding, nor to impose a fine, nor a civil lawsuit to obtain damages.

 

The purpose of the hearing is to determine whether a person operated a motor vehicle “in a manner showing reckless disregard for life or property of others,” and if so, whether action should be taken by the DMV against the motorist’s license. The hearing can result in a driver’s license being suspended or revoked. Additionally, if an operator failed to file an accident (MV-104) report, the hearing would determine whether suspension should occur until the report is filed. The DMV Commissioner has the burden of proving a violation, supported by “substantial evidence.”

 

The safety hearing will take place at [time and date], in [location]. The person conducting the hearing is an “administrative law judge” (ALJ), who is an attorney employed by New York State. The hearing, which is audio recorded, is conducted pursuant to Vehicle & Traffic Law § 510.

 

Among the people who may attend the hearing are: you, the ALJ, a police officer who investigated the accident, and an insurance company representative—some may be there just in the role of observer. One or more attorneys, including me, as well as someone from the estate, may attend. Others who were present at the accident might attend.

 

Someone who attends the proceeding, such as an insurance company representative, may request exhibits, but can obtain them from DMV only via the Freedom of Information Law.

 

The ALJ will consider evidence, which is presented both orally and with exhibits. An investigating police officer usually testifies, along with other witnesses to the accident, and you can testify as well. All testimony is under oath. After a witness testifies, the ALJ or I will be allowed to question that witness further.

 

Various documents will likely be offered into evidence. These may include: your DMV driving abstract, photographs of the area, map, accident reports, police reports, accident reconstruction report, and cellphone records.

 

You have the right to testify, and also the right to decline to testify. I recommend that you testify; otherwise, the ALJ is allowed to draw a negative inference from your not testifying. Because the hearing is recorded, when answering questions, say “yes” or “no,” rather than nodding your head or saying “uh-huh.”

 

We should meet before the hearing, to go over what would be covered in your testimony and what questions I will ask other witnesses. Much of the questioning will be by the ALJ, and many will be quite standard, as noted below. The following questions are likely to be asked of you:

 

— Were you involved in a motor vehicle accident on [date], at about [time]; what day of the week this was this

— Were you driving, the type of vehicle, who it was registered to, what state it was registered in

— Were you a licensed driver on that date, was the license valid on that date, what class license is it, and how long you had your driver’s license

— Any required aids for driving (hearing, vision, etc.)

— Date of your last eye exam before the accident

— Were you alone in the car, or was someone else with you

— Were you familiar with the vehicle

— Is the road one- or two-way; what direction were you traveling

— Are there traffic lines on the road, single or double

— When did you first see the other vehicle

— What was the speed limit in the area, how fast were you traveling

— Was there a stop sign or traffic signal in the area

— Did the airbags in your vehicle deploy

— How far away from the accident did your vehicle stop

— Did you lose consciousness

— Where did the accident occur

— Which direction you were heading

— What you were traveling to

— The weather conditions at the time

— Your familiarity with that road

— Any obstructions to visibility in your car, or outside

— How much sleep did you get the night before the accident; how do you remember that

— Have you ever been treated for various ailments: epilepsy, diabetes, history of blackouts, dizziness, fainting, heart problem, high blood pressure

— Were you hospitalized for any reason three years before the accident

— Were you under a doctor’s care for six months before the accident

— At the time of the accident, were you taking (or supposed to be taking) any medication

— Did you use any other medication or drugs in the 24 hours before the accident

— Did you consume any alcoholic beverages in the 24 hours before the accident

— Were you issued any traffic tickets after the accident, what these were for, and the result in court of these tickets

— When the car was last inspected, whether you had any problems driving it

— How did the accident occur

— What you saw after the accident

— What you did after the accident, who you called

— Were you on your cell phone at the time, and whether the police officers checked your phone afterward

— Any other electronic devices (such as GPS) in the vehicle

After the Administrative Law Judge finishes questioning, I will have the opportunity to ask you questions as well. My questions will be to give background about you, and further develop some of the areas that the ALJ asked about. My questions may include:

 

— Where are you employed now, type of work

— Why you were driving to [location]

— What time you started out, where had you been earlier that day, whether you were eating or drinking anything in the car

— Were you running late, early, or on time to get to your destination

— Did you cooperate with the police

— Did you go to the hospital afterward

— Were you released by the police to a relative; when that person arrived

— Were you given a roadside test for alcohol consumption at the scene; the result of that

— Did you take any other alcohol/drug test as required by your employer; the result of that

— Whether you had any counseling after the accident

— Was the case reviewed by the District Attorney’s Office, and the result

— Did you file an MV-104 report

The hearing may last half an hour to an hour, or longer. At the end of the hearing, the ALJ will usually “reserve decision” and we should receive a written decision a few weeks later. If the ruling is against you, you can file an appeal within 60 days after the decision is issued.

 

Please let me know if you have any questions.

 

Very truly yours,

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

§ 1:102. Release of information request

Correlation Table

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​633.1

 

 

(See § 1:82, Agencies)

RELEASE OF INFORMATION

 

To: _____

_____

_____

_____ (name of client), _____ (date of birth/Social Security number), hereby authorizes and requests you to release to my attorney, _____ (name of attorney), _____ (address) or to my attorney’s authorized agent, any and all papers, records, reports, and other information in your possession or under your control pertaining to: ___________ (subject matter in question)

 

You are hereby authorized to speak to my attorney concerning this subject.

 

It is my desire that a photocopy of this document shall have the same force and effect as the original.

 

___________

(name of defendant)

Sworn to before me

this ___ day of ___, 20__

___________

Notary Public

I am the complainant in the above-listed charges. I do not wish to pursue the prosecution of this case. I make this statement freely and voluntarily, without any reservation or duress, and free from any threats. No promises of any kind have been made by anyone to make me sign this statement.

Correlation Table
