Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:1

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:1. Right to counsel, generally

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1870

 

 

A defendant charged with a crime (felony or misdemeanor) is entitled to be represented by an attorney. Gideon v. Wainwright, 372 U.S. 335, 83 S. Ct. 792, 9 L. Ed. 2d 799, 93 A.L.R.2d 733 (1963) (felonies); Argersinger v. Hamlin, 407 U.S. 25, 92 S. Ct. 2006, 32 L. Ed. 2d 530 (1972) (misdemeanors).

 

The New York Constitution provides a substantially greater right to counsel than the federal constitution or other state constitutions. N.Y. Const. Art. I, § 6; People v. Harris, 77 N.Y.2d 434, 568 N.Y.S.2d 702, 570 N.E.2d 1051 (1991).

 

A defendant may be entitled to assigned counsel in a CPL article 440 proceeding. See § 23:60, Defense right to counsel.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:2

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:2. Right to counsel, generally—Assigned counsel

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1870

 

 

When a crime is charged, the court must inform the defendant, financially unable to obtain the services of an attorney, that he/she has the right to have one assigned by the court. CPL 170.10(3); CPL 180.10(3); People v. Van Florcke, 120 Misc. 2d 273, 467 N.Y.S.2d 298 (App. Term 1983). See § 2:21, Types of representation.

 

Even if the judge eliminates the possibility of incarceration by stating that no such sentence will be imposed, an indigent accused of a crime is still entitled to an assigned attorney. CPL 170.10(3)(c); People v. Ross, 67 N.Y.2d 321, 502 N.Y.S.2d 693, 493 N.E.2d 917 (1986).

 

At the time of arraignment, a local judge setting bail must allow an indigent defendant the use of a telephone to obtain counsel, to inform a relative or friend that he or she has been charged with an offense, and determine eligibility for assigned counsel. 22 NYCRR § 200.26. See § 4:20, Right to counsel.

 

The determination of eligibility for assigned counsel varies greatly among courts. Judges infrequently determine eligibility at arraignment. A defendant who is released may be given instructions regarding obtaining assigned counsel.

 

Denial of an attorney due to financial ineligibility may be challenged on appeal. See People v. Zahangir, 73 Misc. 3d 138(A), 155 N.Y.S.3d 527 (App. Term 2021).

 

Traffic infractions do not entitle the defendant to assigned counsel. CPL 170.10(3)(c); Scott v. Illinois, 440 U.S. 367, 99 S. Ct. 1158, 59 L. Ed. 2d 383 (1979); People v. Farinaro, 36 N.Y.2d 283, 367 N.Y.S.2d 258, 326 N.E.2d 819 (1975). However, an indigent who is charged with a violation or an offense under a local law for which a term of imprisonment is authorized (other than a traffic infraction) is entitled to assigned counsel. County Law § 722-a.

 

Practice Tip:

The court has an obligation to determine whether the defendant is financially eligible for assigned counsel. Typically the court or a Legal Aid/Public Defender attorney interviews the defendant to make this determination. People v. McKiernan, 84 N.Y.2d 915, 620 N.Y.S.2d 808, 644 N.E.2d 1364 (1994).

 

Counsel is not appointed in a property forfeiture proceeding. Morgenthau v. Rodriguez, 261 A.D.2d 165, 690 N.Y.S.2d 201 (1st Dep’t 1999). See § 1:64, Property held by police: evidence, retained or forfeited.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:3

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:3. Right to counsel, generally—Counsel required at “critical stages”

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1870

 

 

Once an accusatory instrument has been filed, the right to counsel attaches. See 32 New York Jur 2d, Criminal Law: Procedure, §§ 795-827. Certain parts of the criminal justice process have been found to be a “critical stage,” while others have not. See U.S. v. Wade, 388 U.S. 218, 87 S. Ct. 1926, 18 L. Ed. 2d 1149 (1967).

 

The following have been found to be a critical stage:

         • arrest warrant, People v. Jones, 2 N.Y.3d 235, 778 N.Y.S.2d 133, 810 N.E.2d 415 (2004)

         • arraignment, Hamilton v. State of Ala., 368 U.S. 52, 82 S. Ct. 157, 7 L. Ed. 2d 114 (1961); Hurrell-Harring v. State, 15 N.Y.3d 8, 904 N.Y.S.2d 296, 930 N.E.2d 217 (2010)

         • bail hearing, see Hurrell-Harring v. State, 15 N.Y.3d 8, 904 N.Y.S.2d 296, 930 N.E.2d 217 (2010)

         • preliminary hearing, Coleman v. Alabama, 399 U.S. 1, 90 S. Ct. 1999, 26 L. Ed. 2d 387 (1970); see People v. Wicks, 76 N.Y.2d 128, 556 N.Y.S.2d 970, 556 N.E.2d 409 (1990)

         • prearrest lineup, where there has been “significant judicial activity” in the matter. People v. Coates, 74 N.Y.2d 244, 544 N.Y.S.2d 992, 543 N.E.2d 440 (1989)

         • postindictment lineup, People v. Coleman, 43 N.Y.2d 222, 401 N.Y.S.2d 57, 371 N.E.2d 819 (1977)

         • appearing at a grand jury proceeding, Trudeau v. Cantwell, 31 A.D.3d 844, 817 N.Y.S.2d 760 (3d Dep’t 2006)

         • pretrial psychiatric examination, People v. Guevara, 37 N.Y.3d 1014, 152 N.Y.S.3d 866, 174 N.E.3d 1240 (2021); Lee v. County Court of Erie County, 27 N.Y.2d 432, 318 N.Y.S.2d 705, 267 N.E.2d 452 (1971)

         • initial commitment hearing, CPL 330.20(6); In re Brian HH., 39 A.D.3d 1007, 833 N.Y.S.2d 718 (3d Dep’t 2007).

         • competency hearing, see People v. Perkins, 166 A.D.2d 737, 562 N.Y.S.2d 244 (3d Dep’t 1990)

         • pretrial proceedings concerning DNA discovery motion, People v. Smith, 30 N.Y.3d 626, 69 N.Y.S.3d 566, 92 N.E.3d 789 (2017)

         • suppression hearing, People v. Carracedo, 214 A.D.2d 404, 624 N.Y.S.2d 601 (1st Dep’t 1995)

         • plea bargaining, Lafler v. Cooper, 566 U.S. 156, 132 S. Ct. 1376, 182 L. Ed. 2d 398 (2012)

         • guilty plea, Iowa v. Tovar, 541 U.S. 77, 124 S. Ct. 1379, 158 L. Ed. 2d 209 (2004)

         • trial, Perry v. Leeke, 488 U.S. 272, 109 S. Ct. 594, 102 L. Ed. 2d 624 (1989)

         • jury instructions, People v. Martin, 26 A.D.3d 847, 808 N.Y.S.2d 865 (4th Dep’t 2006), order aff’d, 8 N.Y.3d 129, 831 N.Y.S.2d 738, 863 N.E.2d 990 (2007)

         • sentencing, Townsend v. Burke, 334 U.S. 736, 68 S. Ct. 1252, 92 L. Ed. 1690 (1948); see People v. Sparber, 10 N.Y.3d 457, 859 N.Y.S.2d 582, 889 N.E.2d 459 (2008)

         • revocation of parole, People ex rel. Donohoe v. Montanye, 35 N.Y.2d 221, 360 N.Y.S.2d 619, 318 N.E.2d 781 (1974).

 

The following are not a “critical stage”:

         • warrantless arrest, People v. Pelkey, 100 A.D.2d 663, 473 N.Y.S.2d 616 (3d Dep’t 1984)

         • interrogation by police before the filing of charges, People v. Ramos, 99 N.Y.2d 27, 750 N.Y.S.2d 821, 780 N.E.2d 506 (2002)

         • investigatory lineup, People v. Hernandez, 70 N.Y.2d 833, 523 N.Y.S.2d 442, 517 N.E.2d 1328 (1987); People v. LaClere, 76 N.Y.2d 670, 563 N.Y.S.2d 30, 564 N.E.2d 640 (1990)

         • intoxication tests, including blood tests, People v. Bradway, 285 A.D.2d 831, 728 N.Y.S.2d 286 (3d Dep’t 2001)

         • filing of charges against a codefendant, People v. Williams, 112 A.D.2d 259, 491 N.Y.S.2d 706 (2d Dep’t 1985)

         • filing of a “John Doe” indictment, People v. Dickson, 133 A.D.2d 492, 519 N.Y.S.2d 419 (3d Dep’t 1987); see § 13:9, Tolling: defendant’s whereabouts unknown

         • parole warrant and arrest, People v. Pelkey, 294 A.D.2d 669, 742 N.Y.S.2d 693 (3d Dep’t 2002)

         • search warrant application, People v. Wells, 133 A.D.2d 385, 519 N.Y.S.2d 553 (2d Dep’t 1987), and execution thereof, People v. Dawson, 249 A.D.2d 977, 672 N.Y.S.2d 203 (4th Dep’t 1998)

         • removal of a defendant from Treatment Alternatives to Street Crime (TASC), People v. Garcia, 92 N.Y.2d 726, 685 N.Y.S.2d 919, 708 N.E.2d 992 (1999)

         • presentence investigation interview, People v. McNamara, 103 A.D.3d 1273, 958 N.Y.S.2d 925 (4th Dep’t 2013); People v. Bogart, 148 Misc. 2d 327, 560 N.Y.S.2d 266 (Sup 1990)

         • execution of sentence, People v. Harris, 79 N.Y.2d 909, 581 N.Y.S.2d 657, 590 N.E.2d 242 (1992)

         • extradition process, People v. Morton, 104 A.D.2d 569, 479 N.Y.S.2d 275 (2d Dep’t 1984)

 

An attorney’s absence at a stage, which does not affect the adjudication of a case, is not ground for reversal. People v. Kaetzel, 117 A.D.3d 1187, 985 N.Y.S.2d 734 (3d Dep’t 2014).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:4

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:4. Right to counsel, generally—Representing a witness

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1870

 

 

A witness at a trial or hearing may give self-incriminating testimony or be a “material witness.” Or, the prosecutor may emphasize the possibility of prosecuting a defense witness for perjury, affecting the witness’s choice of whether to testify. See People v. Vernay, 174 A.D.3d 1485, 106 N.Y.S.3d 507 (4th Dep’t 2019). In these situations, the judge may allow the witness to retain counsel or can appoint counsel particularly where a witness refuses to testify or might make an incriminating statement. The judge may assign an attorney to give advice, particularly where the witness refuses to testify or might make an incriminating statement. See § 2:21, Types of representation; § 18:46, Witness invoking Fifth Amendment; §§ 18:81 et seq., Material witness proceeding.

 

When representing a witness, counsel needs to consider whether the witness could be prosecuted for perjury or for making a false written statement. Did the witness make a previous statement under oath? Was that statement made within the applicable statute of limitation?

 

If there is exposure, will the prosecution offer immunity? See § 18:47, Immunity granted only by prosecutor.

 

An attorney should not communicate with a witness who is represented by an attorney in that matter. RPC 4.2(a). See §§ 1:66 et seq., Role of the complainant.

 

A witness is obligated to attend court in response to a properly served subpoena, but is not required to meet with an attorney to prepare for trial. The witness’s attorney should also consider whether there are grounds to move to quash the subpoena. See §§ 8:118 to 8:120, Motion to quash.

 

A grand jury witness who is called by the DA receives immunity and is not entitled to have counsel present in the grand jury room, but can confer with counsel outside the room. Where the grand jury calls the witness, and therefore immunity is waived, the witness is entitled to have counsel present in the grand jury room. See §§ 6:14 et seq., Witness rights; immunity.

 

See § 2:112 for Checklist—Checklist of issues in representing a witness.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:5

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:5. Right to proceed pro se

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1975

 

 

A defendant is not required to retain an attorney or accept assignment of counsel, with the attendant reliance on the attorney’s decision-making. The defendant has a constitutional right to proceed in propria persona. Faretta v. California, 422 U.S. 806, 95 S. Ct. 2525, 45 L. Ed. 2d 562 (1975); People v. Silvers, 68 N.Y.2d 957, 510 N.Y.S.2d 540, 503 N.E.2d 96 (1986); N.Y. Const. Art. I, § 6.

 

The court, however, is not obliged to inform every defendant of the right to proceed pro se. People v. McIntyre, 36 N.Y.2d 10, 364 N.Y.S.2d 837, 324 N.E.2d 322 (1974); People v. Williams, 256 A.D.2d 661, 681 N.Y.S.2d 150 (3d Dep’t 1998).

 

A request to proceed pro se may be in essence a request for new assigned counsel. See People v. Hayden, 250 A.D.2d 937, 672 N.Y.S.2d 538 (3d Dep’t 1998).

 

The court is not required to advise the defendant that waiving counsel entails the risk that a viable defense will be overlooked and deprives the defendant of the opportunity to obtain an independent opinion on the wisdom of pleading guilty. Iowa v. Tovar, 541 U.S. 77, 124 S. Ct. 1379, 158 L. Ed. 2d 209 (2004).

 

A defendant does not have a federal constitutional right to self-representation on a direct appeal. Martinez v. Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate Dist., 528 U.S. 152, 120 S. Ct. 684, 145 L. Ed. 2d 597 (2000).

 

Practice Tips:

When dealing with a pro se defendant, the prosecutor should take special care (e.g., documenting the delivery of discovery) and avoid personal or telephone contact.

 

A pro se defendant in many ways is at a significant disadvantage. This is particularly so where the defendant is incarcerated. Aside from lacking the knowledge that a trained lawyer possesses, and the ability of another person to evaluate somewhat objectively, there are problems of limited access to legal research, ability to investigate, to issue and serve subpoenas, and serve and file papers. See, e.g., People v. Herbin, 187 A.D.3d 520, 132 N.Y.S.3d 423 (1st Dep’t 2020). As Peter M. Tiersma observed, “The hope that every man can be his own lawyer, which has existed for centuries, is probably no more realistic than having people be their own doctor.”

 

Example:

Denial of defendant’s request to represent himself on felony charge was improper, though defendant was unfamiliar with legal issues, but he had made a timely request, there was no indication that he would act disorderly, and defendant clearly stated he wanted to proceed pro se. People v. Hamilton, 133 A.D.3d 1090, 20 N.Y.S.3d 676 (3d Dep’t 2015); see also, People v. Paulin, 140 A.D.3d 985, 33 N.Y.S.3d 459 (2d Dep’t 2016).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:6

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:6. Right to proceed pro se—Three-part test

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1975

 

 

If the defendant makes the request to proceed pro se, the court must engage in a “searching inquiry” of the risks inherent in proceeding pro se and the singular importance of the lawyer in the adversarial system. People v. Crampe, 17 N.Y.3d 469, 932 N.Y.S.2d 765, 957 N.E.2d 255 (2011); People v. Herbin, 161 A.D.3d 672, 78 N.Y.S.3d 110 (1st Dep’t 2018). The court must be satisfied that the following requirements have been met, People v. McIntyre, 36 N.Y.2d 10, 364 N.Y.S.2d 837, 324 N.E.2d 322 (1974):

         • The request must be unequivocally and timely asserted. If a defendant gives a contrary indication, the right to counsel is not surrendered. The request is timely where it is made before trial commences. People v. Crespo, 32 N.Y.3d 176, 88 N.Y.S.3d 120, 112 N.E.3d 1243 (2018).

   Example:

     Defendant’s request to represent himself, after 11 jurors had been selected and sworn in, was untimely. People v. Crespo, 32 N.Y.3d 176, 88 N.Y.S.3d 120, 112 N.E.3d 1243 (2018). The statement, “I would love to go pro se,” did not trigger the trial judge’s need to inquire about self-representation. People v. Duarte, 37 N.Y.3d 1218, 163 N.Y.S.3d 487, 183 N.E.3d 1205 (2022). A defendant who asks only to participate in the defense, such as addressing the jury, has not relinquished the right to counsel and there is no need for the court to inquire further. People v. Cabassa, 79 N.Y.2d 722, 586 N.Y.S.2d 234, 598 N.E.2d 1 (1992); People v. Timmons, 199 A.D.2d 8, 604 N.Y.S.2d 99 (1st Dep’t 1993).

          

     A defendant’s request to proceed that is made in the alternative, e.g., along with having another attorney appointed, is improper. People v. Gillian, 8 N.Y.3d 85, 828 N.Y.S.2d 277, 861 N.E.2d 92 (2006); People v. Littlejohn, 92 A.D.3d 898, 939 N.Y.S.2d 118 (2d Dep’t 2012).

          

     Although requests to proceed pro se, made on the eve of trial, are discouraged, the trial judge erred in denying the request, when it was made before the prosecutor’s opening statement. People v. Smith, 134 A.D.3d 1568, 22 N.Y.S.3d 783 (4th Dep’t 2015); People v. Crespo, 144 A.D.3d 461, 40 N.Y.S.3d 423 (1st Dep’t 2016).

          

         • The defendant must make a knowing and intelligent waiver of the right to counsel. People v. Schoolfield, 196 A.D.2d 111, 608 N.Y.S.2d 413 (1st Dep’t 1994). A judge’s paternalistic view that defendant would have a better defense with knowledgeable counsel is an improper basis. People v. Tafari, 68 A.D.3d 1540, 891 N.Y.S.2d 711 (3d Dep’t 2009).

         • The defendant must not have engaged in conduct that might prevent an orderly exposition of the issues. A disruptive defendant may forfeit the right to proceed pro se. People v. Glover, 90 A.D.2d 776, 455 N.Y.S.2d 285 (2d Dep’t 1982). But a belated finding that defendant intended to disrupt did not legitimize earlier denials of requests to proceed pro se. People v. Trammell, 183 A.D.3d 155, 123 N.Y.S.3d 1 (1st Dep’t 2020).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:7

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:7. Right to proceed pro se—Mental competency and waiver of counsel

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1975

 

 

A defendant who is found mentally competent to stand trial is competent to waive the right to counsel. Godinez v. Moran, 509 U.S. 389, 113 S. Ct. 2680, 125 L. Ed. 2d 321 (1993); People v. Ferguson, 248 A.D.2d 725, 670 N.Y.S.2d 327 (2d Dep’t 1998); see also People v. Robinson, 69 A.D.3d 973, 891 N.Y.S.2d 752 (3d Dep’t 2010), rev’d on other grounds, 17 N.Y.3d 868, 933 N.Y.S.2d 192, 957 N.E.2d 761 (2011). However, the U.S. Const. Amend VI, allows a state to require counsel to represent a defendant who is competent enough to stand trial, but who suffers from severe mental illness to the point that the defendant is incompetent to represent himself. Indiana v. Edwards, 554 U.S. 164, 128 S. Ct. 2379, 171 L. Ed. 2d 345 (2008).

 

With a pro se litigant, the trial judge is not required to undertake a particularized assessment of mental capacity. People v. Stone, 22 N.Y.3d 520, 983 N.Y.S.2d 454, 6 N.E.3d 572 (2014). A competency examination is not required. People v. Nadler, 164 A.D.3d 1263, 82 N.Y.S.3d 528 (2d Dep’t 2018).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:8

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:8. Right to proceed pro se—Effect on ineffective assistance of counsel claim

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1975

 

 

A defendant who proceeds pro se may not thereafter claim ineffective assistance of counsel, so long as the judge has properly advised the defendant of the risks of self-representation. People v. Pickens, 229 A.D.2d 607, 645 N.Y.S.2d 559 (3d Dep’t 1996); People v. Marshall, 249 A.D.2d 785, 671 N.Y.S.2d 858 (3d Dep’t 1998); People v. Hodge, 255 A.D.2d 943, 681 N.Y.S.2d 718 (4th Dep’t 1998); People v. Duffy, 299 A.D.2d 914, 750 N.Y.S.2d 228 (4th Dep’t 2002).

 

Example:

Where the defendant was improperly allowed to represent himself in the pretrial stages of a case, the error was not harmless and was of constitutional dimension. The defense was impaired to a significant extent. The defendant was ordered restored to his status immediately postindictment, with leave to serve motions, discovery and notices, so as to place him in a position comparable to what he would have occupied. People v. Lott, 23 A.D.3d 1088, 804 N.Y.S.2d 881 (4th Dep’t 2005).

 

Defendant, denied new counsel, waived his right to effective assistance of counsel by directing his attorney to not participate in trial. People v. Lewis, 2024 WL 2985932 (N.Y. App. Div. 4th Dep’t 2024).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:9

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:9. Right to proceed pro se—Duty to advise of risks; hearing

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1975

 

 

The court must make a “searching inquiry” so as to advise the defendant of the risks of self-representation. People v Holmes, 40 NY3d 147, 195 NYS3d 657, 217 NE3d 677 (2023); People v. Baines, 39 N.Y.3d 1, 176 N.Y.S.3d 843, 197 N.E.3d 1282 (2022). No searching inquiry is required where the defendant has “hybrid” representation. See § 2:11, No right to “hybrid” representation. The waiver must be knowing, voluntary and intelligent. People v. Crampe, 17 N.Y.3d 469, 932 N.Y.S.2d 765, 957 N.E.2d 255 (2011); People v. Arroyo, 98 N.Y.2d 101, 745 N.Y.S.2d 796, 772 N.E.2d 1154 (2002); People v. Smith, 92 N.Y.2d 516, 683 N.Y.S.2d 164, 705 N.E.2d 1205 (1998); People v. Providence, 2 N.Y.3d 579, 780 N.Y.S.2d 552, 813 N.E.2d 632 (2004). Compare People v. Herbin, 161 A.D.3d 672, 78 N.Y.S.3d 110 (1st Dep’t 2018) with People v. Ball, 162 A.D.3d 680, 78 N.Y.S.3d 225 (2d Dep’t 2018).

 

Example:

Judge’s failure to disclose maximum sentences did not invalidate waiver of counsel. People v. Rogers, 186 A.D.3d 1046, 129 N.Y.S.3d 227 (4th Dep’t 2020).

 

The following were found insufficient:

 

While advising defendant that it would be extraordinarily dangerous to proceed without counsel, the judge did not advise of the importance of the attorney’s role nor of the dangers and disadvantages of self-representation. The waiver was not knowing and voluntary. People v. Rafikian, 98 A.D.3d 1139, 951 N.Y.S.2d 226 (2d Dep’t 2012).

 

The sentencing judge erred by denying, without inquiry, defendant’s request to represent himself at sentencing. People v. Lewis, 114 A.D.3d 402, 980 N.Y.S.2d 389 (1st Dep’t 2014).

 

The court may properly question the defendant regarding age, education, occupation, and previous involvement with the legal system. People v. McIntyre, 36 N.Y.2d 10, 364 N.Y.S.2d 837, 324 N.E.2d 322 (1974).

 

A defendant’s lack of knowledge of legal principles and rules of law is not a proper ground for denying pro se representation. People v. Ryan, 82 N.Y.2d 497, 605 N.Y.S.2d 235, 626 N.E.2d 51 (1993); People v. Coleman, 210 A.D.2d 977, 621 N.Y.S.2d 244 (4th Dep’t 1994).

 

A defendant who refuses self-representation but restricts the participation of counsel will be found to have waived the right to counsel. People v. Henriquez, 3 N.Y.3d 210, 785 N.Y.S.2d 384, 818 N.E.2d 1125 (2004). In addressing a request to proceed pro se, the court need not address whether new counsel should be appointed. People v. Crooks, 95 A.D.3d 417, 943 N.Y.S.2d 90 (1st Dep’t 2012).

 

A defendant’s egregious misconduct may forfeit the right to counsel. See People v. Smith, 92 N.Y.2d 516, 683 N.Y.S.2d 164, 705 N.E.2d 1205 (1998); People v. Williams, 101 A.D.3d 1730, 957 N.Y.S.2d 548 (4th Dep’t 2012). Cf. People v. Shanks, 37 N.Y.3d 244, 154 N.Y.S.3d 646, 176 N.E.3d 682 (2021).

 

But rejecting repeated attorneys may be justified, both where defendant has made his position of self-representation clear, and where the defense counsel’s conduct was deficient. See People v. Trammell, 183 A.D.3d 155, 123 N.Y.S.3d 1 (1st Dep’t 2020).

 

Denial of defendant’s request to proceed pro se without a hearing is error. People v. Smith, 68 N.Y.2d 737, 506 N.Y.S.2d 322, 497 N.E.2d 689 (1986); People v. Youngblood, 225 A.D.2d 346, 638 N.Y.S.2d 658 (1st Dep’t 1996).

 

For a sample colloquy, see Bench Book for Trial Judges, § 10:1.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:10

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:10. Right to proceed pro se—When pro se representation is approved

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1975

 

 

If the request to proceed pro se is approved, the defendant may represent her/himself and is entitled, for example, to attend sidebar conferences. See People v. Rosen, 81 N.Y.2d 237, 597 N.Y.S.2d 914, 613 N.E.2d 946 (1993); see §§ 19:11 et seq., Defendant’s right to be present. The court may limit questioning where a pro se defendant engages in improper activity at trial. People v. Allah, 254 A.D.2d 186, 680 N.Y.S.2d 211 (1st Dep’t 1998). Cf. People v. Hall, 49 A.D.3d 1180, 856 N.Y.S.2d 360 (4th Dep’t 2008). If the defendant engages in misconduct during trial, the court may assign counsel. ABA Standards for Criminal Justice 6-3.9.

 

Once trial starts, the right to proceed pro se is severely limited, and granted only in the most compelling circumstances. People v. Morales, 12 A.D.3d 1126, 785 N.Y.S.2d 241 (4th Dep’t 2004); People v. Race, 78 A.D.3d 1217, 910 N.Y.S.2d 271 (3d Dep’t 2010).

 

Example:

Defendant represented herself but absented herself from trial, contending that she did not recognize the court’s authority, and refused to abide by the court’s rules. The judge did not terminate her pro se status or appoint standby counsel. While no one was present in the courtroom to represent her during the prosecution’s case, the right to counsel was not violated by the defendant’s voluntary absence. Clark v. Perez, 510 F.3d 382 (2d Cir. 2008).

 

The better course may be for the judge to have available assigned counsel to represent a pro se defendant who is excluded from the courtroom. See Davis v. Grant, 532 F.3d 132 (2d Cir. 2008).

 

Practice Tip:

Is a pro se defendant entitled to personally cross-examine the victim? In a civil management context, the victim’s right was greater. See State v. John T., 195 A.D.3d 102, 146 N.Y.S.3d 352 (3d Dep’t 2021).

 

A pro se defendant must be allowed to make arguments of law and address the court at appropriate points in the trial. But not every interaction is a material stage or critical stage that requires defendant’s presence. People v. Williams, 208 A.D.3d 65, 171 N.Y.S.3d 10 (1st Dep’t 2022), leave to appeal denied, 38 N.Y.3d 1191, 176 N.Y.S.3d 222, 197 N.E.3d 502 (2022).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:11

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:11. Right to proceed pro se—No right to “hybrid” representation

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1975

 

 

There is no right to “hybrid” representation—that is, to both have an attorney and also proceed pro se. People v. Rodriguez, 95 N.Y.2d 497, 719 N.Y.S.2d 208, 741 N.E.2d 882 (2000). It is within a court’s sound discretion whether to allow this. People v. Ferguson, 67 N.Y.2d 383, 502 N.Y.S.2d 972, 494 N.E.2d 77 (1986); People v. Simmons, 155 A.D.3d 782, 64 N.Y.S.3d 79 (2d Dep’t 2017).

 

With hybrid representation, the judge has discretion whether to entertain pro se motions. People v. Johnson, 195 A.D.3d 1422, 147 N.Y.S.3d 862 (4th Dep’t 2021).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:12

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:12. Right to proceed pro se—Standby counsel at court’s discretion

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1975

 

 

A judge may assign “standby counsel” to assist a pro se defendant, but this is a matter of the trial judge’s discretion. People v. Mirenda, 57 N.Y.2d 261, 455 N.Y.S.2d 752, 442 N.E.2d 49 (1982); People v. Silburn, 31 N.Y.3d 144, 74 N.Y.S.3d 781, 98 N.E.3d 696 (2018); ABA Standards for Criminal Justice 6-3.7. The court may limit the role of standby counsel. People v. Hilts, 46 A.D.3d 947, 846 N.Y.S.2d 750 (3d Dep’t 2007), aff’d, 13 N.Y.3d 895, 895 N.Y.S.2d 286, 922 N.E.2d 872 (2009).

 

The state and federal constitutions allow the right to counsel or to self-representation, but they do not guarantee a right to both. A pro se defendant is not guaranteed the assistance of standby counsel during trial. People v. Roberts, 213 A.D.3d 1348, 183 N.Y.S.3d 224 (4th Dep’t 2023).

 

Once assigned, however, this attorney will not be removed except for good cause shown. People v. Outlaw, 184 A.D.2d 665, 584 N.Y.S.2d 870 (2d Dep’t 1992).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:13

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:13. Right to proceed pro se—Pro se motion

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1975

 

 

When a defendant has counsel but chooses to make a pro se motion, the court has discretion whether to entertain the motion. People v. Session, 206 A.D.3d 1678, 169 N.Y.S.3d 760 (4th Dep’t 2022). The better practice is for the judge to inquire whether defense counsel is aware of the motion and discussed it with the client. People v. Rodriguez, 95 N.Y.2d 497, 719 N.Y.S.2d 208, 741 N.E.2d 882 (2000). It is improper to refuse to consider any pro se motion. People v. Delgado, 281 A.D.2d 556, 723 N.Y.S.2d 40 (2d Dep’t 2001).

 

Defense counsel does not necessarily commit ineffective assistance by failing to assert a motion made by the defendant. People v. Miles, 8 A.D.3d 758, 779 N.Y.S.2d 592 (3d Dep’t 2004).

 

Example:

The court erred in denying, without a hearing, a pro se motion to dismiss the indictment that was based on the ground that the People had violated a cooperation agreement, where defendant produced evidence of the existence of the agreement, and the ADA’s bald assertion in opposition was not based on personal knowledge. People v. Jairam, 10 A.D.3d 455, 781 N.Y.S.2d 161 (2d Dep’t 2004).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:14

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:14. Right to proceed pro se—On appeal

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1975

 

 

An appellate defendant is entitled to counsel. The appellant may also file a pro se supplemental brief, but does not have an absolute right to do so. People v. Barber, 74 N.Y.2d 653, 543 N.Y.S.2d 365, 541 N.E.2d 394 (1989). See § 24:38, Pro se submissions: supplemental brief.

 

As at the trial level, it is the trained defense attorney who guides the selection of issues to be raised and how those issues will be framed before the appellate court. Jones v. Barnes, 463 U.S. 745, 103 S. Ct. 3308, 77 L. Ed. 2d 987 (1983). There is no constitutional right to represent oneself on appeal. Martinez v. Court of Appeal of California, Fourth Appellate Dist., 528 U.S. 152, 120 S. Ct. 684, 145 L. Ed. 2d 597 (2000). See § 24:98, Effective assistance of counsel on appeal.

 

The Baldi standard—“meaningful representation”—is used to evaluate effectiveness of appellate counsel. People v. Stultz, 2 N.Y.3d 277, 778 N.Y.S.2d 431, 810 N.E.2d 883 (2004). See § 2:69, Effective/ineffective assistance of counsel.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:15

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:15. Choosing counsel

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1820

 

 

A defendant who can afford to retain an attorney is constitutionally entitled to one of his/her own choosing. U.S. Const. Amend. VI; N.Y. Const. Art. I, § 6; People v. Limongelli, 156 A.D.2d 473, 548 N.Y.S.2d 759 (2d Dep’t 1989). The right to choice of counsel is different from the right to effective counsel. The erroneous denial of counsel of one’s choice has been found, in federal court proceedings, to be “structural error.” With wrongful denial of representation by counsel of one’s choice, it is unnecessary to conduct an ineffectiveness or prejudice inquiry. U.S. v. Gonzalez-Lopez, 548 U.S. 140, 126 S. Ct. 2557, 165 L. Ed. 2d 409, 33 A.L.R. Fed. 2d 661 (2006). Delaying the substitution of counsel is error. People v. Mack, 39 A.D.3d 882, 833 N.Y.S.2d 688 (3d Dep’t 2007).

 

A defendant’s refusal without good cause to accept able appointed counsel is a waiver of the right to counsel. People v. Robinson, 244 A.D.2d 364, 663 N.Y.S.2d 651 (2d Dep’t 1997). Differences over trial tactics do not amount to good cause. People v. Williams, 225 A.D.2d 717, 639 N.Y.S.2d 456 (2d Dep’t 1996). On the other hand, once counsel is assigned, the trial judge may not remove the assigned attorney over defendant’s objection unless findings are spelled out on the record sufficient to justify dismissal. See People v. Espinal, 10 A.D.3d 326, 781 N.Y.S.2d 99 (1st Dep’t 2004); People v. Griffin, 20 N.Y.3d 626, 964 N.Y.S.2d 505, 987 N.E.2d 282 (2013). See § 2:58, Removal of attorney by court.

 

More than one attorney may represent a defendant at a trial, handling various tasks. The trial judge has discretion to impose reasonable restrictions to ensure the orderly conduct of proceedings. People v. Knowles, 88 N.Y.2d 763, 650 N.Y.S.2d 617, 673 N.E.2d 902 (1996); People v. Seabrook, 241 A.D.2d 325, 659 N.Y.S.2d 463 (1st Dep’t 1997).

 

The defendant may be granted an adjournment to obtain counsel, CPL 170.10(3)(a); CPL 180.10(3)(a); see People v. Arroyave, 49 N.Y.2d 264, 425 N.Y.S.2d 282, 401 N.E.2d 393 (1980), but there are limits, and an “eleventh hour” change may be refused. People v. Terry, 115 A.D.2d 130, 496 N.Y.S.2d 93 (3d Dep’t 1985). Cf. People v. Rohadfox, 114 A.D.3d 1217, 979 N.Y.S.2d 758 (4th Dep’t 2014). Denial of adjournment to obtain new retained counsel was, under the circumstances, an abuse of discretion as a matter of law.

 

Where assigned counsel is needed, the attorney will typically be chosen from the county’s assigned counsel panel either by the judge or the panel administrator. But a defendant is not entitled to one’s choice of attorney. And a litigant’s refusal to work with a series of attorneys may effectively exhaust the right to counsel. See In re Micah T., 171 A.D.3d 546, 98 N.Y.S.3d 167 (1st Dep’t 2019).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:16

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:16. Choosing counsel—Assignment

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1820

 

 

An indigent defendant who qualifies for court-assigned counsel does not have the right to select which lawyer will be assigned. People v. Porto, 16 N.Y.3d 93, 917 N.Y.S.2d 74, 942 N.E.2d 283 (2010). There is no right to appointment of successive lawyers at defendant’s option. People v. Fulgencio, 168 A.D.3d 1094, 92 N.Y.S.3d 370 (2d Dep’t 2019). See also People v. Linares, 2 N.Y.3d 507, 780 N.Y.S.2d 529, 813 N.E.2d 609 (2004).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:17

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

I. Assistance of Counsel, Generally

§ 2:17. Choosing counsel—Assignment—New assignment

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1820

 

 

Although there is no entitlement to a succession of lawyers, a defendant may be assigned new counsel for good cause, such as a conflict of interest or irreconcilable difference between attorney and client. “The right of an indigent criminal defendant to the services of a court-appointed lawyer does not encompass a right to appointment of successive lawyers at defendant’s option.” People v. Washington, 25 N.Y.3d 1091, 13 N.Y.S.3d 343, 34 N.E.3d 853 (2015); People v. Graham, 188 A.D.3d 909, 135 N.Y.S.3d 410 (2d Dep’t 2020).

 

Forfeiture of the right to counsel is an extreme, last-resort finding. People v. Issac, 121 A.D.3d 816, 994 N.Y.S.2d 177 (2d Dep’t 2014).

 

Example:

At sentencing, the defendant sought to withdraw his guilty plea and replace the assigned counsel who had represented him at the plea proceeding. The grounds given by the defendant were that he was innocent and had been coerced into the plea by the assigned attorney. The defendant attempted to submit an affidavit with his application, but the court summarily refused to consider any applications. This was improper: the sentencing court should have inquired into the allegations and allowed defendant an opportunity to set forth his contentions. People v. Brown, 205 A.D.2d 436, 613 N.Y.S.2d 903 (1st Dep’t 1994).

 

Even minimal inquiry is not required, however, where the defendant’s request is based on conclusory assertions that do not suggest a serious possibility of good cause for substitution. People v. Frayer, 215 A.D.2d 862, 627 N.Y.S.2d 107 (3d Dep’t 1995).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:18

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:18. Retention and assignment

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1720

 

 

More and more, the practice of criminal law is becoming an area of poverty law. Because most criminal defendants cannot afford to retain a private lawyer, one must be assigned.

 

In determining whether a person is unable to afford the services of an attorney, it is improper to “impute” income. See Carney v. Carney, 160 A.D.3d 218, 73 N.Y.S.3d 694 (4th Dep’t 2018) (eligibility in civil contempt proceeding).

 

See § 2:113 for Form—Defendant’s financial statement.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:19

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:19. Eligibility standards

Correlation Table

The Office of Indigent Legal Services has promulgated eligibility standards for lower-income defendants, guidance on assigning counsel. For 2024, those standards are:

 

Number of dependents (including applicant): 1—$37,650; 2—$51,100; 3—$64,550.

 

See https://www.ils.ny.gov/files/2024%20FPG%20Income%20Eligibility%20Chart.pdf.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:20

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:20. The assigned counsel system: 18-B

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

Pursuant to County Law Article 18-B, each county in New York State must provide counsel for indigents. A county may provide the attorney, or contract out the service. Low-income criminal defendants are represented by a Legal Aid Society or a Public Defender Office or Conflict Defender Office; of special importance in smaller counties that do not have Legal Aid or a Public Defender, there is an assigned counsel “panel” of private attorneys. An assigned counsel panel exists in all counties.

 

The private attorney is assigned where there is a conflict of interest. County Law § 722(4); Legal Aid Soc. of Orange County, Inc. v. Patsalos, 185 A.D.2d 926, 587 N.Y.S.2d 943 (2d Dep’t 1992). This can occur, for example, where a codefendant is represented by the Legal Aid Society or Public Defender.

 

A court has inherent power to assign an attorney, including one not on the assigned counsel list, for an indigent defendant. Smith v. Tormey, 19 N.Y.3d 533, 951 N.Y.S.2d 89, 975 N.E.2d 470 (2012).

 

In most cases, one attorney is assigned to represent the defendant. In significantly complex cases, a judge may appoint additional counsel.

 

Practice Tip:

Some counties have their own assigned counsel administrator, and may have particular rules regarding assignment of counsel. These may include minimum experience to be eligible for cases, continuing legal education, and residency requirements.

 

For attorneys in New York City, there is a limit on the number of cases that an 18-B attorney can be assigned in a calendar year. 22 NYCRR § 127.7(a).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:21

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:21. The assigned counsel system: 18-B—Types of representation

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

Assigned counsel are not confined to representing defendants on criminal charges. A judge may assign counsel to represent a witness. CPL 190.52, 620.40; see People v. Siegel, 87 N.Y.2d 536, 640 N.Y.S.2d 831, 663 N.E.2d 872 (1995). Other matters may include mental health and federal criminal cases. In Family Court, an indigent is entitled to representation in a variety of cases, such as neglect, abuse, and custody. Fam Ct Act § 262. Where a defendant is charged with contempt of court, counsel should be appointed. Jud Law § 770; Family Court Act § 262; Gifford v. Gifford, 223 A.D.2d 669, 637 N.Y.S.2d 430 (2d Dep’t 1996). Attorneys may act as an attorney for the child (formerly “law guardian”), representing juveniles in delinquency, neglect, and custody proceedings, among other proceedings.

 

A court also has authority to appoint counsel in:

         • a probation violation proceeding, see § 22:55, Violation of probation.

         • a postconviction CPL 440.10 proceeding. County Law § 722(4); People v. Monahan, 17 N.Y.2d 310, 270 N.Y.S.2d 613, 217 N.E.2d 664 (1966); see § 24:54, Assigned counsel continues.

         • resentencing under the Drug Law Reform Act. See § 22:186, Drug Law Reform Acts.

         • a proceeding under the Sex Offender Registration Act. Corr L § 168-n(3). See § 23:98, Defendant’s rights.

         • a civil management proceeding, see §§ 23:105 et seq., Civil management for sex offenders.

         • a habeas corpus proceeding, for a person detained in a state facility, when a hearing is ordered. Jud L § 35. See § 23:26, Right to counsel.

         • ERPO proceedings. See § 23:154, ERPO statute.

         • other proceedings. See SCPA 407(1)(a).

 

Practice Tip:

The county paying the attorney for assigned counsel work may decline to compensate for work performed beyond the scope of the original assignment—for example, representing the defendant on an additional charge. Accordingly, counsel should seek formal assignment from a judge before venturing into a new proceeding.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:22

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:22. The assigned counsel system: 18-B—Role of trial judge in compensation

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

The assigned attorney is paid $158 per hour for felony or misdemeanor cases.

 

If the attorney was assigned when the case was a felony and is reduced, the attorney is compensated at the higher rate throughout: the statute does not penalize the attorney or create a disincentive for obtaining a reduction in the charges.

 

Practice Tip:

Some judges require assigned attorneys to submit vouchers within a certain time period after the case ends. Where compensation is made by the state, regulations require submission of vouchers within 45 days. 22 NYCRR § 127.1(b). However, the attorney may apply for compensation any time within the applicable statute of limitations. See Benatovich v. Koessler, 231 A.D.2d 880, 647 N.Y.S.2d 880 (4th Dep’t 1996).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:23

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:23. The assigned counsel system: 18-B—Role of trial judge in compensation—Review of assigned counsel award

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

The trial judge’s decision on payment for an assigned attorney is subject to reconsideration by any person or governmental body affected by an order of enhanced compensation. The trial judge, in consultation with the administrative judge, is to reconsider the determination. 22 NYCRR § 127.2(b). Whether or not an application for reconsideration has been filed, the administrative judge may modify the fee award if it is an abuse of discretion. This administrative method has been found constitutional. Levenson v. Lippman, 4 N.Y.3d 280, 794 N.Y.S.2d 276, 827 N.E.2d 259 (2005).

 

An assigned counsel plan may properly allow for preliminary review and recommendation of a voucher before it is submitted to the trial judge. Roulan v. County of Onondaga, 21 N.Y.3d 902, 966 N.Y.S.2d 744, 989 N.E.2d 6 (2013). A judge may approve a voucher that is not in compliance with an assigned counsel plan. County of Onondaga v. Brunetti, 108 A.D.3d 1138, 970 N.Y.S.2d 150 (4th Dep’t 2013).

 

The statute itself provides that the trial judge determines the requested compensation. County Law § 722-c.

 

An appeal by the attorney to the appropriate administrative judge has been found appropriate. Werfel v. Agresta, 36 N.Y.2d 624, 370 N.Y.S.2d 881, 331 N.E.2d 668 (1975). Caselaw has held that governmental bodies have no standing to contest the fee award. Matter of Director of Assigned Counsel Plan of City of New York, 87 N.Y.2d 191, 638 N.Y.S.2d 415, 661 N.E.2d 988 (1995); People v. Ward, 199 A.D.2d 683, 605 N.Y.S.2d 152 (3d Dep’t 1993).

 

The administrative judge may review the amount of compensation, but may not decide whether the trial judge lacked authority to award fees to the attorney. An order of assignment is reviewable via an Article 78 proceeding. Smith v. Tormey, 19 N.Y.3d 533, 951 N.Y.S.2d 89, 975 N.E.2d 470 (2012).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:24

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:24. The assigned counsel system: 18-B—Role of trial judge in compensation—”Extraordinary circumstances”

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

Payment beyond the maximum is permitted where “extraordinary circumstances” exist, a concept that is difficult to define and varies with each case. Judiciary Law § 35; County Law § 722-b; 22 NYCRR Part 127.

 

Time spent does not alone constitute an extraordinary circumstance. See 22 NYCRR § 1015.9. See People v. Perry, 27 A.D.2d 154, 278 N.Y.S.2d 323 (Sup 1967).

 

The state rates were changed effective April 1, 2023.

 

Practice Tip:

The statutory amounts refer to attorney’s fees, rather than the disbursements. Thus, where the cap is $10,000 and the amount of attorney’s fees is $9,980 with $50 disbursements, an affidavit of excessiveness is not necessary.

 

Where the amount of attorney time exceeds the cap only slightly, counsel may prefer to submit a voucher for the cap amount only, rather than dealing with an excessiveness affidavit and the delay.

In submitting a request for payment above the maximum, counsel should supply an affidavit of activities and time expended, and the court must certify that the circumstances are unusual or extraordinary. 22 NYCRR § 606.2(a), (b) (1st Dept); 22 NYCRR § 691.16 (2d Dept); 22 NYCRR § 822.4(b) (3d Dept); 22 NYCRR § 1015.9 (4th Dept).

 

See § 2:116 for Form—Application in support of excess compensation.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:25

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:25. The assigned counsel system: 18-B—Resolving billing issues

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

In the absence of a local county rule, assigned counsel may use the following guidelines in applying for compensation.

 

Counsel should bill for a pro rata share of time expended on each case. Total time billed should equal total time actually expended. Matter of Stern, 90 A.D.2d 338, 457 N.Y.S.2d 67 (1st Dep’t 1982).

 

Only time reasonably and necessarily spent on assigned matters should be included in the voucher; allocation of total time must be fair and reasonable. Matter of Stern, supra; Lillian Goldman Family, LLC v. New York State Div. of Housing and Community Renewal, 12 A.D.3d 161, 783 N.Y.S.2d 471 (1st Dep’t 2004).

 

Travel time may be properly allocated when more than one matter is involved. See County Law § 722-b; Matter of Stern, above.

 

An assigned attorney may not receive compensation from the defendant or anyone else without a court order. 22 NYCRR 603.30.

 

Where a judge learns that an attorney may have improperly been paid by defendant’s family, there is a duty to inquire. See People v. Jackson, 217 A.D.3d 1530, 192 N.Y.S.3d 837 (4th Dept 2023).

 

Example:

Overbilling and filing false entry in business records for assigned counsel, and guilty plea to misdemeanor, resulted in suspension for three months. Micale v. Grievance Committee of Fifth Judicial District, 217 A.D.3d 8, 190 N.Y.S.3d 571 (4th Dept 2023).

 

Provided that supervision by the assigned attorney is maintained, the assigned attorney may submit a voucher for work performed by another, stating the name of the other attorney and the nature of the services performed.

 

Practice Tip:

There can be pitfalls if court approval is not obtained in advance. One court denied 18-B compensation for services rendered by an attorney other than the one assigned. See People v. Elliot, 98 Misc. 2d 424, 413 N.Y.S.2d 1001 (Sup 1979).

 

Assigned counsel may be reimbursed for such items as postage, long-distance telephone calls, photocopying, and subpoena fees. Rates may vary from county to county. County Law § 722-b.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:26

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:26. Investigative and expert services

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

The law provides for obtaining services of those who are needed to assist in preparing a defense—e.g., an expert witness, interpreter, handwriting expert, forensic chemist, psychiatrist, ballistics expert, investigator, or other auxiliary defense services, such as the cost of transporting witnesses. County Law § 722-c. The maximum is now $3,000.

 

Practice Tip:

Defense counsel should not rely on an investigator alone; it is good practice to view the scene, meet with potential witnesses and follow up on leads personally.

 

A map of the area may be helpful at trial. However, visiting the crime scene allows the attorney to determine, for example, whether a street is one-way, what the sight lines are, where street lights or other light sources are located (e.g., alternating or all on the same side of the street), and whether those lights are functioning. Also, whether there any public or private surveillance cameras. The prosecuting attorney should visit the crime scene as well. During trial the court may permit the jury to view the scene. CPL 270.50.

 

Particularly in the early stages of some complex cases, what may be needed is not so much an expert witness, but a background expert to advise defense counsel on whether and how to proceed. If the case is set for trial, a more credentialed expert may be needed to testify as an expert witness.

 

To ensure that communication with the investigator or others remains privileged, this should be set forth in the representation agreement. U.S. v. Kovel, 296 F.2d 918, 62-1 U.S. Tax Cas. (CCH) P 9111, 9 A.F.T.R.2d 366, 96 A.L.R.2d 116 (2d Cir. 1961).

 

See § 2:117 for Form—Letter from attorney to investigator.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:27

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:27. Investigative and expert services—Transcripts

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

Assigned defense counsel may also obtain transcripts, paid for by the county.

 

Even if retained, such as by relatives, the county may be required to pay for transcripts, if the defendant himself is indigent. People v. Ulloa, 1 A.D.3d 468, 766 N.Y.S.2d 699 (2d Dep’t 2003). See § 24:28, Cost of transcripts.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:28

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:28. Investigative and expert services—Financial need essential but approval discretionary

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

The statute applies to “counsel, whether or not assigned in accordance with a plan,” and the test for eligibility is that the defendant must be “financially unable to obtain” the services. County Law § 722-c. A defendant with retained counsel may have an investigator paid via 722-c order. See People v. Hatterson, 63 A.D.2d 736, 405 N.Y.S.2d 297 (2d Dep’t 1978); People v. Smith, 114 Misc. 2d 258, 451 N.Y.S.2d 549 (County Ct. 1982); Fullan v. Commissioner of Corrections of State of N.Y., 891 F.2d 1007 (2d Cir. 1989).

 

The trial judge may, but is not required, to approve any particular application for services. People v. Lane, 195 A.D.2d 876, 600 N.Y.S.2d 848 (3d Dep’t 1993); People v. Rockwell, 18 A.D.3d 969, 794 N.Y.S.2d 726 (3d Dep’t 2005). The defendant must show indigency, that the service is necessary to the defense, and if compensation sought exceeds the amount set by statute, extraordinary circumstances to justify the expenditure. People v. Weaver, 167 A.D.3d 1238, 90 N.Y.S.3d 359 (3d Dep’t 2018).

 

The failure to apply for investigative or expert services, whether funded by the county or privately, may constitute ineffective assistance. See § 2:81, Expert witness.

 

Failure to apply for expert services on the mistaken belief that they were unavailable may constitute ineffective assistance. See § 2:79, Failure to investigate.

 

Example:

Request for an additional $1,000 for investigative services in a robbery case was denied, where defendant failed to make the showing to justify additional funds. People v. Johnson, 202 A.D.3d 1471, 162 N.Y.S.3d 624 (4th Dep’t 2022).

 

Defendant did not establish a distinct necessity for expert witness to testify about best practices when conducting forensic interviews of children. People v. Wells, 224 A.D.3d 1155, 207 N.Y.S.3d 699 (3d Dep’t 2024).

 

Denying $1,800 in expert witness fees on ground that defendant had a retained attorney was error. People v. Osman, 213 A.D.3d 1256, 184 N.Y.S.3d 249 (4th Dep’t 2023).

 

Practice Tip:

Assigned counsel, rather than applying to the judge for additional services, should check with their county’s assigned counsel program to see if funding is available.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:29

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:29. Investigative and expert services—Payment

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

The statutory maximum for investigative services is $3,000, unless “extraordinary circumstances” are found. County Law § 722-c; see People v. Tyson, 209 A.D.2d 354, 618 N.Y.S.2d 796 (1st Dep’t 1994).

 

Assignment of and compensation of counsel, psychiatrist, psychologist, doctor, and social worker are addressed by court rule. 22 NYCRR Part 127. Rules in the First and Second Departments address compensation of mental health professionals. 22 NYCRR Part 623 (First Dept), Part 680 (Second Dept).

 

The hourly compensation rate under the Judiciary Law § 35 for non-lawyer professionals, as set by the Administrative Board (5/1/2024) is:

 

Psychiatrist and physician

 

$400

 

Certified psychologist

 

$300

 

Certified social worker

 

$100

 

Licensed investigator

 

$90

 

 

 

With Mental Hygiene Law article 10 cases, compensation for psychiatric examiners is $250 per hour, with travel reimbursed at $100 per hour. See MHL § 10.15(a).

 

Practice Tip:

The hourly rate for other experts, as opposed to the total maximum, is not set by statute. As a result, case-by-case review is the rule.

 

Payment of $100 per hour to a certified social worker has been approved. Matter of Director of Assigned Counsel Plan of City of New York, 87 N.Y.2d 191, 638 N.Y.S.2d 415, 661 N.E.2d 988 (1995).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:30

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:30. Investigative and expert services—Motion

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

An application for an investigator may be made as part of the omnibus motion, or ex parte. Either way, the motion should detail the defendant’s financial need. See People v. Jackson, 80 Misc. 2d 595, 363 N.Y.S.2d 288 (County Ct. 1975).

 

Practice Tip:

An ex parte application is preferable if the defense attorney does not want the prosecutor to know of defense strategy. The statute itself provides that the application can be made ex parte. Defense counsel can also request that the application and order be sealed.

 

Once the order is signed, the person hired should be given a copy. After services have been rendered, the person should submit the original or a certified copy with the claim voucher to the county.

 

The request for a 722-c order should be made early on in the case. Where a felony case is pending in local court, counsel should make an application to the local court judge. After the initial sum is exhausted, an additional application may be necessary.

 

See § 2:118 for Form—Application for and order authorizing investigative services.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:31

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:31. Investigative and expert services—Appeal

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

A guilty plea waives the issue of the court’s denial of an expert for the defense. People v. Simcox, 219 A.D.2d 869, 631 N.Y.S.2d 956 (4th Dep’t 1995). See § 17:79, Issues waived by plea. Although the application is directed to the court’s discretion, refusing to approve the employment of an expert may be an issue on appeal after trial. See § 2:81, Expert witness. If an abuse of discretion is found, reversal may result. Cf. Johnson v. Harris, 682 F.2d 49 (2d Cir. 1982).

 

Examples:

The defendant, charged with murder, sought authorization for neurological testing based on reports that, as a child, he had suffered traumatic head injury that caused permanent brain damage. The defense expert believed that the defendant’s cognitive limitations were a result of brain damage and a long history of alcoholism. The testing was crucial to the defense of justification. Denying the application for authorization was reversible error. People v. Jones, 210 A.D.2d 904, 620 N.Y.S.2d 656 (4th Dep’t 1994), order aff’d, 85 N.Y.2d 998, 630 N.Y.S.2d 961, 654 N.E.2d 1209 (1995); see also Ake v. Oklahoma, 470 U.S. 68, 105 S. Ct. 1087, 84 L. Ed. 2d 53 (1985).

 

Where the court ordered a neurological examination but then moved the case up the calendar, effectively preventing the examination from occurring, error resulted. People v. Daley, 9 A.D.3d 601, 780 N.Y.S.2d 423 (3d Dep’t 2004).

 

Denial of expert services was upheld in the following:

 

Where the defendant sought $1,500 for an expert to testify to the effect of “crack” on the ability to form intent to commit crime, the application was denied. The amount was “exorbitant” and no extraordinary circumstances were shown to exceed the statutory limit. People v. Graves, 238 A.D.2d 754, 656 N.Y.S.2d 490 (3d Dep’t 1997); see also People v. Brand, 13 A.D.3d 820, 787 N.Y.S.2d 169 (3d Dep’t 2004) (additional evaluations and neuropsychologist denied; defendant’s expert witnesses adequately addressed issue of automatism); People v. Pike, 63 A.D.3d 1692, 880 N.Y.S.2d 832 (4th Dep’t 2009) (jury consultant denied in Murder 1st trial).

 

Defendant was not deprived of a fair trial by denial of compensation for an identification expert above the statutory limit. There was corroborating evidence with identification, and an expert in this area would have been of minor importance. People v. Peterkin, 81 A.D.3d 1358, 921 N.Y.S.2d 744 (4th Dep’t 2011). See also People v. Mallayev, 120 A.D.3d 1358, 992 N.Y.S.2d 335 (2d Dep’t 2014) (identification).

 

Defendant’s vague and equivocal representations failed to show either that services were necessary or that he was unable to obtain the services. People v. Ganntt, 159 A.D.3d 986, 73 N.Y.S.3d 620 (2d Dep’t 2018).

 

Failure to craft a proper order for investigative services did not constitute ineffective assistance. See People v. Simpson, 173 A.D.3d 1617, 102 N.Y.S.3d 357 (4th Dep’t 2019).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:32

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:32. Investigative and expert services—Reimbursing county for representation

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

An indigent is entitled to free representation, but a person still may be unable to afford the fees charged by private counsel. In such a situation, the court has discretion to assign an attorney (who will be paid by the county at the presumably lower assigned counsel rates), but with the condition that the defendant pay for it.

 

This may be done at the outset of representation, and the court may terminate the assignment of counsel if the defendant’s finances improve. County Law § 722-d; see People v. Alessi, 154 Misc. 2d 322, 584 N.Y.S.2d 275 (Sup 1992).

 

See § 2:120 for Form—Order for defendant’s payment of legal fees.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:33

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:33. Investigative and expert services—Partial fee agreements

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

A variant of the foregoing is a partial fee agreement. If a defendant cannot afford to retain counsel, but is above the maximum income levels that permit the assignment of counsel, this may be the resolution.

 

The agreement is a contract between the defendant, or a person willing to partially fund the defendant’s representation, and the assigned counsel office to the effect that a fee certain, within the means of the obligor, will be paid directly to the attorney, usually at the first or second meeting. The remainder of the attorney’s fee is paid by the county.

 

Court approval of any such arrangement is essential, and counsel should always be familiar with local practice. See, e.g., 22 NYCRR §§ 691.16, 1022.12 et seq. It may be improper for an assigned attorney to afterward accept a retainer on that or any other case the defendant is involved in. 22 NYCRR §§ 603.19 (First Department), 691.16 (Second Department), and 1022.12(a) (Fourth Department).

 

An attorney who is compensated by a client and also submits a voucher may face criminal prosecution. See People v. Tirelli, 156 A.D.2d 738, 549 N.Y.S.2d 489 (2d Dep’t 1989).

 

Where a client runs out of funds, the court may not allow the attorney to then receive public compensation for further representation. Compare People v. Berkowitz, 97 Misc. 2d 277, 411 N.Y.S.2d 164 (Sup 1978) with People v. Ward, 199 A.D.2d 683, 605 N.Y.S.2d 152 (3d Dep’t 1993).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:34

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:34. Investigative and expert services—Parent’s obligation

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1974

 

 

Consistent with the general obligation to provide support, the parent of a defendant who is under age 21 must obtain legal representation for the minor. The criminal court may lack jurisdiction over the parents, but if they are of sufficient means and refuse to pay for a defense, the county may pursue them for the cost of assigned counsel. Fam Ct Act § 413; see People v. Clemson, 149 Misc. 2d 868, 567 N.Y.S.2d 591 (J. Ct. 1991); Matter of Cheri H, 121 Misc. 2d 973, 469 N.Y.S.2d 551 (Fam. Ct. 1983).

 

Practice Tip:

When parents have refused to pay for legal representation for a minor child and thus an attorney is assigned, the court usually determines the fair value of the legal services rendered and grants an order for that amount. The county thereafter brings an action for a money judgment against the parents.

 

Defenses raised to such a proceeding may include lack of notice of the earlier criminal proceedings, and that the child is “emancipated,” as a result of which the parents are not legally required to provide support.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:35

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:35. The retained attorney: retainer agreement may be required

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1870

 

 

A defendant who is able to do so may hire private counsel.

 

Under court rules it may be necessary in criminal cases to have a written retainer agreement (or “letter of engagement”). This must be provided to the client before beginning representation or within a reasonable time thereafter. Where required, the letter of engagement must contain:

         • an explanation of the scope of legal services to be provided.

         • an explanation of the fees to be charged, expenses, and billing practices.

 

A retainer or letter of engagement is required in civil or criminal cases involving a fee of more than $3,000. 22 NYCRR Part 1215. However, an attorney in a criminal matter is not required to submit to fee arbitration. 22 NYCRR § 137.1(b)(1).

 

An updated letter of engagement must be provided where there is a significant change in the scope of services or the fee to be charged.

 

A letter of engagement is not required where the fee is expected to be under $3,000.

 

Information regarding fee arbitration in civil cases can be found at: http://www.nycourts.gov/admin/feedispute/faqs.shtml#Q1.

 

See § 2:121 for Form—Retainer agreement.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:36

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:36. The retained attorney: retainer or letter of engagement may be required—Assignment of bail as payment

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1870

 

 

Cash that has been posted as bail by the client or by a relative or friend may be used for the retainer, or as security for payment of the fee. The person posting the bail money may need to endorse the bail receipt as payable to the attorney. A notarized statement of the bailor may be appropriate. At the end of the case, the money is remitted. Gen Mun Law § 99-m; cf. Herman v. State, 126 Misc. 2d 1019, 484 N.Y.S.2d 453 (Ct. Cl. 1984).

 

The lawyer is required to file a federal report with a retainer that is secured by bail of $10,000 or more, or cash equivalent.

 

Practice Tip:

Cash that has been posted as bail by the client (as opposed to a friend or relative, unless that person has also agreed to pay the fee) may be used as the retainer. In that situation, the client should turn the bail receipt over to the attorney, endorsing it payable to the attorney. Assuming that bail is not forfeited, or applied to restitution or fine, the attorney may later on turn in the bail receipt to the court to obtain payment. It may be appropriate to file the receipt with the court or department of finance before conclusion of the case. See § 4:75, Return of cash bail.

 

Caution is advised, however. The client may have less of an incentive to appear in court if the bail money is going to the attorney, and the bail receipt will be worthless if the client fails to appear. Moreover, questions of conflict of interest and ethics can arise if the client jumps bail, and if the attorney is discharged, the bail receipt can become a subject of dispute. It may, therefore, be more advisable to use the bail receipt as collateral for another written obligation of the client to pay the attorney. Even in this situation, however, counsel should be alert for possible conflicts and review any applicable statutes, rules, and ethical considerations. In addition to signing the bail receipt, it is advisable to have a retainer or other document that reflects that the work performed by the lawyer is commensurate with the amount of bail posted.

 

Regardless of the form it may take, it is advisable to obtain the retainer in advance of any court appearance. Although many judges will allow defense counsel to withdraw upon the indictment arraignment, the judge will be less likely to allow the attorney to do so afterward. Counsel representing an incarcerated defendant who is unable to pay a retainer at an arraignment may avoid the problem at the outset by either notifying the court that the attorney is appearing “provisionally,” or filing a notice of appearance that specifically states, e.g., “For arraignment purposes only.” The attorney should check in advance with the court to determine whether this practice is acceptable, however.

 

It is inappropriate for a lawyer to loan money to a client to post bail. Hall, Professional Responsibility in Criminal Defense Practice, 4th ed., § 13:26.

 

See § 2:123 for Form—Assignment of bail to attorney.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:37

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:37. The retained attorney: retainer or letter of engagement may be required—Prohibitions regarding fees

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​142.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1870

 

 

Under the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 1.5(d), “A lawyer shall not enter into an arrangement for, charge or collect … (4) a nonrefundable retainer fee. A lawyer may enter into a retainer agreement with a client containing a reasonable minimum fee clause if it defines in plain language and sets forth the circumstances under which such fee may be incurred and how it will be calculated.”

 

A “minimum nonrefundable fee” for representation on a criminal matter is impermissible. Matter of Cooperman, 83 N.Y.2d 465, 611 N.Y.S.2d 465, 633 N.E.2d 1069 (1994). However, it is permissible to have a “minimum fee” arrangement that provides for payment of a specific amount below which the fee will not fall based upon handling the matter to conclusion. See 22 NYCRR § 1400.4.

 

A contingency fee for representation in a criminal case is improper. People v. Winkler, 71 N.Y.2d 592, 528 N.Y.S.2d 360, 523 N.E.2d 485 (1988); RPC 1.5(d)(1).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:38

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:38. The retained attorney: retainer or letter of engagement may be required—Disclosure of fees

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​142.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1870

 

 

The fee arrangement between attorney and client is not a confidential communication. Priest v. Hennessy, 51 N.Y.2d 62, 431 N.Y.S.2d 511, 409 N.E.2d 983 (1980).
