Where an attorney receives more than $10,000 in cash (including cashier’s checks, bank drafts, traveler’s checks and money orders), whether as a retainer or to be held in escrow, the attorney is required to file a disclosure notice. 26 U.S.C.A. §§ 6050I, 7203; Matter of Chung, 230 A.D.2d 300, 656 N.Y.S.2d 250 (1st Dep’t 1997); In re Piemonte, 287 A.D.2d 117, 732 N.Y.S.2d 796 (4th Dep’t 2001); see Annot., 152 A.L.R. Fed. 459. Bail money released to the attorney comes within the reporting requirement as well. See § 2:36, Assignment of bail as payment.

 

Payment by personal check does not have to be reported under Form 8300.

 

Practice Tip:

Where separate payments totaling more than $10,000 are made within a 12-month period, IRS Form 8300 must be filed. The report must be filed within 15 days. Form 8300 is available from http://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/f8300.pdf, or 1-800-829-3676.

 

Intentional failure to report can result in fines of $25,000 and a felony conviction; negligent omission can result in a $50 fine. Accepting the retainer so as to circumvent the reporting requirement can result in a federal criminal charge of “structuring,” 26 U.S.C.A. § 6050I(f). However, it is permissible to accept less than $10,000 in cash, and the balance by personal check.

 

Caution in this area is advised.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:39

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:39. The retained attorney: retainer or letter of engagement may be required—Quantum meruit compensation

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​142.1

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1870

 

 

A retained attorney who provides representation and is then discharged is entitled to be compensated, on a quantum meruit basis, for the fair and reasonable value of the completed services. Matter of Cooperman, 83 N.Y.2d 465, 611 N.Y.S.2d 465, 633 N.E.2d 1069 (1994).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:40

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

II. Representation and Compensation

§ 2:40. The retained attorney: retainer or letter of engagement may be required—Scope of representation may be limited

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1870

 

 

A judge may permit defense counsel to appear “provisionally” at the beginning stages of a criminal proceeding, pending the defendant’s retaining of the attorney. And counsel may represent a defendant on just a portion of a case, such as only through presentation to a grand jury but not after indictment. NY State Ethics Opinion No. 856, 2011 WL 1351743.

 

The Rules of Professional Conduct permit an attorney to limit the scope of representation if it is reasonable under the circumstances, the client gives informed consent, and where necessary notice is given to the tribunal and/or opposing counsel. RPC 1.2(c).

 

However, the practice of an attorney representing a client at one court appearance only has been criticized as giving the appearance of representation without any further responsibility on the attorney’s part for additional preparation or consultation. People v. Lynch, 138 Misc. 2d 331, 524 N.Y.S.2d 632 (Sup 1988); see also People v. Jordan, 153 A.D.2d 263, 550 N.Y.S.2d 917 (2d Dep’t 1990).

 

Practice Tip:

A private attorney might represent a client in the initial stages of a case—e.g., up to and through grand jury. Even though that attorney may not handle the trial, it is essential that the investigative aspects of a case be pursued—finding alibi witnesses, for example.

 

Substitution of counsel should be avoided at critical parts of a criminal proceeding. Changing attorneys when trial is fast approaching may result in either the court denying any request for adjournment, or in inadequate representation if a switch occurs. See § 2:68, Substitution of counsel; obtaining file from former counsel.

 

While there is an attorney-client privilege, see §§ 2:47 et seq., Attorney-client privilege, it should be remembered that the attorney has no privilege. The privilege from disclosure to others belongs to the client. See Finn v. Riley, 202 A.D.2d 880, 609 N.Y.S.2d 449 (3d Dep’t 1994). See § 2:47, Attorney-client privilege.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:41

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:41. Advising the client

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1870

 

 

Many defendants know very little about the criminal law; the defense attorney must provide not only advocacy but also essential knowledge of rights as well.

 

Clearly, a defendant should not plead guilty without being adequately informed of the possible alternatives. Nor should a defendant go to trial without being aware of the potential consequences. Finally, the defendant should be aware of the effect a conviction could have after the criminal proceeding has run its course. Muldoon, Collateral Effects of a Criminal Conviction, NYS Bar Journal, July/August 1998, p. 26. See Ch 22, subchapter X, Collateral consequences of convictions. Accordingly, after becoming familiar with the facts of the case, counsel should discuss these matters with the client as early in the relationship as possible.

 

Both the attorney and the client have roles to play, and each has rights and responsibilities.

 

See § 2:111 for Checklist—Items to review with client.

 

See § 2:114 for Form—Initial interview of client.

 

See § 2:115 for Form—Initial letter to client.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:42

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:42. Attorney-client relationship—Defendant makes fundamental decisions

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​105

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​106

 

 

An attorney functions as a guide and adviser, but the defendant makes certain fundamental decisions where counsel cannot impose his/her own views. The defendant decides: whether to plead guilty; waive the right to a jury trial; testify at trial; and take an appeal. Florida v. Nixon, 543 U.S. 175, 125 S. Ct. 551, 160 L. Ed. 2d 565 (2004); Jones v. Barnes, 463 U.S. 745, 103 S. Ct. 3308, 77 L. Ed. 2d 987 (1983); People v. Ferguson, 67 N.Y.2d 383, 502 N.Y.S.2d 972, 494 N.E.2d 77 (1986); Brown v. Artuz, 124 F.3d 73 (2d Cir. 1997); People v. Henriquez, 3 N.Y.3d 210, 785 N.Y.S.2d 384, 818 N.E.2d 1125 (2004) (defendant who refuses self-representation but restricts the participation of counsel thereby waives the right to counsel); People v. Adger, 156 A.D.3d 1458, 66 N.Y.S.3d 584 (4th Dep’t 2017) (defendant could override counsel’s decision on waiving jury trial); ABA Standards for Criminal Justice 4-5.2; Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 1.2(a) (“In a criminal case, the lawyer shall abide by the client’s decision, after consultation with the lawyer, as to a plea to be entered, whether to waive jury trial and whether the client will testify.”)

 

A defendant has the right to choose the objective of his defense, and may require legal counsel to refrain from admitting guilt. McCoy v. Louisiana, 584 U.S. 414, 138 S. Ct. 1500, 200 L. Ed. 2d 821 (2018).

 

An attorney has the duty to inform the defendant of the right to testify, even against the attorney’s advice. See People v. Cosby, 82 A.D.3d 63, 916 N.Y.S.2d 689 (4th Dep’t 2011). See § 18:57, Defendant’s decision to not testify.

 

If defense counsel defers to defendant solely without exercising professional judgment, on an issue that is for the attorney to make, the defendant is deprived of the expert judgment of counsel. People v. Diaz, 163 A.D.3d 110, 78 N.Y.S.3d 792 (3d Dep’t 2018).

 

As between defense counsel and defendant, the defendant retains the authority to request submission of the affirmative defense of extreme emotional disturbance in a murder case. People v. Petrovich, 87 N.Y.2d 961, 641 N.Y.S.2d 592, 664 N.E.2d 503 (1996); see People v. Alvarez, 106 A.D.3d 568, 965 N.Y.S.2d 466 (1st Dep’t 2013). The defendant also has the right to reject use of the insanity defense, even over defense counsel’s objection. People v. McMillan, 148 Misc. 2d 738, 561 N.Y.S.2d 512 (Sup 1990), judgment aff’d, 212 A.D.2d 445, 622 N.Y.S.2d 935 (1st Dep’t 1995).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:43

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:43. Attorney-client relationship—Defendant makes fundamental decisions—Attorney may not waive certain rights

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​105

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​106

 

 

One corollary of the distinction between the decisions made by attorney and by client is the limitation on the attorney’s ability to waive certain rights; for example, the defendant’s right to be present during instructions to the jury cannot be waived by defense counsel. People v. Pegeise, 195 A.D.2d 337, 600 N.Y.S.2d 26 (1st Dep’t 1993). See § 19:11, Defendant’s right to be present.

 

An absent defendant is deemed to have delegated to counsel decisions regarding discharge and substitutions of jurors during deliberations. People v. Cannady, 127 Misc. 2d 783, 487 N.Y.S.2d 294 (Sup 1985), judgment aff’d, 138 A.D.2d 616, 526 N.Y.S.2d 202 (2d Dep’t 1988).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:44

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:44. Attorney-client relationship—Defendant makes fundamental decisions—Defendant’s incapacitation

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​105

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​106

 

 

When the client is found to be incapacitated under CPL Article 730, the attorney’s power to make decisions may be limited. See §§ 15:60 to 15:64, Mental state may affect fitness to proceed.

 

Example:

Counsel may make a motion to suppress evidence for an incompetent defendant, but may not proceed to the hearing. See People v. Matthews, 154 Misc. 2d 848, 585 N.Y.S.2d 948 (Sup 1992).

 

A defendant is competent who has the ability to understand the proceedings and to assist in his/her own defense. See CPL 730.10(1); People v. Matthews, 154 Misc. 2d 848, 585 N.Y.S.2d 948 (Sup 1992).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:45

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:45. Attorney-client relationship—Counsel’s role: case strategy

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​105

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​106

 

 

Choices of a strategic nature are for the lawyer. An attorney is by definition an agent who performs legal work on the defendant’s behalf; by accepting that representation, the defendant defers to the judgment of the lawyer, except for those certain fundamental decisions noted above. People v. Ferguson, 67 N.Y.2d 383, 502 N.Y.S.2d 972, 494 N.E.2d 77 (1986); U.S. v. Marshall, 488 F.2d 1169 (9th Cir. 1973); Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 1.2.

 

Practice Tip:

Where defendant and counsel differ on an issue that counsel has the right to decide, it is error for the court to defer to the defendant’s request, e.g., on whether to submit a lesser included offense. People v. Colville, 20 N.Y.3d 20, 955 N.Y.S.2d 799, 979 N.E.2d 1125 (2012); People v. Allen, 189 A.D.3d 463, 136 N.Y.S.3d 276 (1st Dep’t 2020). See also People v. McKenzie, 142 A.D.3d 1279, 38 N.Y.S.3d 330 (4th Dep’t 2016) (jury selection).

 

Among the “strategic” decisions that defense counsel can make are:

         • whether to consent to a mistrial, People v. Ferguson, 67 N.Y.2d 383, 502 N.Y.S.2d 972, 494 N.E.2d 77 (1986); People v. Hambrick, 96 A.D.3d 972, 947 N.Y.S.2d 139 (2d Dep’t 2012)

         • whether to strike or challenge a particular prospective juror, People v. Colon, 90 N.Y.2d 824, 660 N.Y.S.2d 377, 682 N.E.2d 978 (1997)

         • whether to consent to closure of the courtroom, People v. Vanegas, 243 A.D.2d 261, 663 N.Y.S.2d 140 (1st Dep’t 1997) See §§ 19:31 to 19:39, Closure of courtroom for compelling reasons.

         • whether to forego a duplicate suppression hearing, People v. Parker, 290 A.D.2d 650, 736 N.Y.S.2d 162 (3d Dep’t 2002)

         • whether to waive a statutory speedy trial claim, People v. Trepasso, 197 A.D.2d 891, 602 N.Y.S.2d 291 (4th Dep’t 1993)

         • whether to waive operation of CPL 180.80, People v. Johnson, 150 Misc. 2d 1024, 570 N.Y.S.2d 773 (Sup 1991)

         • whether to submit a lesser included offense to the trier of fact, People v. Colville, 20 N.Y.3d 20, 955 N.Y.S.2d 799, 979 N.E.2d 1125 (2012); People v. Taylor, 2 A.D.3d 1306, 769 N.Y.S.2d 797 (4th Dep’t 2003); see also People v. Garrick, 11 A.D.3d 395, 783 N.Y.S.2d 371 (1st Dep’t 2004) (conceding guilt on a lesser charge not tantamount to a partial plea of guilty, which would require defendant’s express consent); People v. Washington, 19 A.D.3d 1180, 796 N.Y.S.2d 500 (4th Dep’t 2005); People v. Weathersby, 30 A.D.3d 979, 815 N.Y.S.2d 844 (4th Dep’t 2006); People v. Reyes, 287 A.D.2d 660, 731 N.Y.S.2d 737 (2d Dep’t 2001) (attorney conceding guilt on possession and arguing mistaken identity on sale charge was valid strategy). But compare McCoy v. Louisiana, 138 S. Ct. 1500, 200 L. Ed. 2d 821 (2018) (defendant has the right to choose the objective of his defense, and may make legal counsel refrain from admitting guilt).

         • whether to testify at the grand jury, People v. Hogan, 26 N.Y.3d 779, 28 N.Y.S.3d 1, 48 N.E.3d 58 (2016).

 

Practice Tip:

Even when the decisions to be made are strategic, good communication remains essential to maintaining a positive attorney-client relationship.

 

However unschooled in the fine points of law, the client is still the one whose liberty is at stake and whose viewpoint and insight can make a difference. It is therefore prudent for the attorney to stay in contact, to inform the client when certain issues arise, and to explain why strategic decisions have been made.

 

An incarcerated defendant facing trial needs to be visited regularly by the attorney; an appellate client’s letter deserves a speedy response. Of course, certain communications must be shared, such as when the prosecution makes a plea offer. See Missouri v. Frye, 566 U.S. 134, 132 S. Ct. 1399, 182 L. Ed. 2d 379 (2012). See § 2:91, Plea bargaining and guilty plea.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:46

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:46. Attorney-client relationship—Counsel’s role: case strategy—Attorney is recipient of legal notice

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​105

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​106

 

 

The attorney who represents a defendant is the recipient of legal notice. See CPLR 2103(b); People v. White, 115 A.D.2d 313, 496 N.Y.S.2d 187 (4th Dep’t 1985); People v. Brown, 168 Misc. 2d 923, 646 N.Y.S.2d 241 (City Ct. 1996).

 

Once notice is received, however, the client should be informed. For example, where the prosecution seeks bodily samples or a lineup, or provides notification of grand jury presentation, defense counsel should relay this information. In particular, any plea offers should be communicated. See § 2:91, Plea bargaining and guilty plea.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:47

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:47. Attorney-client privilege

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​105

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​106

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1853

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Privileged Communications and Confidentiality​100 to 102

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Privileged Communications and Confidentiality​110

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Privileged Communications and Confidentiality​145

 

 

The attorney-client privilege is part of the right to counsel. CPLR 4503; CPL 245.65; Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 1.6; People v. Belge, 83 Misc. 2d 186, 372 N.Y.S.2d 798 (County Ct. 1975), aff’d, 50 A.D.2d 1088, 376 N.Y.S.2d 771 (4th Dep’t 1975), order aff’d, 41 N.Y.2d 60, 390 N.Y.S.2d 867, 359 N.E.2d 377 (1976); see § 8:53, Attorney work product generally not discoverable; § 14:2, Representation by separate counsel; § 18:33, Privileged communications.

 

The attorney-client privilege, RPC 1.6, applies to those employees, such as paralegals and secretaries, assisting the attorney. See Hall, Professional Responsibility in Criminal Defense Practice, 4th ed., § 29:32.

 

Examples:

An attorney is not required to disclose information concerning an absconding defendant’s whereabouts. Matter of Grand Jury Investigation, 175 Misc. 2d 398, 669 N.Y.S.2d 179 (County Ct. 1998); D’Alessio v. Gilberg, 205 A.D.2d 8, 617 N.Y.S.2d 484 (2d Dep’t 1994); cf. Matter of Jacqueline F., 47 N.Y.2d 215, 417 N.Y.S.2d 884, 391 N.E.2d 967 (1979).

 

A lawyer’s statements to the police while turning in his client, which inculpated his client, were privileged and inadmissible, where there was no evidence that the client had authorized waiver of the privilege. People v. Cassas, 84 N.Y.2d 718, 622 N.Y.S.2d 228, 646 N.E.2d 449 (1995).

 

No privilege existed as to grand jury questions about how attorneys came into possession of a laptop computer that accessed a homicide victim’s residence, and what had happened to that laptop. The evidence suggested strongly that the computer was an instrumentality of the crime rather than a confidential communication. In re Grand Jury Subpoena Dated June 30, 2003, 1 Misc. 3d 510, 770 N.Y.S.2d 568 (Sup 2003).

 

The attorney-client privilege survives the death of the client. Swidler & Berlin v. U.S., 524 U.S. 399, 118 S. Ct. 2081, 141 L. Ed. 2d 379, 49 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 1, 40 Fed. R. Serv. 3d 745, 159 A.L.R. Fed. 729 (1998); People v. Vespucci, 192 Misc. 2d 685, 745 N.Y.S.2d 391 (County Ct. 2002). Because a person while alive can waive the attorney-client privilege, the personal representative of an estate stands in the shoes of the decedent for the same purposes. See In re Estate of Colby, 187 Misc. 2d 695, 723 N.Y.S.2d 631 (Sur. Ct. 2001); Mayorga v. Tate, 302 A.D.2d 11, 752 N.Y.S.2d 353 (2d Dep’t 2002).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:48

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:48. Attorney-client privilege—Discussions confidential unless waived

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​105

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​106

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1853

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Privileged Communications and Confidentiality​100 to 102

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Privileged Communications and Confidentiality​110

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Privileged Communications and Confidentiality​145

 

 

Unless waived, the content of discussions between the client and the attorney or the attorney’s employee is confidential.

 

A lawyer may reveal: confidences or secrets when required by court order; a client’s intention to commit a crime in the future; confidences and secrets to collect a fee or to defend against an accusation of wrongful conduct. RPC 1.6(b). See § 23:51, Ineffective assistance of counsel.

 

Additionally, the “crime-fraud” exception may apply. Nowlin v. People of State of New York, 1 A.D.3d 172, 767 N.Y.S.2d 77 (1st Dep’t 2003); Annot., 9 A.L.R.6th 363.

 

It is improper for a prosecutor to question a defendant about statements made to the defense attorney. People v. Ali, 146 A.D.2d 636, 536 N.Y.S.2d 541 (2d Dep’t 1989); see § 2:101, Assertion of claim waives confidentiality; § 8:36, Attorney work product generally not discoverable.

 

The privilege from disclosure to others belongs to the client, rather than the attorney. See Finn v. Riley, 202 A.D.2d 880, 609 N.Y.S.2d 449 (3d Dep’t 1994).

 

It may be permissible to direct an attorney to not divulge information to client. See People v. Contreras, 12 N.Y.3d 268, 879 N.Y.S.2d 369, 907 N.E.2d 282 (2009).

 

By alleging ineffectiveness, a defendant does not necessarily place in issue all communications with counsel. See Hurrell-Harring v. State, 75 A.D.3d 667, 905 N.Y.S.2d 334 (3d Dep’t 2010), affirmed, 15 N.Y.3d 8, 904 N.Y.S.2d 296, 930 N.E.2d 217 (2010); ABA Formal Opinion 10-456.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:49

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:49. Attorney-client privilege—Consultation is central to relationship

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​105

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Attorney and Client ​106

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1853

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Privileged Communications and Confidentiality​100 to 102

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Privileged Communications and Confidentiality​110

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Privileged Communications and Confidentiality​145

 

 

The defendant’s ability to consult with counsel is central to the attorney-client relationship. Therefore it is improper for the court to bar a defendant or attorney from contacting one another. Geders v. U.S., 425 U.S. 80, 96 S. Ct. 1330, 47 L. Ed. 2d 592 (1976); People v. Hilliard, 73 N.Y.2d 584, 542 N.Y.S.2d 507, 540 N.E.2d 702 (1989). This right to consultation applies at a suppression hearing as well as at trial. People v. Carracedo, 214 A.D.2d 404, 624 N.Y.S.2d 601 (1st Dep’t 1995).

 

Minor interruptions may not constitute reversible error, though. If defense counsel is present and available to register a protest, failure to do so renders the issue unpreserved. People v. Umali, 10 N.Y.3d 417, 859 N.Y.S.2d 104, 888 N.E.2d 1046 (2008).

 

Examples:

A court ruling that prohibited counsel and client from conferring during a luncheon recess did not violate the right to counsel. People v. Enrique, 80 N.Y.2d 869, 587 N.Y.S.2d 598, 600 N.E.2d 229 (1992).

 

But an order that forbade the defendant from consulting with counsel during a weekend recess was improper. People v. Joseph, 84 N.Y.2d 995, 622 N.Y.S.2d 505, 646 N.E.2d 807 (1994); see also People v. Samuels, 22 A.D.3d 507, 802 N.Y.S.2d 458 (2d Dep’t 2005) (overnight).

 

Barring an attorney from speaking with a defense psychiatrist, until the prosecution witness’s testimony was completed, effectively prevented surrebuttal. People v. Santana, 80 N.Y.2d 92, 587 N.Y.S.2d 570, 600 N.E.2d 201 (1992).

 

When the defendant is on the stand, it is proper to bar counsel and defendant from conferring. People v. Narayan, 58 N.Y.2d 904, 460 N.Y.S.2d 503, 447 N.E.2d 51 (1983).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:50

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:50. Conflict may require new counsel; duty to inquire

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1780 to 1791

 

 

A defendant may voice complaints about the quality of defense counsel at various points in the case, including before and during trial, at sentencing, and as well as when seeking to withdraw a guilty plea. See § 17:69, Request not to be summarily denied. Where the articulated complaints are sufficiently serious to trigger the judge’s duty to question, the failure to make a minimal inquiry requires reversal. People v. Edwards, 173 A.D.3d 1615, 102 N.Y.S.3d 354 (4th Dep’t 2019) (trial); People v. Jones, 173 A.D.3d 1628, 102 N.Y.S.3d 365 (4th Dep’t 2019) (guilty plea); People v. Darwish, 195 A.D.3d 1515, 148 N.Y.S.3d 318 (4th Dep’t 2021).

 

An indigent defendant is not entitled to successive attorneys at defendant’s option. An indigent defendant who makes a showing of good cause for substitution of counsel, such as a conflict of interest or irreconcilable difference with counsel, may be entitled to new assigned counsel. Among the factors to be considered are the timing of the request, its effect on the progress of the case, and whether present counsel will likely provide meaningful assistance. People v. Porto, 16 N.Y.3d 93, 917 N.Y.S.2d 74, 942 N.E.2d 283 (2010). Where a court fails to make even a minimal inquiry over the nature of the disagreement with counsel, and whether the attorney could still provide zealous representation, the defendant is denied effective assistance. People v. Sides, 75 N.Y.2d 822, 552 N.Y.S.2d 555, 551 N.E.2d 1233 (1990); People v. Smith, 25 A.D.3d 573, 807 N.Y.S.2d 402 (2d Dep’t 2006).

 

The defense attorney’s response to client criticism might itself cause a conflict to arise. See § 17:68, When conflict with attorney arises.

 

In certain circumstances, a district attorney’s office may have a conflict of interest. See § 7:21, Disqualification of district attorney.

 

Both the prosecution and defense are under a mandatory affirmative obligation to recognize the existence of a potential conflict as well as to alert the court to the facts and circumstances surrounding it. People v. Wandell, 75 N.Y.2d 951, 555 N.Y.S.2d 686, 554 N.E.2d 1274 (1990).

 

A conflict of interest is not automatically created when a defendant files a grievance complaint against his own counsel. People v. Smith, supra; People v. Crowder, 6 Misc. 3d 625, 790 N.Y.S.2d 825 (Sup 2004), aff’d on other grounds, 47 A.D.3d 724, 848 N.Y.S.2d 886 (2d Dep’t 2008); People v. Ogarro, 33 A.D.3d 1025, 823 N.Y.S.2d 511 (2d Dep’t 2006). Where a grievance is filed, the court has the duty to inquire. See People v. Hardy, 159 A.D.3d 1485, 72 N.Y.S.3d 312 (4th Dep’t 2018).

 

Conflicts of interest can be actual or potential. An actual conflict arises when an attorney has divided and incompatible loyalties within the same matter necessarily preclusive of single-minded advocacy. A potential conflict is one that may never be realized. Some actual and all potential conflicts may be waived. See People v. Brown, 33 N.Y.3d 983, 100 N.Y.S.3d 697, 124 N.E.3d 247 (2019).

 

There is an inherent conflict of interest where a defense attorney, having initially represented a defendant, switches sides and joins a prosecutor’s office while the case is pending. But the same concerns are not present when the reverse occurs and the prosecuting attorney assumes the role of defense counsel. See People v. Thomas, 217 A.D.3d 1125, 191 N.Y.S.3d 519 (3d Dep’t 2023), leave to appeal denied, 40 N.Y.3d 1013, 199 N.Y.S.3d 13, 222 N.E.3d 529 (2023).

 

Examples:

A prosecutor, by accusing defense counsel of misconduct at trial, did not cause a conflict of interest. People v. Langguth, 63 A.D.3d 478, 880 N.Y.S.2d 638 (1st Dep’t 2009).

 

Where an attorney is implicated in the defendant’s crime, this is ineffective assistance per se. See U.S. v. Kaid, 502 F.3d 43 (2d Cir. 2007), for additional opinion, see, 241 Fed. Appx. 747 (2d Cir. 2007). But see People v. Konstantinides, 14 N.Y.3d 1, 896 N.Y.S.2d 284, 923 N.E.2d 567 (2009) (where attorney accused of suborning perjury, no ineffectiveness found: defendant was fully informed of potential conflict, and a conflict-free attorney also represented defendant).

 

Practice Tip:

Generally, a simultaneous conflict of interest is more serious than a serial conflict of interest. See RPC 1.7(1)(a). Simultaneous representation is improper unless the conflict is validly waived. See People v. Prescott, 21 N.Y.3d 925, 967 N.Y.S.2d 887, 990 N.E.2d 125 (2013); People v. Lynch, 104 A.D.3d 1062, 961 N.Y.S.2d 605 (3d Dep’t 2013).

 

Examples:

There was no ineffective assistance where defense counsel represented both defendant and confidential informant before trial. People v. Harris, 99 N.Y.2d 202, 753 N.Y.S.2d 437, 783 N.E.2d 502 (2002). Where the attorney represented victim before the posttrial proceedings, this was a potential but not actual conflict of interest. People v. Lewis-Bush, 204 A.D.3d 1424, 166 N.Y.S.3d 783 (4th Dep’t 2022), leave to appeal denied, 38 N.Y.3d 1072, 171 N.Y.S.3d 451, 191 N.E.3d 403 (2022).

 

Where a defense attorney represented a witness who testifies against the defendant, the court must make an inquiry and receive the informed consent of the defendant. People v. Solomon, 20 N.Y.3d 91, 956 N.Y.S.2d 457, 980 N.E.2d 505 (2012); People v. Price, 163 A.D.2d 915, 559 N.Y.S.2d 66 (4th Dep’t 1990). See § 2:56, Simultaneous representation of defendant and of prosecution witness.

 

The fact that an attorney previously represented a codefendant does not cause disqualification. People v. Singleton, 3 A.D.3d 408, 771 N.Y.S.2d 106 (1st Dep’t 2004).

 

The court acted properly in relieving the defense attorney, who represented a codefendant who had implicated defendant, resulting in potential advocate-witness and unsworn-witness issues. People v. Rufus, 56 A.D.3d 1175, 867 N.Y.S.2d 608 (4th Dep’t 2008); People v. Carncross, 14 N.Y.3d 319, 901 N.Y.S.2d 112, 927 N.E.2d 532 (2010).

 

In showing that the conduct of the defense was in fact affected by defense counsel’s conflict of interest arising from the attorney’s previous representation of a client whose interests conflicted with the defendant’s, or that the conflict operated on the representation, the defendant need not show specific prejudice. People v. Solomon, 20 N.Y.3d 91, 956 N.Y.S.2d 457, 980 N.E.2d 505 (2012); People v. DiPippo, 82 A.D.3d 786, 918 N.Y.S.2d 136 (2d Dep’t 2011).

 

Defendant’s statement to the police referred to another defendant that his defense counsel had recently represented. Also, a recorded conversation between defendant and the former client was introduced into evidence. At trial, defense counsel indicated he would be unable to question the police officer regarding defendant’s statement about his former client. Defense counsel did not call his former client to testify about the recorded conversation. Defendant’s representation was compromised. People v. McGillicuddy, 103 A.D.3d 1200, 959 N.Y.S.2d 341 (4th Dep’t 2013).

 

Practice Tip:

The size of a law office may affect whether representation constitutes a conflict. See Hempstead Video, Inc. v. Incorporated Village of Valley Stream, 409 F.3d 127 (2d Cir. 2005). In an office of less than ten attorneys, the “of counsel” status did not insulate a conflict of interest. People v. Lynch, 104 A.D.3d 1062, 961 N.Y.S.2d 605 (3d Dep’t 2013). This issue may arise with prosecutor’s offices as well. See People v. Gaines, 277 A.D.2d 900, 716 N.Y.S.2d 207 (4th Dep’t 2000); see § 7:21, Disqualification of district attorney.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:51

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:51. Advocate-witness rule

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1780

 

 

An attorney cannot be both a witness and an advocate in a proceeding. RPC 3.7; People v. Amato, 173 A.D.2d 714, 570 N.Y.S.2d 817 (2d Dep’t 1991); People v. Swanson, 43 A.D.3d 1331, 844 N.Y.S.2d 521 (4th Dep’t 2007). This rule applies to both defense and prosecution. See § 7:21, Disqualification of district attorney. Removal of the attorney is not required if the testimony is not prejudicial to the client. People v. Brand, 13 A.D.3d 820, 787 N.Y.S.2d 169 (3d Dep’t 2004) (attorney testified at suppression hearing).

 

A conflict arises when an attorney becomes an “unsworn witness,” People v. Berroa, 99 N.Y.2d 134, 753 N.Y.S.2d 12, 782 N.E.2d 1148 (2002), or a sworn witness at trial.

 

The defendant is not deprived of the right to present a defense where defense counsel is barred from testifying, where defense counsel does not request to withdraw so as to testify. People v. Ramchair, 308 A.D.2d 601, 764 N.Y.S.2d 725 (2d Dep’t 2003).

 

Example:

Defense counsel alone interviewed the prosecution’s main witness, who allegedly recanted his identification of defendant. Defense counsel should have been relieved as trial counsel, as he was faced with the choice of testifying for the client, which would result in disqualification, or not presenting evidence of the exculpatory statement. People v. Lawrence, 156 A.D.3d 652, 66 N.Y.S.3d 286 (2d Dep’t 2017).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:52

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:52. Defendant’s right to make choice

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1780

 

 

Ultimately, the defendant’s right to choice of counsel is more important than a conflict of interest. Some conflicts of interest are waivable, others nonwaivable. People v. Salcedo, 68 N.Y.2d 130, 506 N.Y.S.2d 154, 497 N.E.2d 292 (1986).

 

The decision to waive the right to conflict-free counsel is normally for the defendant to make. A trial judge’s discretion is especially broad when faced with the dilemma of having to choose between undesirable alternatives, either one of which would theoretically provide the defendant with a basis for appellate review. People v. Tineo, 64 N.Y.2d 531, 490 N.Y.S.2d 159, 479 N.E.2d 795 (1985). The waiver cannot be defeated simply because the conflict later affects counsel’s performance; such a result would eliminate the purpose of obtaining the waiver. People v. Glinton, 72 A.D.3d 618, 900 N.Y.S.2d 264 (1st Dep’t 2010).

 

The defendant also has the right to reject use of the insanity defense, even over defense counsel’s objection. People v. McMillan, 148 Misc. 2d 738, 561 N.Y.S.2d 512 (Sup 1990), judgment aff’d, 212 A.D.2d 445, 622 N.Y.S.2d 935 (1st Dep’t 1995). See § 2:42, Defendant makes fundamental decisions; §§ 15:52 et seq., Mental disease or defect.

 

Example:

Where defendant’s attorney absented himself during jury deliberations, leaving the defendant to be represented by the codefendant’s attorney, who had an actual conflict, defendant’s informed consent was required. People v. Allah, 80 N.Y.2d 396, 590 N.Y.S.2d 840, 605 N.E.2d 327 (1992).

 

However, even if the defendant consents to continued representation, the court may decline to accept and, additionally, require substitution of counsel. People v. Carncross, 14 N.Y.3d 319, 901 N.Y.S.2d 112, 927 N.E.2d 532 (2010); U.S. v. Arrington, 867 F.2d 122 (2d Cir. 1989); People v. Limongelli, 156 A.D.2d 473, 548 N.Y.S.2d 759 (2d Dep’t 1989); People v. Gordon, 272 A.D.2d 133, 709 N.Y.S.2d 503 (1st Dep’t 2000).

 

A defendant has the right to counsel of their own choosing, but may not employ this right as a means of delaying judicial proceedings. People v. Makropoulos, 211 A.D.3d 968, 180 N.Y.S.3d 285 (2d Dep’t 2022).

 

Examples:

After several months of representing a defendant, an attorney in an institutional defender’s office learned through discovery that his office had represented another defendant who had been arrested on the same offense. The defendant was willing to waive the conflict, but the judge appointed new counsel. Substituting counsel was not an abuse of discretion. People v. Watson, 26 N.Y.3d 620, 26 N.Y.S.3d 504, 46 N.E.3d 1057 (2016).

 

Removal of defense counsel was appropriate where the conflict was too serious to be addressed by asking whether defendant wanted to waive the conflict: defense counsel was to be called as a witness against defendant. People v. Ramos, 164 A.D.3d 1154, 82 N.Y.S.3d 409 (1st Dep’t 2018).

 

Practice Tip:

It may be appropriate for the court to appoint “conflict counsel,” an independent attorney to advise the defendant on whether another attorney should be appointed. See People v. Carncross, supra.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:53

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:53. Gomberg hearing to assess conflict

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1780

 

 

A Gomberg hearing is required where there is multiple simultaneous representation, but not with multiple successive representations. People v. Jordan, 83 N.Y.2d 785, 610 N.Y.S.2d 952, 632 N.E.2d 1275 (1994); People v. Lewis, 97 A.D.3d 1097, 947 N.Y.S.2d 745 (4th Dep’t 2012).

 

When a conflict is alleged, the court should conduct a hearing to determine whether one exists. People v. Gomberg, 38 N.Y.2d 307, 379 N.Y.S.2d 769, 342 N.E.2d 550 (1975).

 

A defendant’s waiver of the conflict may be invalid where the court’s inquiry is insufficient to show an intentional relinquishment of a known right. See People v. Solomon, 20 N.Y.3d 91, 956 N.Y.S.2d 457, 980 N.E.2d 505 (2012).

 

Where a concurrent conflict of interest exists, each affected client must give informed consent, confirmed in writing. RPC 1.7(b)(4).

 

If a conflict of interest is improperly denied, on appeal the defense must establish that the conflict affected the defense. See People v. Solomon, supra. See also People v. Monette, 70 A.D.3d 1186, 895 N.Y.S.2d 574 (3d Dep’t 2010). See § 2:75, Defendant’s burden to overcome presumed effectiveness: strategy. Where not waived, the conflict must have affected, or operated on, or bore a substantial relation to the conduct of the defense. People v. Sanchez, 21 N.Y.3d 216, 969 N.Y.S.2d 840, 991 N.E.2d 698 (2013); People v. Konstantinides, 14 N.Y.3d 1, 896 N.Y.S.2d 284, 923 N.E.2d 567 (2009).

 

Practice Tip:

The contents of a Gomberg hearing regarding joint representation, see § 2:53, Gomberg hearing to assess conflict, depend on the particular case and the defenses available to the defendants.

 

In a typical case the judge might remind each defendant of the right to separate, independent counsel and the availability of assigned counsel, including counsel to discuss the possibility of any conflict of interest. The judge may then inquire whether the defendants have discussed the issue of a conflict with their counsel, and whether the defendants are aware of the potential results of a conflict, such as the attorney’s choosing not to use all available evidence or witnesses.

 

If no conflict is apparent, the judge may want to ascertain that the defendants understand that a conflict may arise as trial preparation progresses or as the case is actually tried.

 

For an example of judge’s colloquy, see http://www.nycourts.gov/judges/cji/8-Colloquies/1MCTOC.shtml.

 

Regardless of whether a Gomberg hearing is held, counsel who represents multiple defendants should raise the ethical issue in the retainer letter to clients, or otherwise document each client’s awareness and waiver of potential conflicts.

 

The failure to conduct a hearing mandates reversal only if the defendant demonstrates that a conflict of interest, or at least the significant possibility of a conflict, existed. People v. Carillo, 218 A.D.2d 505, 630 N.Y.S.2d 305 (1st Dep’t 1995).

 

The trial judge should conduct a sufficient inquiry when there is evidence of a prior relationship between defense counsel and a prosecution witness. People v. Smart, 96 N.Y.2d 793, 726 N.Y.S.2d 343, 750 N.E.2d 45 (2001).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:54

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:54. Court’s inquiry with defendant requesting new attorney

Correlation Table

Separate from a conflict of interest, where a defendant seeks to have another attorney appointed, what is the court’s responsibility? Mere difference over strategy is not grounds for substitution of counsel. People v. Linares, 2 N.Y.3d 507, 780 N.Y.S.2d 529, 813 N.E.2d 609 (2004). The court’s obligation to make an inquiry depends upon the circumstances. Normally at least a limited inquiry should occur. People v. Medina, 44 N.Y.2d 199, 404 N.Y.S.2d 588, 375 N.E.2d 768 (1978); People v. Beard, 100 A.D.3d 1508, 953 N.Y.S.2d 805 (4th Dep’t 2012). The judge should consider the timing of defendant’s request, its effect on the progress of the case, and whether present counsel will likely provide meaningful assistance. People v. Matthews, 159 A.D.3d 1111, 72 N.Y.S.3d 230 (3d Dep’t 2018).

 

Example:

On the day of trial, defendant complained that he had never met his assigned attorney before that day and did not know that trial had been scheduled for that day. The judge spoke with attorneys off record, but never asked the attorney on the record to address defendant’s allegations. It was error to summarily dismiss defendant’s allegations. People v. Beard, supra.

 

A conclusory assertion of counsel’s quality is insufficient to require the court to inquire further. People v. Watkins, 77 A.D.3d 1403, 909 N.Y.S.2d 233 (4th Dep’t 2010).

 

Example:

Defendant requested a new attorney, based largely on a breakdown of communication. Defense counsel agreed. A breakdown in communication may constitute good cause. Defendant also had legitimate concerns about his attorney’s performance, including meeting only sporadically, not taking phone calls, and not providing copies of requested papers. Despite an extended inquiry by the judge, the denial of new counsel was an abuse of discretion. People v. Gibson, 126 A.D.3d 1300, 6 N.Y.S.3d 198 (4th Dep’t 2015).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:55

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:55. Joint representation of codefendants

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1780

 

 

Representation of two codefendants is not per se forbidden, but is fraught with danger. The court should conduct a Gomberg hearing with each codefendant in this situation. People v. Kessler, 167 A.D.2d 947, 562 N.Y.S.2d 901 (4th Dep’t 1990); see § 14:2, Representation by separate counsel. In some cases, where a lawyer represents more than one defendant, the interests of codefendants will be in harmony, such as where their defense involves attempting to show that prosecution witnesses are lying or mistaken. People v. Macerola, 47 N.Y.2d 257, 417 N.Y.S.2d 908, 391 N.E.2d 990 (1979); see also People v. Solomon, 20 N.Y.3d 91, 956 N.Y.S.2d 457, 980 N.E.2d 505 (2012) (dictum).

 

Examples:

In a sex-offense prosecution in state court, an attorney’s near-simultaneous representation of two codefendants (father and son) was not a conflict of interest that resulted in a reduced set of options for the defendant. Eisemann v. Herbert, 401 F.3d 102 (2d Cir. 2005). Cf. People v. Kopp, 33 A.D.3d 153, 817 N.Y.S.2d 806 (4th Dep’t 2006).

 

Defendant was not denied effective assistance of counsel by his attorney also representing codefendants before the felony arraignment. People v. Mundo, 11 A.D.3d 388, 784 N.Y.S.2d 504 (1st Dep’t 2004).

 

The joint representation of husband and wife did not affect the defense that was presented. The prosecution did not assert different levels of culpability, which would suggest that different theories and defense tactics should have been pursued for each. Counsel did not engage in shifting blame from one defendant to another. Counsel could have more aggressively questioned the codefendant to elicit exculpatory testimony, but the husband did not inculpate his wife in any way. While the judge did not address joint representation, the defendant failed to establish that the conflict of interest affected counsel’s representation. People v. St. Andrews, 82 A.D.3d 1358, 918 N.Y.S.2d 640 (3d Dep’t 2011).

 

See § 14:63 for Form—Letter to client regarding representing two defendants.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:56

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:56. Simultaneous representation of defendant and of prosecution witness

Correlation Table

Where a lawyer simultaneously represents the defendant as well as a prosecution witness, again no per se rule exists, but where the interests actually conflict, the attorney cannot represent both, unless the conflict is validly waived. An actual (as opposed to potential) conflict exists if an attorney simultaneously represents clients whose interests are opposed; in this situation, reversal is required if the defendant does not waive the actual conflict. But a potential conflict that is not waived by the accused requires reversal only if it affects the defense. People v. Solomon, 20 N.Y.3d 91, 956 N.Y.S.2d 457, 980 N.E.2d 505 (2012); People v. Palmer, 173 A.D.3d 1560, 101 N.Y.S.3d 678 (3d Dep’t 2019) (public defender cannot represent defendant and confidential informant without express waiver from defendant).

 

Example:

In a drug sale case, the same attorney was appointed to represent the alleged seller as well as one of the alleged buyers. When the buyer pleaded guilty, his allocution described one of the sellers, which fit defendant. The dual representation lasted for six months; the attorney did not represent the seller at trial. But there was an actual conflict, and the alleged seller’s conviction after trial was reversed. The appropriate remedy was to exclude the buyer’s testimony at retrial, but not dismissal, because the People possessed other evidence. People v. Peters, 157 A.D.3d 79, 66 N.Y.S.3d 238 (1st Dep’t 2017).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:57

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:57. Must affect defense to be grounds for appeal

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1780

 

 

Because joint representation is not per se forbidden, a defendant on appeal must demonstrate not only that a significant possibility of a conflict of interest existed but also that it bore a substantial relationship to the conduct of the defense. People v. Recupero, 73 N.Y.2d 877, 538 N.Y.S.2d 234, 535 N.E.2d 287 (1988). Cf. People v. DiPippo, 82 A.D.3d 786, 918 N.Y.S.2d 136 (2d Dep’t 2011) (with representation of a former client, conduct of defense was affected, and no need to show specific prejudice). See § 2:75, Defendant’s burden to overcome presumed effectiveness: strategy.

 

Where there is simultaneous representation and no valid waiver, the fact that an attorney did a “good job” at trial is insufficient to overlook the conflict. People v. Solomon, 20 N.Y.3d 91, 956 N.Y.S.2d 457, 980 N.E.2d 505 (2012).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:58

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:58. Removal of attorney by court

Correlation Table

A sexual relationship between an attorney and client may be subject to professional discipline. See RPC 1.8(j); Matter of Weinstock, 241 A.D.2d 1, 669 N.Y.S.2d 368 (2d Dep’t 1998); see People v. Rubadue, 222 A.D.3d 1266, 202 N.Y.S.3d 784 (3d Dep’t 2023); 7 NY Jur 2d, Attorneys at Law, § 390.

 

Examples:

Removal of an attorney and assigning another attorney (due to office turnover) interfered with the right to counsel and was an abuse of discretion. People v. Griffin, 20 N.Y.3d 626, 964 N.Y.S.2d 505, 987 N.E.2d 282 (2013).

 

The court’s sua sponte dismissal of counsel for missing one court appearance, for which an explanation was given, resulted in denying defendant effective assistance, where that attorney was familiar with the defendant’s case. People v. Burton, 28 A.D.3d 203, 811 N.Y.S.2d 663 (1st Dep’t 2006).

 

Defense counsel was properly removed where the assigned representation did not involve an established relationship, and the attorney repeatedly delayed in accomplishing a simple task. People v. Foreman, 117 A.D.3d 445, 985 N.Y.S.2d 75 (1st Dep’t 2014).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:59

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:59. Attorney’s withdrawal from representation

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1832

 

 

At times, the interests of a client and attorney may diverge. Just as a defendant may seek to terminate the attorney-client relationship, so too a defense attorney may seek to withdraw from a case.

 

Among the factors that may lead an attorney to conclude that it would be best to terminate the relationship, what is listed in the following sections are common.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:60

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:60. Attorney’s withdrawal from representation—Differences over strategy

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1832

 

 

There may be differences over which defense should be used, whether to call a certain witness, or whether to accept a plea offer. See § 2:45, Counsel’s role: case strategy.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:61

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:61. Attorney’s withdrawal from representation—Failure to pay retainer

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1832

 

 

A defendant facing “upstate time” is unlikely to pay a bill after conviction, and thus the fact that a retainer has not been paid in full can become an issue when trial looms. An attorney who is discharged without being fully paid is normally entitled to a “retaining lien” on legal papers. With a criminal case, the defendant and new counsel need to adequately prepare for trial, and the state needs to have the underlying criminal matter promptly determined. At least where the defendant is indigent, the prior attorney may be required to turn over a copy of the file. People v. Altvater, 78 Misc. 2d 24, 355 N.Y.S.2d 736 (Sup 1974); see also Katsaros v. Katsaros, 152 A.D.2d 539, 543 N.Y.S.2d 478 (2d Dep’t 1989). See § 2:68, Substitution of counsel; obtaining file from former counsel.

 

A dispute over nonpayment of attorney fees did not adversely affect the conduct of the defense, where counsel negotiated a favorable plea agreement, and there was no showing that the advice was due to counsel’s economic interest. People v. Husbands, 303 A.D.2d 227, 756 N.Y.S.2d 553 (1st Dep’t 2003).

 

Practice Tip:

A retained attorney whose client has run out of money may seek to be assigned, provided the attorney is on the assigned counsel panel. If assignment is approved by the court, it can avoid withdrawal where continued payment is the only issue separating attorney and client.

 

A written retainer agreement is required in criminal cases (and other cases) where the fee is $3,000 or more. 22 NYCRR §§ 1215.1, 1215.2.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:62

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:62. Attorney’s withdrawal from representation—Conflict of interest

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1832

 

 

If counsel perceives that an irreconcilable conflict of interest has arisen, withdrawal may be necessary. See § 2:17, New assignment; § 2:51, Advocate-witness rule.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:63

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:63. Attorney’s withdrawal from representation—Defense counsel’s employment by district attorney’s office

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1832

 

 

Where counsel for a defendant joins the district attorney’s office, there is a potential conflict of interest. To warrant vacatur of a conviction, the defendant must demonstrate actual prejudice or a substantial risk of abuse of confidence. People v. English, 88 N.Y.2d 30, 643 N.Y.S.2d 16, 665 N.E.2d 1056 (1996); see § 7:21, Disqualification of district attorney.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:64

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:64. Attorney’s withdrawal from representation—Poor relationship

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1832

 

 

An inability to work with an individual defendant may adversely affect the quality of representation.

 

A personality conflict between counsel and client does not constitute a conflict of interest. People v. Russell, 83 A.D.3d 1463, 919 N.Y.S.2d 721 (4th Dep’t 2011).

 

Example:

Defendant’s unjustified hostility toward his attorney and disagreement with tactics did not require substituting counsel. No good cause was shown for a midtrial change of attorneys. People v. Johnson, 76 A.D.3d 937, 907 N.Y.S.2d 494 (1st Dep’t 2010).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:65

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:65. Attorney’s withdrawal from representation—Breach of contract with retained counsel

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1832

 

 

When retained counsel is involved, there may be a breach of the contract of representation.

 

However, an attorney who has appeared in court on a case cannot withdraw based upon the language of a retainer, but instead needs court permission. The attorney must show good cause warranting withdrawal. RPC 1.16(c). See Willis v. Holder, 43 A.D.3d 1441, 842 N.Y.S.2d 841 (4th Dep’t 2007).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:66

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:66. Withdrawal application to court on notice to defendant

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1832

 

 

An application to withdraw should be made to the trial judge, on notice to the defendant. The procedure outlined by the Civil Practice Law and Rules requires the use of an order to show cause. CPLR 321(b)(2); RPC 1.16(d).

 

Practice Tip:

Although civil practice normally requires a 30-day stay upon the discharge of an attorney, no such rule exists in criminal practice. However, new counsel should request an adjournment to become familiar with the case. See § 19:46, When adjournment sought for change of attorney.

 

Where a judge allows an attorney to withdraw, arrangements should be made to transfer the contents of defense counsel’s files, including decisions and orders, accusatory instruments, motions, and investigative reports.

 

See § 2:124 for Form—Motion to withdraw as counsel.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:67

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:67. Withdrawal application to court on notice to defendant—Unilateral action disapproved

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1832

 

 

Even if the attorney perceives an ethical barrier to continued representation, court permission should be obtained, and if denied, counsel must remain. See Balter v. Regan, 97 A.D.2d 953, 468 N.Y.S.2d 750 (4th Dep’t 1983), judgment aff’d, 63 N.Y.2d 630, 479 N.Y.S.2d 506, 468 N.E.2d 688 (1984). Where trial is impending, the trial judge may deny a motion to withdraw that is based on client noncooperation or financial reasons. People v. Fen, 192 Misc. 2d 788, 747 N.Y.S.2d 353 (Sup 2002).

 

Indeed, counsel who fail to appear in court on a criminal matter on which they have previously appeared risk sanction by the court. 22 NYCRR Part 130-2. See § 18:238, Sanctions against counsel.

 

The denial of a motion to withdraw, based upon a conflict of interest, is not reviewable by CPLR Article 78. Dayton v. Campbell, 64 A.D.3d 955, 881 N.Y.S.2d 733 (3d Dep’t 2009).

 

Practice Tip:

A retained attorney may be bound, both contractually and judicially, to continue representing the client. Further, and unlike the situation in civil cases, the defendant’s right to a speedy trial and the State’s need to have an end result are at stake; the court will likely deny the request if made near the time of trial unless a conflict is so clear that the court is left with no choice. Under these circumstances, it is advisable for the practitioner to bring the motion sooner rather than later.

 

Additionally, it may be easier to obtain permission to withdraw from the court if another attorney can be found to take on the case, especially if the client approves and executes a substitution of attorney form.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:68

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

III. Counsel and Client

§ 2:68. Substitution of counsel; obtaining file from former counsel

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1823

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1830

 

 

Where counsel is substituted, the incoming attorney should obtain the contents of the previous attorney’s file. A client is “presumptively entitled” to the contents of the file. The attorney may properly charge for the costs of copying. See Sage Realty Corp. v. Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn L.L.P., 91 N.Y.2d 30, 666 N.Y.S.2d 985, 689 N.E.2d 879 (1997); NYS Bar Association Ethics Opinion 766, 2003 WL 22379944.

 

The Sage Realty decision recognizes that the former attorney is not required to disclose documents that might violate a duty of nondisclosure owed to a third party or otherwise imposed by law. Nor is disclosure required with documents meant for internal law office use. An attorney may need to set down private thoughts and keep such documents secret from the client—e.g., assessment of the client or tentative preliminary impressions of the issues—documents unlikely to be useful to the client or successor attorney.

 

Part of the rationale of Sage Realty, involving business litigation, may be inapplicable to a criminal case.

 

While an attorney is entitled to a “retaining lien” in a criminal case as in other cases, the court may direct the previous attorney to make available papers for copying yet keep the originals. Surrender of documents pursuant to court order does not extinguish the lien. See People v. Altvater, 78 Misc. 2d 24, 355 N.Y.S.2d 736 (Sup 1974).

 

Failure to turn over a file may result in disciplinary action against the attorney. See RPC 1.15; In re Solymosy, 252 A.D.2d 152, 683 N.Y.S.2d 251 (1st Dep’t 1999); In re Strunk, 53 A.D.3d 60, 862 N.Y.S.2d 222 (4th Dep’t 2008).

 

Practice Tip:

Upon obtaining the file from the previous attorney, it may be appropriate to inventory the contents.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:69

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:69. Effective/ineffective assistance of counsel

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1883

 

 

The variation in quality of the representation afforded defendants, depending as it does upon the particular attorney who is representing a given defendant, is perhaps the weakest link in the criminal justice system. See http://www.innocenceproject.org/understand/Bad-Lawyering.php.

 

No matter how odious the crime, a criminal defendant is entitled to effective assistance of counsel under both the state and federal constitutions, and a finding of ineffective assistance can lead to a reversal of conviction. U.S. Const. Amend. VI; N.Y. Const. Art. I, § 6; People v. Baldi, 54 N.Y.2d 137, 444 N.Y.S.2d 893, 429 N.E.2d 400 (1981).

 

The right to constitutionally effective representation does not turn upon whether counsel was retained or assigned. People v. Stultz, 2 N.Y.3d 277, 778 N.Y.S.2d 431, 810 N.E.2d 883 (2004).

 

A defendant who, after sufficient inquiry by the court, is properly permitted to represent himself, may not thereafter claim ineffective assistance. See § 2:8, Effect on ineffective assistance of counsel claim.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:70

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:70. Effective/ineffective assistance of counsel—Application of right

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1883

 

 

The right to effective assistance of counsel has been applied in a variety of contexts, including:

         • custody cases, Jackson v. Lee, 96 A.D.2d 760, 465 N.Y.S.2d 314 (4th Dep’t 1983).

         • children in abuse proceeding, Matter of Jamie TT, 191 A.D.2d 132, 599 N.Y.S.2d 892 (3d Dep’t 1993).

         • review of prison disciplinary proceeding, Crosson v. Coughlin, 197 A.D.2d 864, 604 N.Y.S.2d 878 (4th Dep’t 1993).

         • SORA proceeding, People v. Bertrand, 194 A.D.3d 1081, 144 N.Y.S.3d 593 (2d Dep’t 2021).

         • applications under the DVSJA. See People v. Susan C., 217 A.D.3d 1576, 190 N.Y.S.3d 564 (4th Dep’t 2023), leave to appeal denied, 40 N.Y.3d 1082, 202 N.Y.S.3d 753, 225 N.E.3d 873 (2023). See § 22:187, Domestic Violence Survivors Justice Act.

 

The right to effective assistance does not generally apply in civil cases. See Drake v. Bates, 49 A.D.3d 1098, 853 N.Y.S.2d 733 (3d Dep’t 2008).

 

With ineffective assistance claims, a per se rule applies only where the “attorney” is not a licensed attorney or where the attorney is implicated in defendant’s crime. See U.S. v. Kaid, 502 F.3d 43 (2d Cir. 2007), for additional opinion, see 241 Fed. Appx. 747 (2d Cir. 2007).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:71

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:71. Effective/ineffective assistance of counsel—Test for effective assistance

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1883

 

 

”So long as the evidence, the law, and the circumstances of a particular case, viewed in totality and as of the time of the representation, reveal that the attorney provided meaningful representation, the constitutional requirement will have been met.” People v. Baldi, 54 N.Y.2d 137, 444 N.Y.S.2d 893, 429 N.E.2d 400 (1981). The defendant bears the burden of demonstrating that he was deprived of a fair trial by less-than-meaningful representation. People v. Caban, 5 N.Y.3d 143, 800 N.Y.S.2d 70, 833 N.E.2d 213 (2005). Whether the defendant would have been acquitted but for counsel’s errors is relevant but not dispositive. People v. Benevento, 91 N.Y.2d 708, 674 N.Y.S.2d 629, 697 N.E.2d 584 (1998). While demonstrating prejudice is important, the New York Court of Appeals has not required the defendant to show that, but for counsel’s ineffectiveness, the outcome probably would have been different. People v. Stultz, 2 N.Y.3d 277, 283-284, 778 N.Y.S.2d 431, 810 N.E.2d 883 (2004); People v. Cyrus, 48 A.D.3d 150, 848 N.Y.S.2d 67 (1st Dep’t 2007). The test is reasonable competence, not perfect representation. People v. Oathout, 21 N.Y.3d 127, 967 N.Y.S.2d 654, 989 N.E.2d 936 (2013).

 

The “meaningful representation” standard includes a prejudice component that focuses on the fairness of the process as a whole rather than any particular impact on the outcome of the case. People v. Henry, 95 N.Y.2d 563, 721 N.Y.S.2d 577, 744 N.E.2d 112 (2000). Harmless-error analysis is inapplicable in substantiated cases of ineffective assistance. People v. Benevento, above. See § 24:94, Harmless error.

 

Adequate representation does not require clairvoyance with legal issues that are in flux. People v. Sanchez, 76 A.D.3d 122, 904 N.Y.S.2d 24 (1st Dep’t 2010). See also People v. Schrock, 99 A.D.3d 1196, 951 N.Y.S.2d 819 (4th Dep’t 2012).

 

There is no “litmus test” for “inadequate” or “ineffective” legal representation. People v. Ellis, 81 N.Y.2d 854, 597 N.Y.S.2d 623, 613 N.E.2d 529 (1993).

 

An attorney is not ineffective under the state standard for failing to make a motion or argument that has little or no chance of success. People v. Carver, 27 N.Y.3d 418, 33 N.Y.S.3d 857, 53 N.E.3d 734 (2016); see also, People v. Blake, 24 N.Y.3d 78, 996 N.Y.S.2d 585, 21 N.E.3d 214 (2014). Among the areas where an appellate court found an attorney had little or no chance of success are:

         • Sandoval application. See People v. Perulli, 217 A.D.3d 1133, 191 N.Y.S.3d 523 (3d Dep’t 2023), leave to appeal denied, 40 N.Y.3d 1081, 202 N.Y.S.3d 752, 225 N.E.3d 872 (2023).

         • Huntley hearing. People v. Herman, 217 A.D.3d 1469, 194 N.Y.S.3d 358 (4th Dep’t 2023), leave to appeal denied, 40 N.Y.3d 997, 197 N.Y.S.3d 100, 219 N.E.3d 861 (2023).

 

Defense counsel may not be expected to create a defense when it does not exist. See People v. Murphy, 168 A.D.3d 632, 92 N.Y.S.3d 272 (1st Dep’t 2019).

 

Not every ethical violation constitutes ineffective assistance. See People v. Grimes, 32 N.Y.3d 302, 91 N.Y.S.3d 315, 115 N.E.3d 587 (2018); People v. Crosby, 215 A.D.3d 1225, 187 N.Y.S.3d 876 (4th Dep’t 2023). The advocacy should be evaluated at the time of representation, not for failing to anticipate changes in the law. See People v. Russell, 216 A.D.3d 1111, 189 N.Y.S.3d 704 (2d Dep’t 2023), leave to appeal denied, 40 N.Y.3d 999, 197 N.Y.S.3d 103, 219 N.E.3d 864 (2023).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:72

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:72. Single-error standard

Correlation Table

Where a substantial error so seriously compromises a defendant’s right to a fair trial, it will constitute ineffective representation. See People v. Hobot, 84 N.Y.2d 1021, 622 N.Y.S.2d 675, 646 N.E.2d 1102 (1995). Rarely does a single error by otherwise competent counsel result in ineffective assistance. People v. Turner, 5 N.Y.3d 476, 806 N.Y.S.2d 154, 840 N.E.2d 123 (2005); People v. Flowers, 28 N.Y.3d 536, 46 N.Y.S.3d 497, 68 N.E.3d 1228 (2016); People v. Vasquez, 20 N.Y.3d 461, 962 N.Y.S.2d 589, 985 N.E.2d 899 (2013); People v. Prue, 26 A.D.3d 671, 811 N.Y.S.2d 455 (3d Dep’t 2006); cf. People v. Rivera, 45 A.D.3d 1249, 845 N.Y.S.2d 636 (4th Dep’t 2007) (jury selection). For a single error to constitute ineffectiveness, the failure must be clear-cut and not one based on complex analysis. See People v. Calderon, 66 A.D.3d 314, 884 N.Y.S.2d 29 (1st Dep’t 2009). See People v. Espinosa, 40 N.Y.3d 1065, 202 N.Y.S.3d 730, 225 N.E.3d 849 (2023), cert. denied, 144 S. Ct. 1107 (2024) (DNA).

 

Where the attorney’s error deprived defendant of a jury charge on the only defense supported by the evidence, defendant was denied a fair trial. People v. Debellis, 40 N.Y.3d 431, 202 N.Y.S.3d 740, 225 N.E.3d 859 (2023).

 

Where the issue was not resolved by clear appellate authority and therefore was so clear-cut and dispositive at the time of trial, the effectiveness of the attorney’s conduct does not fall to the level that no reasonable defense counsel would have failed to assert it. People v. Saenger, 39 N.Y.3d 433, 190 N.Y.S.3d 297, 211 N.E.3d 686 (2023) See also People v. Watkins, 2024 WL 2331854 (N.Y. 2024) (cross-racial jury instruction).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:73

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:73. Cumulative error

Correlation Table

Errors by defense counsel, viewed cumulatively, may constitute ineffective assistance. People v. Droz, 39 N.Y.2d 457, 384 N.Y.S.2d 404, 348 N.E.2d 880 (1976); People v. Miller, 11 A.D.3d 729, 783 N.Y.S.2d 130 (3d Dep’t 2004); People v. Ugweches, 116 A.D.3d 440, 983 N.Y.S.2d 244 (1st Dep’t 2014); People v. Newman, 169 A.D.3d 1157, 94 N.Y.S.3d 400 (3d Dep’t 2019).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:74

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:74. Pursuit of a “colorable” claim or defense

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1883

 

 

Counsel’s obligation to pursue a particular contention or defense assumes that the claim or defense is “colorable.” The failure to pursue a course of conduct may be legitimately based on the justifiable belief that there was no colorable basis to do so. People v. DeFreitas, 213 A.D.2d 96, 630 N.Y.S.2d 755 (2d Dep’t 1995); People v. Park, 229 A.D.2d 598, 646 N.Y.S.2d 145 (2d Dep’t 1996).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:75

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:75. Defendant’s burden to overcome presumed effectiveness: strategy

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1883

 

 

There is a strong presumption of effective assistance of counsel. People v. Finch, 199 A.D.2d 278, 604 N.Y.S.2d 222 (2d Dep’t 1993). The burden of demonstrating ineffective assistance, therefore, is upon the defendant. For example, a defendant must show the absence of strategic or other legitimate explanations for counsel’s failure to pursue “colorable” claims. People v. Garcia, 75 N.Y.2d 973, 556 N.Y.S.2d 505, 555 N.E.2d 902 (1990). But terming the decisions made as “strategic” does not mean that all inquiry into effectiveness should wither. Pavel v. Hollins, 261 F.3d 210 (2d Cir. 2001); Miller v. Anderson, 255 F.3d 455 (7th Cir. 2001), order vacated, 268 F.3d 485 (7th Cir. 2001). An attorney cannot be deemed effective merely because of following a strategy; the reasonableness of the strategy must be considered. People v. Stefanovich, 136 A.D.3d 1375, 25 N.Y.S.3d 492 (4th Dep’t 2016).

 

Practice Tip:

Raising a meaningless defense, when a more meaningful alternative theory could have been pursued, may constitute ineffectiveness. See People v. Wosu, 55 A.D.3d 1253, 865 N.Y.S.2d 411 (4th Dep’t 2008).

 

Where a conflict of interest is alleged, the defendant on appeal must demonstrate that the conduct of the defense was in fact affected by the operation of the conflict. People v. Longtin, 92 N.Y.2d 640, 684 N.Y.S.2d 463, 707 N.E.2d 418 (1998); Cuyler v. Sullivan, 446 U.S. 335, 100 S. Ct. 1708, 64 L. Ed. 2d 333 (1980); People v. Gibson, 185 A.D.3d 1101, 126 N.Y.S.3d 581 (3d Dep’t 2020).

 

However, the presumption may be overcome. For example, defense counsel who is “asleep at the switch”—that is, advocacy is found to be essentially perfunctory—may be judged ineffective. People v. Kilstein, 174 A.D.2d 756, 571 N.Y.S.2d 781 (2d Dep’t 1991). Actual sleeping during trial, it should be noted, is not ineffectiveness per se. People v. Tippins, 173 A.D.2d 512, 570 N.Y.S.2d 581 (2d Dep’t 1991); Tippins v. Walker, 77 F.3d 682 (2d Cir. 1996). See also § 19:139, The case of the sleeping juror.

 

Sometimes the finding of ineffective assistance is clear.

 

Examples:

Defendant was represented by an alcoholic attorney who had been once disbarred for more than 20 years and seemed confused and inattentive. People v. Huggins, 164 A.D.2d 784, 559 N.Y.S.2d 720 (1st Dep’t 1990).

 

The defense “attorney” had never been admitted to practice law. People v. Felder, 47 N.Y.2d 287, 418 N.Y.S.2d 295, 391 N.E.2d 1274 (1979). Cf. People v. Jacobs, 6 N.Y.3d 188, 811 N.Y.S.2d 604, 844 N.E.2d 1126 (2005) (nonlawyer participated in trial as cocounsel with an admitted attorney; defendant had benefit of an admitted attorney).
