The assigned attorney had never tried a felony case, did not believe himself capable of providing adequate representation, and his representation was, in fact, inadequate. People v. Forbes, 203 A.D.2d 609, 609 N.Y.S.2d 961 (3d Dep’t 1994).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:76

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:76. Federal standard

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1883

 

 

The federal standard for ineffective assistance has a two-pronged standard: under the “performance” prong, the defendant must show that the attorney’s performance was outside the wide range of professionally competent assistance. Under the “prejudice” prong, the defendant must show that there is a reasonable probability that but for the attorney’s unprofessional errors, the result of the proceeding would be different. Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 104 S. Ct. 2052, 80 L. Ed. 2d 674 (1984); People v. Parker, 220 A.D.2d 815, 632 N.Y.S.2d 288 (3d Dep’t 1995); People v. Sullivan, 153 A.D.2d 223, 550 N.Y.S.2d 358 (2d Dep’t 1990); People v. McDonald, 1 N.Y.3d 109, 769 N.Y.S.2d 781, 802 N.E.2d 131 (2003). Representation that may comply with the federal standard for effective assistance may violate the state standard. See People v. Canales, 110 A.D.3d 731, 972 N.Y.S.2d 316 (2d Dep’t 2013).

 

New York’s Baldi standard is identical to the first prong of the federal standard, but the second prong of the federal standard is based on the fairness of the process as a whole rather than on the impact of counsel’s errors on the outcome of the case. People v. Tirado, 221 A.D.3d 834, 200 N.Y.S.3d 82 (2d Dep’t 2023), leave to appeal denied, 41 N.Y.3d 967, 208 N.Y.S.3d 547, 232 N.E.3d 225 (2024).

 

Practice Tip:

Under the federal standard, a defendant must show that the attorney’s performance fell below an objective standard of reasonableness, and that there is a reasonable probability that, but for counsel’s unprofessional errors, the result of the proceeding would have been different. Under the state standard, which has been called somewhat more favorable to defendants, the constitutional requirement for effective assistance requires meaningful representation. The state standard focuses on the fairness of the process as a whole rather than its particular impact on the outcome of the case. See People v. Bodden, 82 A.D.3d 781, 918 N.Y.S.2d 141 (2d Dep’t 2011). A showing of prejudice is not indispensable, but is significant in evaluating counsel’s effectiveness under the state constitutional standard. People v. Stultz, 2 N.Y.3d 277, 778 N.Y.S.2d 431, 810 N.E.2d 883 (2004).

 

In federal court, where ineffectiveness is raised, the asserted ineffective attorney has an opportunity to be heard and to present evidence, in the form of live testimony, affidavits, or briefs. Sparman v. Edwards, 154 F.3d 51 (2d Cir. 1998); Cullen v. Pinholster, 563 U.S. 170, 131 S. Ct. 1388, 179 L. Ed. 2d 557 (2011). See Defending Against Claim of Ineffective Assistance of Counsel, 82 Am. Jur. Trials 1.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:77

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:77. Particular areas where effectiveness raised—Preaccusatory representation

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1883

 

 

The state is not required to provide effective representation at the preaccusatory, investigatory stage of a criminal case—that is, before the start of the criminal proceeding. Consequently, a defendant who receives faulty representation at this stage may not challenge the conviction on grounds of ineffective assistance of counsel. People v. Claudio, 83 N.Y.2d 76, 607 N.Y.S.2d 912, 629 N.E.2d 384 (1993); People v. Anonymous, 299 A.D.2d 296, 750 N.Y.S.2d 600 (1st Dep’t 2002). See also People v. Maull, 218 A.D.3d 1236, 194 N.Y.S.3d 616 (4th Dep’t 2023) (where police eavesdropped on calls with attorney before defendant was charged, this required a hearing).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:78

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:78. Particular areas where effectiveness raised—Pretrial activity

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1883

 

 

After a case is begins, the defense attorney’s failure to provide crucial advocacy before trial may constitute ineffective assistance of counsel.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:79

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:79. Particular areas where effectiveness raised—Pretrial activity—Failure to investigate

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1883

 

 

Ineffective assistance of counsel may be found when there is a failure to investigate. Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 104 S. Ct. 2052, 80 L. Ed. 2d 674 (1984); People v. Everson, 213 A.D.3d 1294, 183 N.Y.S.3d 230 (4th Dep’t 2023); People v. Donovan, 184 A.D.2d 654, 585 N.Y.S.2d 70 (2d Dep’t 1992); Cosio v. U.S., 927 A.2d 1106 (D.C. 2007); People v. Dombrowski, 87 A.D.3d 1267, 930 N.Y.S.2d 321 (4th Dep’t 2011); see also ABA Standards for Criminal Justice, Standard § 4-4.1 (3d ed., 1993). “The failure to investigate is so fundamental to the deprivation of the effective assistance of trial counsel … that it cannot be rationalized away with a post hoc construction of the trial theory of defense.” People v. Fogle, 307 A.D.2d 299, 762 N.Y.S.2d 104 (2d Dep’t 2003); see also People v. Oliveras, 21 N.Y.3d 339, 971 N.Y.S.2d 221, 993 N.E.2d 1241 (2013); People v. Williams, 206 A.D.3d 1625, 168 N.Y.S.3d 613 (4th Dep’t 2022), leave to appeal denied, 38 N.Y.3d 1154, 174 N.Y.S.3d 52, 194 N.E.3d 759 (2022); People v. Bussey, 6 A.D.3d 621, 775 N.Y.S.2d 364 (2d Dep’t 2004). Cf. People v. Liboy, 15 A.D.3d 275, 789 N.Y.S.2d 493 (1st Dep’t 2005). The need to investigate is one of the most important areas of attorney effectiveness. Failing to contact and interview witnesses, or review pertinent records, is not a legitimate strategic decision. A witness’s unsavory background does not render the person’s testimony incredible as a matter of law. People v. Davis, 193 A.D.3d 967, 145 N.Y.S.3d 591 (2d Dep’t 2021).

 

Failure to investigate a viable alibi defense may constitute ineffective assistance. People v. Milazo, 18 A.D.3d 1068, 795 N.Y.S.2d 418 (3d Dep’t 2005). See also People v. Wiley, 120 A.D.2d 66, 507 N.Y.S.2d 928 (4th Dep’t 1986) (failure to request alibi charge).

 

Failure to undertake an investigation because the attorney believed the client could not afford an investigator, and did not want to apply for county funds for an investigator, constituted ineffective assistance. Thomas v. Kuhlman, 255 F. Supp. 2d 99 (E.D. N.Y. 2003); see also Hinton v. Alabama, 571 U.S. 263, 134 S. Ct. 1081, 188 L. Ed. 2d 1 (2014); People v. Carter, 167 A.D.3d 513, 88 N.Y.S.3d 339 (1st Dep’t 2018).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:80

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:80. Particular areas where effectiveness raised—Pretrial activity—Grand jury matters

Correlation Table

Ineffectiveness may also be found where insufficient attention is paid to procedure at the grand jury level. People v. Crown, 216 A.D.2d 484, 628 N.Y.S.2d 741 (2d Dep’t 1995); but see People v. Wiggins, 89 N.Y.2d 872, 653 N.Y.S.2d 91, 675 N.E.2d 845 (1996).

 

A defendant may testify at grand jury, if proper notice is given. However, the decision of whether to testify at that stage comes within tactical and strategic decisions, which are reserved for defense counsel. People v. Hogan, 26 N.Y.3d 779, 28 N.Y.S.3d 1, 48 N.E.3d 58 (2016). See § 6:43, Defense counsel’s obligation.

 

Practice Tip:

Defense counsel should inform the defendant, preferably in writing, about testifying before the grand jury, but often should advise against the defendant doing so. See § 6:43, Defense counsel’s obligation.

 

Example:

Not facilitating defendant’s presence before the grand jury was not ineffective, where defendant did not demonstrate that the outcome would have been different had he testified. People v. McPherson, 170 A.D.3d 1255, 95 N.Y.S.3d 469 (3d Dep’t 2019).

 

Counsel’s failing to effectuate defendant’s desire to testify before the grand jury was not per se ineffective assistance. While the right is a significant one, a defendant does not have a constitutional right to testify before the grand jury. People v. Robinson, 193 A.D.3d 1393, 147 N.Y.S.3d 792 (4th Dep’t 2021).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:81

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:81. Particular areas where effectiveness raised—Expert witness

Correlation Table

Failing to obtain expert witness testimony, or to avail of expert consultant to evaluate evidence when the attorney is unable to assess the evidence, may constitute ineffective assistance. People v. Tiger, 207 A.D.3d 574, 171 N.Y.S.3d 169 (2d Dep’t 2022), leave to appeal denied, 38 N.Y.3d 1190, 176 N.Y.S.3d 201, 197 N.E.3d 481 (2022); People v. Hull, 71 A.D.3d 1336, 898 N.Y.S.2d 284 (3d Dep’t 2010). Cf. People v. Caldavado, 166 A.D.3d 792, 88 N.Y.S.3d 236 (2d Dep’t 2018).

 

In the area of child sex offense prosecutions, a line of cases has stressed the importance of the defense obtaining expert witnesses. People v. Okongwu, 71 A.D.3d 1393, 897 N.Y.S.2d 330 (4th Dep’t 2010); Pavel v. Hollins, 261 F.3d 210 (2d Cir. 2001); Eze v. Senkowski, 321 F.3d 110, 128 (2d Cir. 2003); Gersten v. Senkowski, 426 F.3d 588 (2d Cir. 2005); Lindstadt v. Keane, 239 F.3d 191 (2d Cir. 2001); People v. Hernandez, 125 A.D.3d 885, 4 N.Y.S.3d 108 (2d Dep’t 2015). See also People v. Caldavado, 26 N.Y.3d 1034, 22 N.Y.S.3d 159, 43 N.E.3d 369 (2015) (failing to call expert on Shaken Baby Syndrome solely because of the number of People’s expert witnesses is not a legitimate strategy). Cf. Harrington v. Richter, 562 U.S. 86, 131 S. Ct. 770, 178 L. Ed. 2d 624 (2011); People v. Elliott, 73 A.D.3d 1444, 900 N.Y.S.2d 814 (4th Dep’t 2010).

 

But not calling an expert witness may be due to trial strategy. People v. Caldavado, 166 A.D.3d 792, 88 N.Y.S.3d 236 (2d Dep’t 2018); People v. Richards, 177 A.D.3d 1280, 112 N.Y.S.3d 394 (4th Dep’t 2019). And see People v. Sposito, 37 N.Y.3d 1149, 159 N.Y.S.3d 753, 180 N.E.3d 1053 (2022). An expert may be unable to testify as the defense would want. See People v. Defio, 200 A.D.3d 1672, 159 N.Y.S.3d 600 (4th Dep’t 2021), leave to appeal denied, 38 N.Y.3d 949, 2022 WL 1090103 (2022).

 

The issue may be outside the record on a direct appeal. People v. Ocasio, 81 A.D.3d 1469, 917 N.Y.S.2d 803 (4th Dep’t 2011).

 

Example:

Defense counsel’s challenging of evidence through cross-examination, rather than expert testimony, was a reasonable trial strategy. People v. Ross, 119 A.D.3d 964, 990 N.Y.S.2d 265 (2d Dep’t 2014); see also People v. King, 124 A.D.3d 1064, 1 N.Y.S.3d 569 (3d Dep’t 2015).

 

No ineffective assistance of counsel, despite defense counsel’s failure to provide his expert with every piece of information that conceivably aids the witness, even though the witness admitted that such information would have been useful and important. People v. Henderson, 27 N.Y.3d 509, 35 N.Y.S.3d 274, 54 N.E.3d 1145 (2016).

 

Where the crux of the defense is casting doubt on the prosecution’s medical proof, deciding that it would be futile to call an expert solely on the volume of the prosecution’s expert testimony is not a legitimate or rational tactical choice. People v. Caldavado, 26 N.Y.3d 1034, 22 N.Y.S.3d 159, 43 N.E.3d 369 (2015).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:82

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:82. Particular areas where effectiveness raised—Pretrial motions and hearings

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1883

 

 

Merely failing to bring a particular motion does not of itself constitute ineffective assistance of counsel. See, e.g., People v. Rivera, 71 N.Y.2d 705, 530 N.Y.S.2d 52, 525 N.E.2d 698 (1988); People v. Biro, 85 A.D.3d 1570, 925 N.Y.S.2d 285 (4th Dep’t 2011); People v. Mohamed, 226 A.D.2d 556, 641 N.Y.S.2d 332 (2d Dep’t 1996). Ineffectiveness will not be found where the motion had little likelihood of success. People v. Phelan, 82 A.D.3d 1279, 918 N.Y.S.2d 608, 72 A.L.R.6th 653 (3d Dep’t 2011). Nor does not filing an omnibus motion and instead, entering a guilty plea. People v. Hewitt, 201 A.D.3d 1041, 159 N.Y.S.3d 578 (3d Dep’t 2022), leave to appeal denied, 38 N.Y.3d 928, 164 N.Y.S.3d 28, 184 N.E.3d 849 (2022).

 

However, ineffectiveness has been found with the following:

         • Sandoval, People v. Langlois, 265 A.D.2d 683, 697 N.Y.S.2d 360 (3d Dep’t 1999); see also People v. Ofunniyin, 114 A.D.2d 1045, 495 N.Y.S.2d 485 (2d Dep’t 1985); People v. Webb, 90 A.D.3d 1563, 935 N.Y.S.2d 423 (4th Dep’t 2011), amended on other grounds on reargument, 92 A.D.3d 1268, 937 N.Y.S.2d 911 (4th Dep’t 2012). See Ch 11, Defendant’s Decision to Testify.

         • Huntley, People v. Carnevale, 101 A.D.3d 1375, 957 N.Y.S.2d 746 (3d Dep’t 2012); People v. Noll, 24 A.D.3d 688, 808 N.Y.S.2d 381 (2d Dep’t 2005); cf. People v. Vargas, 109 A.D.3d 1143, 971 N.Y.S.2d 624 (4th Dep’t 2013). But defense counsel is not obliged to seek suppression of a statement. People v. Sposito, 37 N.Y.3d 1149, 159 N.Y.S.3d 753, 180 N.E.3d 1053 (2022). See Ch 9, Suppression.

         Example:

         Failing to move to suppress a statement taken after 26 hours of questioning was found ineffective in a CPL 440 proceeding. Defense counsel maintained that defendant wanted to testify at trial and counsel did not want defendant subjected to additional testimony that could be used against him. But defense counsel was under no obligation to call defendant in a suppression hearing. Counsel had everything to gain and nothing to lose by moving to suppress. The Appellate Division said that this case represented one of the rare instances where failure to seek suppression denied defendant effective assistance. People v. Zeh, 144 A.D.3d 1395, 42 N.Y.S.3d 373 (3d Dep’t 2016).

          

         • speedy trial, Compare People v. Coulibaly, 172 A.D.3d 647, 101 N.Y.S.3d 318 (1st Dep’t 2019) with People v. Testamark, 173 A.D.3d 523, 103 N.Y.S.3d 394 (1st Dep’t 2019). See also People v. Smart, 163 A.D.3d 1039, 80 N.Y.S.3d 687 (3d Dep’t 2018); People v. Courtney, 249 A.D.2d 485, 671 N.Y.S.2d 667 (2d Dep’t 1998). See also People v. Stewart, 171 A.D.3d 625, 99 N.Y.S.3d 30 (1st Dep’t 2019); People v. Reed, 191 A.D.3d 1382, 137 N.Y.S.3d 800 (4th Dep’t 2017). Cf. People v. Brunner, 16 N.Y.3d 820, 922 N.Y.S.2d 248, 947 N.E.2d 139 (2011). See People v. Sweet, 79 A.D.3d 1772, 917 N.Y.S.2d 768 (4th Dep’t 2010). See Ch 13, Time Limits.

         • Molineux, People v. Felder, 186 A.D.2d 1050, 588 N.Y.S.2d 491 (4th Dep’t 1992). See Ch 12, Proving Guilt With Uncharged Crimes.

         • Wade, People v. Echavarria, 167 A.D.2d 138, 561 N.Y.S.2d 226 (1st Dep’t 1990). See Ch 9, Suppression.

         • Fourth Amendment, People v. Bilal, 27 N.Y.3d 961, 29 N.Y.S.3d 863, 49 N.E.3d 1155 (2016); People v. Velez, 138 A.D.3d 1041, 30 N.Y.S.3d 218 (2d Dep’t 2016); People v. Johnson, 37 A.D.3d 363, 830 N.Y.S.2d 546 (1st Dep’t 2007). See Ch 9, Suppression.

         Example:

         Counsel’s failure to raise a clear-cut, dispositive argument on the applicability of a statute was ineffective. People v. Allen, 184 A.D.3d 1076, 125 A.D.3d 783 (4th Dep’t 2020).

          

         • bill of particulars, People v. Toporczyk, 178 A.D.2d 947, 578 N.Y.S.2d 742 (4th Dep’t 1991). See Ch 8, Disclosure.

         • motion to dismiss, People v. Kilstein, 174 A.D.2d 756, 571 N.Y.S.2d 781 (2d Dep’t 1991) (among other inadequacies). See Ch 7, Motion and Hearing Practice.

         • waiver of indictment (and numerous other inadequacies), People v. Miller, 11 A.D.3d 729, 783 N.Y.S.2d 130 (3d Dep’t 2004).

         • Frye hearing, People v. Wilson, 164 A.D.3d 1012, 83 N.Y.S.3d 705 (3d Dep’t 2018).

 

Ineffectiveness was not found with the following:

         • failing to make a motion that has little or no chance of success. People v. Virapen, 147 A.D.3d 981, 47 N.Y.S.3d 426 (2d Dep’t 2017).

         • waiving suppression hearings, where waiver was made in exchange for additional time to consider plea offer. People v. Spencer, 169 A.D.3d 1268, 95 N.Y.S.3d 435 (3d Dep’t 2019).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:83

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:83. Particular areas where effectiveness raised—Trial tactics

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1884

 

 

“The right of a defendant to be represented by an attorney means more than just having a person with a law degree nominally represent him upon a trial and ask questions.” People v. Bennett, 29 N.Y.2d 462, 329 N.Y.S.2d 801, 280 N.E.2d 637 (1972).

 

Poor trial tactics may be grounds for finding ineffective assistance of counsel. People v. Lindo, 167 A.D.2d 558, 562 N.Y.S.2d 229 (2d Dep’t 1990); People v. Brown, 300 A.D.2d 314, 752 N.Y.S.2d 347 (2d Dep’t 2002).

 

Failing to call a witness after promising to do so does not, of itself, establish ineffective assistance. People v. Lopez-Mendoza, 33 N.Y.3d 565, 106 N.Y.S.3d 266, 130 N.E.3d 862 (2019).

 

While individual errors may not constitute ineffectiveness, the cumulative effect may deny effective assistance. People v. Oathout, 21 N.Y.3d 127, 967 N.Y.S.2d 654, 989 N.E.2d 936 (2013). See § 2:73, Cumulative error.

 

Where codefendants are joined for trial, one attorney’s ineffective assistance may cause another defendant to be denied a fair trial. See People v. Bell, 48 N.Y.2d 933, 425 N.Y.S.2d 57, 401 N.E.2d 180 (1979).

 

Failure to object to pervasive misconduct on prosecutor’s summation may be found ineffective. People v. Fisher, 18 N.Y.3d 964, 944 N.Y.S.2d 453, 967 N.E.2d 676 (2012).

 

But failure to make a meritorious motion for a trial order of dismissal has not been found to be ineffective. People v. Wright, 43 A.D.3d 1359, 843 N.Y.S.2d 482 (4th Dep’t 2007). See § 18:203, Making the motion.

 

Example:

When defense counsel’s actions are challenged, it may be necessary for defense counsel to address the matter, when asked to do so by the court, but counsel cannot take a position adverse to defendant’s motion. Even an indirect disagreement may result in counsel’s response being perceived as a conflict.

 

For example, defendant moved to withdraw his guilty plea, alleging that he had been coerced. Defense counsel’s response in court was that he did not adopt the motion’s merits or factual assertions, expressing concern that if he did not respond to the motion, his silence might be deemed acknowledgment that there was merit to the claim. The trial judge properly exercised discretion in assigning new counsel. People v. Mitchell, 21 N.Y.3d 964, 970 N.Y.S.2d 919, 993 N.E.2d 405 (2013).

 

The personal ethical dilemma of an attorney is markedly different from a professional ethical conflict. See People v. Ennis, 11 N.Y.3d 403, 872 N.Y.S.2d 364, 900 N.E.2d 915 (2008). An attorney’s subjective reasons are immaterial, so long as viewed objectively, a trial strategy might well have been used by a reasonably competent attorney. People v. Illescas, 87 A.D.3d 699, 928 N.Y.S.2d 762 (2d Dep’t 2011).

 

Delay in raising a repugnant verdict was not ineffective, as the jury could have returned a guilty verdict on both counts. People v. Stroud, 91 A.D.3d 1026, 936 N.Y.S.2d 381 (3d Dep’t 2012).

 

Courts are reluctant to second-guess decisions made on jury selection, which involve a quintessentially tactical decision. People v. Maffei, 35 N.Y.3d 264, 127 N.Y.S.3d 403, 150 N.E.3d 1169 (2020); People v. Santiago, 185 A.D.3d 1151, 126 N.Y.S.3d 812 (3d Dep’t 2020); People v. Piasta, 207 A.D.3d 1054, 170 N.Y.S.3d 776 (4th Dep’t 2022), leave to appeal denied, 38 N.Y.3d 1190, 176 N.Y.S.3d 222, 197 N.E.3d 502 (2022); People v. Walker, 191 A.D.3d 1154, 142 N.Y.S.3d 648 (3d Dep’t 2021); People v. Edwards, 151 A.D.3d 1832, 57 N.Y.S.3d 817 (4th Dep’t 2017). Cf. People v. Wlasiuk, 90 A.D.3d 1405, 935 N.Y.S.2d 709 (3d Dep’t 2011).

 

Ineffectiveness at trial has been found with:

         • failure to move to redact a laboratory report that implicated the defendant with a prior similar offense; the curative instruction was insufficient in a case that turned solely on credibility. People v. Alford, 33 A.D.3d 1014, 824 N.Y.S.2d 323 (2d Dep’t 2006).

         Example:

         The attorney’s deferring to the defendant on whether to submit a lesser included offense was constitutionally ineffective, as it denied the attorney’s expert advice. People v. Colville, 20 N.Y.3d 20, 955 N.Y.S.2d 799, 979 N.E.2d 1125 (2012); People v. Brown, 117 A.D.3d 1536, 985 N.Y.S.2d 375 (4th Dep’t 2014). See also, People v. Lee, 120 A.D.3d 1137, 992 N.Y.S.2d 429 (1st Dep’t 2014). Cf. People v. Gottsche, 118 A.D.3d 1303, 987 N.Y.S.2d 736 (4th Dep’t 2014).

          

         • venue, Cornell v. Kirkpatrick, 665 F.3d 369 (2d Cir. 2011).

Example:

Defense counsel was not ineffective where a count had been dismissed before trial, yet upon retrial it was again submitted to the jury, where defendant was acquitted of the count on retrial. The evidence on that count would have been admissible on retrial, thus defendant was not prejudiced by the error. People v. Lott, 55 A.D.3d 1274, 864 N.Y.S.2d 626 (4th Dep’t 2008).

 

Where trial counsel failed to prepare the witness to testify, this was a deliberate decision designed to enhance her credibility: counsel elicited that they had never met or discussed the case. People v. Newhall, 206 A.D.3d 1144, 168 N.Y.S.3d 746 (3d Dep’t 2022), leave to appeal denied, 39 N.Y.3d 941, 177 N.Y.S.3d 539, 198 N.E.3d 782 (2022).

 

Counsel was not ineffective by not obtaining a suppression hearing transcript. People v. Kuforiji, 88 A.D.3d 1165, 931 N.Y.S.2d 433 (3d Dep’t 2011).

 

 

Example:

Ineffective assistance has been found in the following situations:

         • Attorney on opening statement assumed the burden of proof, stating that defense would prove defendant was innocent. Defense counsel improperly assumed the relevancy of a Family Court custody award. People v. Dean, 50 A.D.3d 1052, 856 N.Y.S.2d 649 (2d Dep’t 2008). Cf. People v. Rodriguez, 211 A.D.3d 544, 180 N.Y.S.3d 32 (1st Dep’t 2022).

         • An attorney’s rambling opening statements and excessive and purposeless cross-examination constituted ineffectiveness. People v. Trait, 139 A.D.2d 937, 527 N.Y.S.2d 920 (4th Dep’t 1988); People v. Arnold, 85 A.D.3d 1330, 924 N.Y.S.2d 679 (3d Dep’t 2011). But there was no legitimate strategy to concede all of the points raised by the prosecutor at a suppression hearing. See People v. Johnson, 37 A.D.3d 363, 830 N.Y.S.2d 546 (1st Dep’t 2007).

         • The record in a burglary trial was replete with errors, including a defense that had no basis in law. People v. Miller, 63 A.D.3d 1186, 880 N.Y.S.2d 383 (3d Dep’t 2009).

         • Counsel’s theory at a drug-sale trial rested on a theory that was legally nonexistent: that defendant could not be convicted if he sold drugs to an intermediary, essentially admitting that defendant sold narcotics. People v. Holland, 115 A.D.3d 492, 981 N.Y.S.2d 425 (1st Dep’t 2014).

         • A legally indefensible strategy regarding a lesser included offense that permeated the entire defense theory of the case was not an isolated error, and was reviewable on direct appeal. People v. Yagudayev, 91 A.D.3d 888, 937 N.Y.S.2d 279 (2d Dep’t 2012).

         • Counsel’s offering into evidence a statement implicating defendant, made by another participant, was ineffective assistance. People v. Jeannot, 59 A.D.3d 737, 875 N.Y.S.2d 114 (2d Dep’t 2009); People v. Brown, 61 A.D.3d 1427, 879 N.Y.S.2d 263 (4th Dep’t 2009).

         • Cumulative effect of closely related errors was IAC. People v. Newman, 169 A.D.3d 1157, 94 N.Y.S.3d 400 (3d Dep’t 2019).

         • Defense counsel’s decision to forgo preclusion of sole eyewitness’s unnoticed identification; not objecting to the improper video identification by detective; and introducing mugshot that had “shooter” written on it—these were not legitimate tactical decisions. People v. McCray, 213 A.D.3d 423, 182 N.Y.S.3d 106 (1st Dep’t 2023).

         • Defense counsel did nothing. People v. Bush, 107 A.D.3d 1302, 967 N.Y.S.2d 779 (3d Dep’t 2013).

 

Defense counsel was not ineffective in the following:

         — Defense questioning that “opened the door” to evidence of uncharged crimes did not constitute ineffective assistance, as the attorney was pursuing a competent strategy to challenge the credibility of a key witness. People v. Henry, 297 A.D.2d 585, 748 N.Y.S.2d 2 (1st Dep’t 2002); People v. Davis, 90 A.D.3d 432, 933 N.Y.S.2d 663 (1st Dep’t 2011); People v. Delp, 156 A.D.3d 1450, 68 N.Y.S.3d 247 (4th Dep’t 2017). Cf. People v. Droz, 39 N.Y.2d 457, 384 N.Y.S.2d 404, 348 N.E.2d 880 (1976); People v. Hewitt, 95 A.D.3d 1358, 944 N.Y.S.2d 766 (2d Dep’t 2012); People v. Cyrus, 48 A.D.3d 150, 848 N.Y.S.2d 67 (1st Dep’t 2007). See § 18:184, ”Opening the door.”

         — No ineffectiveness occurred where defense counsel did not seek a mistrial, as counsel could have reasonably determined that there was greater risk of retrying the case. People v. Washington, 85 A.D.3d 1303, 924 N.Y.S.2d 668 (3d Dep’t 2011).

         — Defendant counsel’s failure to cross-examine an alibi witness was not ineffective, and may have been attributable to trial strategy. People v. Taylor, 1 N.Y.3d 174, 770 N.Y.S.2d 711, 802 N.E.2d 1109 (2003); People v. Watts, 218 A.D.3d 1171, 195 N.Y.S.3d 330 (4th Dep’t 2023), leave to appeal denied, 40 N.Y.3d 1013, 199 N.Y.S.3d 17, 222 N.E.3d 533 (2023).

         — Defense counsel’s concession of guilt on one count was not tantamount to a partial guilty plea, for which defendant’s express consent would have been required. People v. Weathersby, 30 A.D.3d 979, 815 N.Y.S.2d 844 (4th Dep’t 2006). See § 2:45, Counsel’s role: case strategy.

         — Failing to object to repugnant verdicts. People v. Jennings, 37 N.Y.3d 1078, 155 N.Y.S.3d 150, 177 N.E.3d 213 (2021).

         — Defense counsel failed to provide notice of extreme emotional disturbance. At trial, defendant testified but refused to testify of the circumstances of the homicide. Held, while failing to provide the notice was error, there was no ineffective assistance; defendant’s conduct on the witness stand was an independent basis for not giving the jury instruction. People v. Wells, 101 A.D.3d 1250, 955 N.Y.S.2d 684 (3d Dep’t 2012). See § 15:56, Extreme emotional disturbance as defense to Murder charge.

         — No ineffectiveness occurred with defense counsel’s failure to object to testimony regarding defendant’s out-of-court identification. People v. Vasquez, 20 N.Y.3d 461, 962 N.Y.S.2d 589, 985 N.E.2d 899 (2013).

         — Defense counsel failed to seek dismissal of misdemeanor counts that were time-barred. But counsel may have decided to keep them in so as to allow the jury to convict on those rather than on greater charges. People v. Ambers, 26 N.Y.3d 313, 22 N.Y.S.3d 400, 43 N.E.3d 757 (2015).

         — Failing to advise that it was defendant’s decision whether to testify was not ineffective. See People v. Dray, 193 A.D.3d 551, 147 N.Y.S.3d 14 (1st Dep’t 2021).

         — Justification defense might have undermined another stronger argument. People v. Bradley, 225 A.D.3d 1138, 207 N.Y.S.3d 277 (4th Dep’t 2024), leave to appeal denied, 2024 WL 2925029 (N.Y. 2024) and leave to appeal denied, 2024 WL 2925024 (N.Y. 2024).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:84

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:84. Particular areas where effectiveness raised—Trial tactics—Failure to use discovery or cross-examine

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1884

 

 

Failure to make use of discovery or hearing testimony on cross-examination may show ineffectiveness. People v. Cantave, 83 A.D.3d 857, 921 N.Y.S.2d 278 (2d Dep’t 2011); People v. Wallace, 187 A.D.2d 998, 591 N.Y.S.2d 129 (4th Dep’t 1992); People v. Clarke, 66 A.D.3d 694, 886 N.Y.S.2d 753 (2d Dep’t 2009). See People v. Lopez-Mendoza, 33 N.Y.3d 565, 106 N.Y.S.3d 266, 130 N.E.3d 862 (2019). Similarly, failure to use the records of previous proceedings in examining any witness indicates ineffectiveness. People v. Cantave, supra; People v. Riley, 101 A.D.2d 710, 475 N.Y.S.2d 691 (4th Dep’t 1984).

 

Example:

Among other things, defense counsel offered to stipulate to witness’s testimony, though he had no idea what the witness would testify to. People v. Bodden, 82 A.D.3d 781, 918 N.Y.S.2d 141 (2d Dep’t 2011).

 

Defense counsel’s arguing an uninvestigated theory of defense that was unsupported by the physical evidence was ineffective. People v. Barnes, 106 A.D.3d 600, 965 N.Y.S.2d 488 (1st Dep’t 2013); see also People v. Murray, 40 Misc. 3d 47, 970 N.Y.S.2d 659 (App. Term 2013) (arguing defenseless defense in DWI trial).

 

Failure to review a DVD with defendant was IAC. People v. Owens, 159 A.D.3d 1349, 72 N.Y.S.3d 285 (4th Dep’t 2018).

 

Failure to secure attendance of witness with exculpatory information was IAC. People v. Borcyk, 184 A.D.3d 1183, 125 N.Y.S.3d 517 (4th Dep’t 2020).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:85

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:85. Particular areas where effectiveness raised—Trial tactics—Failure to object

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1884

 

 

Failing to object to improper evidence or to improper arguments by the prosecution, may constitute ineffective assistance. People v. Wright, 25 N.Y.3d 769, 16 N.Y.S.3d 485, 37 N.E.3d 1127 (2015).

 

Example:

Failing to object may have been a reasonable trial strategy, to avoid drawing attention to minor evidence. People v. Masi, 151 A.D.3d 1389, 58 N.Y.S.3d 197 (3d Dep’t 2017).

 

But failing to object to comments on summation was found to be IAC on direct appeal. People v. Lakhani, 70 Misc. 3d 55, 137 N.Y.S.3d 617 (App. Term 2020).

 

Similarly, failure to object to nontestifying accomplice’s guilty plea. People v. Alvarenga, 218 A.D.3d 485, 193 N.Y.S.3d 140 (2d Dep’t 2023), leave to appeal denied, 40 N.Y.3d 1038, 200 N.Y.S.3d 766, 223 N.E.3d 1242 (2023).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:86

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:86. Particular areas where effectiveness raised—Trial tactics—Faulty evaluation of evidence

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1884

 

 

Failure to use crucial evidence, if due solely to the attorney’s erroneous assumption of its inadmissibility, may be so prejudicial as to deny meaningful representation. People v. Jenkins, 68 N.Y.2d 896, 508 N.Y.S.2d 937, 501 N.E.2d 586 (1986).

 

Failure to object to evidence may constitute ineffective assistance. People v. Brown, 61 A.D.3d 1427, 879 N.Y.S.2d 263 (4th Dep’t 2009).

 

Example:

Ineffective assistance was found where the crime under indictment required a prior conviction. The defense admitted to the prior conviction before trial, thereby avoiding the jury from learning of it. At trial, however, defense counsel consented to the prior guilty plea minutes being introduced. People v. Cleophus, 81 A.D.3d 844, 916 N.Y.S.2d 624 (2d Dep’t 2011).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:87

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:87. Mental health issues

Correlation Table

At a commitment hearing, counsel was ineffective for conceding that defendant had a dangerous mental disorder. People v. Darryl T., 166 A.D.3d 68, 84 N.Y.S.3d 458 (1st Dep’t 2018). See also People v. Greenfield, 167 A.D.3d 1060, 89 N.Y.S.3d 461 (3d Dep’t 2018) (440.10 hearing required).

 

Abandonment of psychiatric defense by counsel, who had the ultimate decision on the issue, was proper. People v. Diaz, 163 A.D.3d 110, 78 N.Y.S.3d 792 (3d Dep’t 2018). Cf. People v. Boodrow, 205 A.D.3d 1134, 167 N.Y.S.3d 633 (3d Dep’t 2022) (defense counsel acted properly in requesting a 730 exam over defendant’s objection).

 

Other mental health issues include:

         • severance, People v. Hall, 120 A.D.3d 588, 991 N.Y.S.2d 114 (2d Dep’t 2014); People v. Kirk, 290 A.D.2d 805, 736 N.Y.S.2d 778 (3d Dep’t 2002); People v. Meralla, 228 A.D.2d 160, 644 N.Y.S.2d 177 (1st Dep’t 1996); People v. Chapman, 54 A.D.3d 507, 862 N.Y.S.2d 660 (3d Dep’t 2008); People v. Davydov, 144 A.D.3d 1170, 43 N.Y.S.3d 74 (2d Dep’t 2016); cf. People v. Schultz, 128 A.D.3d 989, 9 N.Y.S.3d 402 (2d Dep’t 2015).

         • mental disease or defect, see People v. Nau, 21 A.D.3d 568, 800 N.Y.S.2d 584 (2d Dep’t 2005); People v. Oliveras, 21 N.Y.3d 339, 971 N.Y.S.2d 221, 993 N.E.2d 1241 (2013) (failing to obtain mental-health records or to consult with an expert, instead presenting a defense through mother’s testimony); People v. Jackson, 202 A.D.3d 1483, 160 N.Y.S.3d 527 (4th Dep’t 2022); Annot., Adequacy of Defense Counsel’s Representation of Criminal Client—Conduct at Trial Regarding Issues of Insanity, 95 A.L.R.5th 125. See §§ 15:50 et seq., Mental health, generally.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:88

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:88. Failure to request proper jury charge

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1884

 

 

An attorney who fails to request proper jury charges may be found ineffective. People v. Norfleet, 267 A.D.2d 881, 704 N.Y.S.2d 146 (3d Dep’t 1999); People v. Wiley, 120 A.D.2d 66, 507 N.Y.S.2d 928 (4th Dep’t 1986); People v. Smith, 30 A.D. 3d 693, 816 N.Y.S.2d 237 (3d Dep’t 2006). Cf. People v. Clarke, 55 A.D.3d 370, 865 N.Y.S.2d 211 (1st Dep’t 2008); People v. Calderon, 66 A.D.3d 314, 884 N.Y.S.2d 29 (1st Dep’t 2009) (failure to request LIO is not IAC); see also People v. Reyes, 84 A.D.3d 426, 922 N.Y.S.2d 339 (1st Dep’t 2011); People v. Illescas, 87 A.D.3d 699, 928 N.Y.S.2d 762 (2d Dep’t 2011); People v. Jones, 138 A.D.3d 1144, 30 N.Y.S.3d 329 (2d Dep’t 2016).

 

This includes:

         • failure to request lesser included offense, People v. Colville, 20 N.Y.3d 20, 955 N.Y.S.2d 799, 979 N.E.2d 1125 (2012); People v. Nesbitt, 20 N.Y.3d 1080, 965 N.Y.S.2d 743, 988 N.E.2d 478 (2013); People v. Jones, 167 A.D.3d 443, 89 N.Y.S.3d 156 (1st Dep’t 2018). See also People v. Orama, 157 A.D.3d 967, 70 N.Y.S.3d 249 (2d Dep’t 2018). Cf. People v. Bailey, 181 A.D.3d 1172, 118 N.Y.S.3d 351 (4th Dep’t 2020); People v. Quick, 187 A.D.3d 1612, 132 N.Y.S.3d 219 (4th Dep’t 2020).

         • failing to request missing witness charge, People v. Davydov, 144 A.D.3d 1170, 43 N.Y.S.3d 74 (2d Dep’t 2016). Cf. People v. Gonzales, 145 A.D.3d 1432, 43 N.Y.S.3d 616 (4th Dep’t 2016).

         • failing to request limiting instruction, People v. Miller, 87 A.D.3d 1075, 929 N.Y.S.2d 328 (2d Dep’t 2011); People v. Gavalo, 87 A.D.3d 1014, 929 N.Y.S.2d 321 (2d Dep’t 2011); People v. Wlasiuk, 90 A.D.3d 1405, 935 N.Y.S.2d 709 (3d Dep’t 2011).

 

Example:

Failure to request an instruction regarding voluntariness of defendant’s statement was not ineffective. After moving to suppress the statement, defense counsel could have reasonably concluded that there was insufficient evidence to challenge voluntariness at trial. People v. Parrotte, 34 A.D.3d 921, 823 N.Y.S.2d 593 (3d Dep’t 2006).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:89

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:89. Failure to request proper jury charge—Unconventional tactics

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1883

 

 

Unusual tactics do not necessarily reflect ineffective assistance, and may well indicate the reverse. People v. Zayas, 89 A.D.3d 610, 933 N.Y.S.2d 263 (1st Dep’t 2011); People v. Estrada, 192 A.D.2d 495, 597 N.Y.S.2d 668 (1st Dep’t 1993); People v. Hines, 24 A.D.3d 964, 806 N.Y.S.2d 737 (3d Dep’t 2005).

 

Example:

The result of a predictable defense may be an equally predictable guilty verdict. Instead, a creative approach may be needed to defeat that “garden variety” burglary charge.

 

Counsel may have had reason to inform the jury of suppressed identifications to challenge the reliability of another identification that was not suppressed. See People v. Foti, 83 A.D.2d 641, 441 N.Y.S.2d 521 (2d Dep’t 1981).

 

Practice Tip:

Counsel should make an effort to discuss unorthodox tactics with the client, and obtain the client’s approval, before engaging in them. Such consultation is conducive to a positive attorney-client relationship and can prevent posttrial attacks on effectiveness of counsel.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:90

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:90. Perjury intended by defendant

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1883

 

 

A defense attorney who learns of defendant’s intended perjury will be deemed to have acted effectively in discharging applicable ethical duties by first attempting to dissuade the defendant from testifying falsely, and then notifying the court. See People v. DePallo, 96 N.Y.2d 437, 729 N.Y.S.2d 649, 754 N.E.2d 751 (2001); People v. Diaz, 199 A.D.2d 182, 605 N.Y.S.2d 276 (1st Dep’t 1993); see also People v. Tyler, 245 A.D.2d 1100, 667 N.Y.S.2d 578 (4th Dep’t 1997); People v. Andrades, 4 N.Y.3d 355, 795 N.Y.S.2d 497, 828 N.E.2d 599 (2005); People v. Mercure, 47 A.D.3d 950, 851 N.Y.S.2d 603 (2d Dep’t 2008); Nix v. Whiteside, 475 U.S. 157, 106 S. Ct. 988, 89 L. Ed. 2d 123 (1986); generally, see Hall, Professional Responsibility in Criminal Defense Practice, 4th ed., ch 26. See also RPC 3.3(a)(3). The attorney should not assume that the client will commit perjury. The obligation to provide zealous representation is violated when lawyers second-guess their clients. See State v. McDowell, 2004 WI 70, 272 Wis. 2d 488, 681 N.W.2d 500 (2004).

 

Practice Tip:

A client who intends to commit perjury presents a nettlesome problem. One lower court ruled that a defense attorney acted properly by informing the court when the client “unequivocally informed” counsel of his intention to lie while testifying. No breach of confidentiality occurred because defendant’s intention to commit perjury was not a confidence or secret that the attorney was ethically required to preserve. See Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 1.6.

 

In this situation the court may not allow the attorney to withdraw, because the defendant is not entitled a new attorney to assist in possible perjury. When testifying, the defendant has the right to speak to the jury under oath, but the attorney should not question the client in the conventional manner. See Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 3.3; ABA Standards for Criminal Justice 4-7.7.

 

On summation, defense counsel should not argue the false version of the facts to the jury. People v. Salquerro, 107 Misc. 2d 155, 433 N.Y.S.2d 711 (Sup 1980), aff’d, 92 A.D.2d 1091, 460 N.Y.S.2d 971 (1st Dep’t 1983).

 

A defendant is ultimately to blame for committing perjury, which undercuts a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel. People v. Hagood, 291 A.D.2d 289, 737 N.Y.S.2d 611 (1st Dep’t 2002); see also People v. Hampton, 64 A.D.3d 872, 883 N.Y.S.2d 338 (3d Dep’t 2009).

 

Practice Tip:

With a perjury charge, a defense may be that the statement was literally true though unresponsive. The burden is on the questioner to recognize the evasiveness of an answer and pin the person down. Bronston v. U.S., 409 U.S. 352, 93 S. Ct. 595, 34 L. Ed. 2d 568 (1973); People v. Siggia, 163 A.D.2d 113, 558 N.Y.S.2d 518 (1st Dep’t 1990).

 

Where a prosecution witness makes a false statement, the prosecutor has an obligation to correct it. See § 18:231, Objections to prosecutor’s summation.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:91

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:91. Particular areas where effectiveness raised—Plea bargaining and guilty plea

Correlation Table

West’s Key Number Digest

•       West’s Key Number Digest, Criminal Law​1879 to 1883

 

 

A defendant is entitled to effective assistance of counsel when entering a plea. Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52, 106 S. Ct. 366, 88 L. Ed. 2d 203 (1985); see Ch 17, The Guilty Plea.

 

The right to effective assistance applies to pleading guilty, including when a defendant is not informed of a plea offer, or rejects a plea offer because of incompetent advice. Missouri v. Frye, 566 U.S. 134, 132 S. Ct. 1399, 182 L. Ed. 2d 379 (2012); Lafler v. Cooper, 566 U.S. 156, 132 S. Ct. 1376, 182 L. Ed. 2d 398 (2012). Defendant must demonstrate that a plea offer was made, that the defense attorney failed to inform him of that offer, and that he would have been willing to accept the offer. People v. Fernandez, 5 N.Y.3d 813, 803 N.Y.S.2d 22, 836 N.E.2d 1144 (2005); People v. Brett W., 144 A.D.3d 1314, 42 N.Y.S.3d 362 (3d Dep’t 2016). But this may be difficult to establish on direct appeal. See People v. Aponte, 190 A.D.3d 1031, 138 N.Y.S.3d 724 (3d Dep’t 2021). If that is shown, the prosecution may be directed to offer a prior, more favorable plea offer. People v. McGee, 166 A.D.3d 1390, 88 N.Y.S.3d 691 (3d Dep’t 2018). Where counsel’s error infects the plea-bargaining process, the conviction may be vacated. People v. Dealmeida, 124 A.D.3d 1405, 1 N.Y.S.3d 704 (4th Dep’t 2015). The plea offer should be placed on the record. People v. Roy, 122 A.D.2d 482, 505 N.Y.S.2d 242 (3d Dep’t 1986).

 

Defense counsel’s failure to inform the client of exculpatory evidence may constitute ineffective assistance. See People v. Campbell, 81 A.D.3d 1251, 916 N.Y.S.2d 426 (4th Dep’t 2011).

 

However, mistaken advice by an attorney regarding a sentence does not necessarily rise to the level of ineffective assistance. People v. Modica, 64 N.Y.2d 828, 486 N.Y.S.2d 931, 476 N.E.2d 330 (1985); People v. Culver, 94 A.D.3d 1427, 942 N.Y.S.2d 832 (4th Dep’t 2012); People v. Palma, 305 A.D.2d 333, 760 N.Y.S.2d 472 (1st Dep’t 2003); People v. Royal, 32 A.D.3d 1081, 821 N.Y.S.2d 305 (3d Dep’t 2006); cf. People v. Perron, 287 A.D.2d 808, 731 N.Y.S.2d 512 (3d Dep’t 2001); see § 17:36, Plea must be knowing, voluntary and intelligent. The defense must show there is a reasonable probability that, but for counsel’s error, defendant would not have pleaded guilty. People v. McDonald, 1 N.Y.3d 109, 769 N.Y.S.2d 781, 802 N.E.2d 131 (2003); People v. McKenzie, 4 A.D.3d 437, 771 N.Y.S.2d 551 (2d Dep’t 2004); see also People v. White, 67 A.D.3d 933, 889 N.Y.S.2d 236 (2d Dep’t 2009) (failure to advise that guilty plea would result in parole revocation). See § 22:204, Immigration consequences: Padilla and Peque.

 

Defense counsel may be obliged to urge a client to plead guilty, even where the client has the avowed intention of pursuing trial, where prevailing at trial appears hopeless and the defendant is offered a relatively favorable plea bargain. Boria v. Keane, 99 F.3d 492 (2d Cir. 1996), decision clarified on reh’g, 90 F.3d 36 (2d Cir. 1996); cf. People v. McGuire, 244 A.D.2d 292, 664 N.Y.S.2d 774 (1st Dep’t 1997); see also Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 1.4(b). Counsel has a constitutional duty to give the client the benefit of professional advice on whether or not to plead guilty. The attorney should communicate the strengths and weaknesses of the case, although reasonable representation does not always require an explicit opinion of whether the defendant should accept the plea offer. Pham v. U.S., 317 F.3d 178 (2d Cir. 2003). See People v. Wood, 203 A.D.3d 1406, 164 N.Y.S.3d 727 (3d Dep’t 2022) (attorney’s “frank advice” about strength of People’s case was effective assistance); People v. Rodriguez-Rivera, 203 A.D.3d 1624, 164 N.Y.S.3d 745 (4th Dep’t 2022); Purdy v. U.S., 208 F.3d 41 (2d Cir. 2000).

 

A court may require a prosecutor to reoffer a prior, more favorable plea offer on ineffective assistance of counsel grounds. See People v. Vargas, 173 A.D.3d 1466, 103 N.Y.S.3d 669 (3d Dep’t 2019).

 

Where a defendant who has pleaded guilty seeks to withdraw the plea, counsel should in no way undermine that effort. People v. Mitchell, 21 N.Y.3d 964, 970 N.Y.S.2d 919, 993 N.E.2d 405 (2013); People v. Duart, 113 A.D.3d 788, 978 N.Y.S.2d 369 (2d Dep’t 2014); People v. Faulkner, 168 A.D.3d 1317, 92 N.Y.S.3d 753 (3d Dep’t 2019); People v. Bryant, 22 A.D.3d 676, 804 N.Y.S.2d 347 (2d Dep’t 2005); cf. People v. Faden, 1 A.D.3d 200, 767 N.Y.S.2d 92 (1st Dep’t 2003). But where counsel does not join in the motion, the judge is not required to assign new counsel. People v. Arnold, 102 A.D.3d 1061, 958 N.Y.S.2d 540 (3d Dep’t 2013). At other stages in a criminal action as well, the attorney shall not take a position contrary to the client. People v. Gruttadauria, 40 A.D.3d 879, 836 N.Y.S.2d 272 (2d Dep’t 2007); cf. People v. Rogers, 43 A.D.3d 1189, 842 N.Y.S.2d 584 (2d Dep’t 2007) (CPL 330.30 motion). See § 17:68, When conflict with attorney arises.

 

Where defense counsel represents a prosecution witness, a conflict of interest exists. On appeal, to establish ineffective representation, the defendant must show that the conflict bears a substantial relation to the conduct of the defense. People v. Smalls, 282 A.D.2d 873, 725 N.Y.S.2d 421 (3d Dep’t 2001); People v. Gonzalez, 180 A.D.2d 816, 580 N.Y.S.2d 414 (2d Dep’t 1992).

 

Where a person who is released from custody or is on recognizance fails to return to court, a Bail Jumping charge may be filed. People v. Edmond, 84 A.D.2d 938, 447 N.Y.S.2d 60 (4th Dep’t 1981).

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:92

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:92. Particular areas where effectiveness raised—Collateral consequences; immigration

Correlation Table

Beyond the direct consequences of a conviction are many collateral consequences that do not occur through the criminal proceeding but may be taken by agencies, or that happen as a matter of law. Generally, failing to inform, or perhaps misinforming, a client of collateral consequences is not ineffective assistance. See People v. Catu, 4 N.Y.3d 242, 792 N.Y.S.2d 887, 825 N.E.2d 1081 (2005). See §§ 22:201 et seq., Knowledge of consequences.

 

One exception is in the area of immigration: defense counsel is obligated to provide information on the immigration consequences. Padilla v. Kentucky, 559 U.S. 356, 130 S. Ct. 1473, 176 L. Ed. 2d 284 (2010). See § 22:204, Immigration consequences: Padilla and Peque.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document

 

© 2025 Thomson Reuters. No claim to original U.S. Government Works.

 

 

 

 

Handling a Criminal Case in New York § 2:93

Handling a Criminal Case in New York | October 2024 Update

Gary Muldoon

Chapter 2. Role of Defense Counsel

IV. Effective assistance of counsel

§ 2:93. Particular areas where effectiveness raised—Sentencing

Correlation Table

Before sentence is imposed, counsel should be familiar with the defendant and the presentence report. People v. Stella, 188 A.D.2d 318, 590 N.Y.S.2d 478 (1st Dep’t 1992); People v. Jones, 15 A.D.3d 208, 789 N.Y.S.2d 476 (1st Dep’t 2005); People v. Susankar, 34 A.D.3d 201, 824 N.Y.S.2d 28 (1st Dep’t 2006); cf. People v. Stickey, 114 A.D.3d 532, 980 N.Y.S.2d 118 (1st Dep’t 2014); see § 22:155, Defense counsel entitled to copy of report. However, in general, defense counsel’s inability to persuade the sentencing judge to impose a lower sentence is not ineffective assistance. People v. Smith, 300 A.D.2d 745, 751 N.Y.S.2d 665 (3d Dep’t 2002).

 

Examples:

No ineffective assistance was found with:

 

Incorrect advice to defendant who did not plead guilty, about mandatory consecutive sentences, was not ineffective, where there was no possibility that a reduced plea would have been offered. People v. Bank, 28 N.Y.3d 131, 42 N.Y.S.3d 651, 65 N.E.3d 680 (2016).

 

Ineffective assistance was found in the following:

 

Failing to challenge a previous felony conviction, and giving incorrect advice on concurrent sentencing. People v. Perron, 287 A.D.2d 808, 731 N.Y.S.2d 512 (3d Dep’t 2001); see also People v. Agard, 127 A.D.3d 602, 8 N.Y.S.3d 125 (1st Dep’t 2015); People v. Wimberly, 86 A.D.3d 651, 926 N.Y.S.2d 718 (3d Dep’t 2011).

 

Failing to correct the assumption that defendant was a persistent violent felony offender, rather than a second violent felony offender, resulting in an unfavorable guilty plea. People v. Garcia, 19 A.D.3d 17, 795 N.Y.S.2d 216 (1st Dep’t 2005).

 

Giving incorrect advice on defendant’s eligibility for shock incarceration program. People v. Wiggins, 126 A.D.3d 1229, 4 N.Y.S.3d 404 (3d Dep’t 2015).

 

Failing to properly advise of the period of postrelease supervision. People v. Jordan, 169 A.D.3d 1357, 92 N.Y.S.3d 766 (4th Dep’t 2019).

 

On the record, defense counsel stated that he had advised of consecutive sentences if convicted at trial. Defendant was not presented with legitimate alternatives about the maximum: misdemeanor and felony sentences had to run concurrently. People v. Keller, 168 A.D.3d 1098, 92 N.Y.S.3d 415 (2d Dep’t 2019).

 

Defendant had already served the maximum sentence. When he pleaded guilty again, he was denied effective assistance. People v. Jones, 171 A.D.3d 1249, 97 N.Y.S.3d 784 (3d Dep’t 2019).

 

Failing to challenge enhanced sentence after judge failed to warn defendant of consequences of being rearrested before sentencing. Goewey v. Hogan, 102 N.Y.S.2d 339 (Sup 1951); see also People v. Barnes, 177 A.D.3d 1168, 115 N.Y.S.3d 485 (3d Dep’t 2019).

 

Ineffectiveness was not found with the following:

         — Where counsel did not seek a sentence under the DVSJA. People v. Riley, 221 A.D.3d 1162, 200 N.Y.S.3d 150 (3d Dep’t 2023), leave to appeal denied, 40 N.Y.3d 1094, 204 N.Y.S.3d 783, 228 N.E.3d 597 (2024).

 

The area of Youthful Offender treatment is one that the Court of Appeals has made clear requires special consideration. See People v. Rudolph, 21 N.Y.3d 497, 974 N.Y.S.2d 885, 997 N.E.2d 457 (2013). See § 21:63 and following, Purpose and effect of Youthful Offender status.

 

Where YO status is possible, defense counsel should submit mitigating information in support.

 

Westlaw. © 2024 Thomson Reuters. No Claim to Orig. U.S. Govt. Works.

End of Document
